Authors: Armstrong S.E., Loveless T.D., Hicks J.R., Holman W.T., McMorrow D., Massengill L.W.
Title: Phase-dependent single-event sensitivity analysis of high-speed A/MS circuits extracted from asynchronous measurements
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Institute for Space and Defense Electronics, Nashville, TN 37235-1683, United States; Center for Human Genetics Research, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232-0700, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, S.E., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States, Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Loveless, T.D., Institute for Space and Defense Electronics, Nashville, TN 37235-1683, United States; Hicks, J.R., Center for Human Genetics Research, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232-0700, United States; Holman, W.T., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; McMorrow, D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Massengill, L.W., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States
Abstract: A method for experimental determination of the phase dependence of single-event sensitivity in high-speed A/MS circuits is presented. The technique ensures testing coverage of the complete data cycle and results in a correlation of errors to the data or clock cycle of the circuit. Designers can apply the information, along with knowledge of the circuit state at the time of errors, to make informed radiation-hardening-by-design decisions. © 2011 IEEE.

Authors: Gadlage M.J., Ahlbin J.R., Bhuva B.L., Hooten N.C., Dodds N.A., Reed R.A., Massengill L.W., Schrimpf R.D., Vizkelethy G.
Title: Alpha-particle and focused-ion-beam-induced single-event transient measurements in a bulk 65-nm CMOS technology
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Sandia National Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM 87123, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Ahlbin, J.R., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Bhuva, B.L., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Hooten, N.C., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Dodds, N.A., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Reed, R.A., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Massengill, L.W., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Vizkelethy, G., Sandia National Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM 87123, United States
Abstract: Pulse widths of single-event transients produced by alpha particles in a 65-nm bulk CMOS technology are reported. The experimental setup and calibration of the alpha particle experiment is described in detail. A focused-ion beam is also utilized to explore how pulse broadening in the test circuit impacts the alpha particle SET measurements. The results of this work show that alpha particles are able to induce transient signals with a width of about 25 ps in this technology. © 2011 IEEE.

Authors: Dauby J.P., Dagli C.H.
Title: The canonical decomposition fuzzy comparative methodology for assessing architectures
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Missouri University of Science and Technology, Rolla, MO 65409, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dauby, J.P., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Dagli, C.H., Missouri University of Science and Technology, Rolla, MO 65409, United States
Abstract: The challenge for system architects is to perform a realistic assessment of an inherently ambiguous system concept. Many existing assessment methods are available, but these are often subjective and unrepeatable. Repeatability, objectivity, and increased fidelity are desired. An architecture assessment methodology capable of achieving these objectives is possible by drawing on the strengths of existing approaches while addressing their collective weaknesses. The proposed methodology is the Canonical Decomposition Fuzzy Comparative approach. The theoretical foundations of this methodology are developed herein and tested through the assessment of three physical architectures for a peer-to-peer wireless network. An extensible modeling framework is established to decompose high-level system attributes into technical performance measures suitable for analysis via computational modeling. Canonical design primitives are used to assess antenna performance in the form of a comparative analysis between the baseline free space gain patterns and the installed gain patterns. Finally, a fuzzy inference system is used to interpret the comparative feature set and offer a numerical assessment. The results of this experiment support the assertion that the proposed methodology is well suited for exposing integration sensitivity and assessing coupled performance in physical architecture concepts. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Dauby J.P., Upholzer S.
Title: Exploring behavioral dynamics in systems of systems
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dauby, J.P., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Upholzer, S., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: This paper summarizes the early stages of research into methodologies for understanding the governing principles in systems of systems. An approach is suggested utilizing computational intelligence, agent based modeling, and wireless ad hoc network simulation as a computational testbed for exploring the generalized dynamics of complex adaptive systems. Utilizing a standard 802.11 ad hoc protocol set, the network can be understood in terms of its capabilities and limitations. Agent based modeling facilitates the individual autonomy aspect of system of systems participants and is responsible for determining how a node will use the 802.11 protocol. Evolutionary algorithms can be used to evolve the protocol usage strategies of the individuals. It is proposed that the evolutionary algorithm and agent based model provide the flexibility and autonomy needed to simulate a representative system of systems while the clear definition of the 802.11 protocol provides a framework for the experiment. © 2011 Published by Elsevier Ltd.

Authors: Gadlage M.J., Ahlbin J.R., Bhuva B.L., Massengill L.W., Schrimpf R.D., Narasimham B.
Title: Single-Event Transient Measurements in nMOS and pMOS Transistors in a 65-nm Bulk CMOS Technology at Elevated Temperatures
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37212, United States; Broadcom Corporation, Irvine, CA 92617, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Ahlbin, J.R., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37212, United States; Bhuva, B.L., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37212, United States; Massengill, L.W., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37212, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37212, United States; Narasimham, B., Broadcom Corporation, Irvine, CA 92617, United States
Abstract: In this paper, heavy-ion-induced single-event transient (SET) pulsewidths measured in a 65-nm bulk CMOS technology at temperatures ranging from 25 °C to 100 °C with an autonomous SET capture circuit are presented. The experimental results for the SETs induced in two different inverter chain circuits indicate an increase in the average SET pulsewidth as a function of the operating temperature. Unique SET test structures were also designed to differentiate between SETs induced in an nMOS transistor and those induced in a pMOS transistor. The SET widths induced in a pMOS transistor increase more with temperature than the SETs induced in an nMOS transistor. © 2011, IEEE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Hoover L., Crespo W., Mitsdarffer K.B.
Title: Direct IF sampling of HPA's AM and PM noise
Affiliations: Polyphase Microwave Inc., Bloomington, IN, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoover, L., Polyphase Microwave Inc., Bloomington, IN, United States; Crespo, W., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Mitsdarffer, K.B., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: The development of a novel technique for measuring HPA (High Power Amplifiers) AM (Amplitude Modulation) and PM (Phase Modulation) noise is reported. The new method utilizes a dual channel microwave downconverter and a 16-bit high-speed digitizer to directly sample the IF allowing digital demodulation of AM and PM noise simultaneously. A prototype AM/PM noise measurement system has been built with a measurement single-sideband noise floor of -155 dBc/Hz at 100 kHz offset from the carrier. © 2010 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Digital demodulation; Digitizers; Down converters; Dual channel; High power amplifier; High-speed; Noise measurement systems; Novel techniques; Single-sideband noise; High energy physics; Light velocity; Power amplifiers; Amplitude modulation

Authors: Jagannathan S., Gadlage M.J., Bhuva B.L., Schrimpf R.D., Narasimham B., Chetia J., Ahlbin J.R., Massengill L.W.
Title: Independent measurement of SET pulse widths from N-hits and P-hits in 65-nm CMOS
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Broadcomm Corporation, Irvine, CA 92617, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jagannathan, S., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Bhuva, B.L., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Narasimham, B., Broadcomm Corporation, Irvine, CA 92617, United States; Chetia, J., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Ahlbin, J.R., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Massengill, L.W., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States
Abstract: A novel circuit design for separating single-event transients due to N-hits and P-hits is described. Measurement results obtained from a 65 nm technology using heavy-ions show different dominant mechanisms for charge collection for P-hits and N-hits. The data collected represent the first such separation of SET pulse widths for 65 nm bulk CMOS technology. For low LET particles, N-hit transients are longer, but for high LET particles, P-hit transients are longer. N-well depth and the parasitic bipolar effect are shown to be the most important parameters affecting transient pulse widths. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Armstrong S.E., Olson B.D., Holman W.T., Warner J., McMorrow D., Massengill L.W.
Title: Demonstration of a differential layout solution for improved ASET tolerance in CMOS A/MS circuits
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, S.E., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States, Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Olson, B.D., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Holman, W.T., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Warner, J., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; McMorrow, D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Massengill, L.W., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States
Abstract: Layout techniques that exploit charge-sharing phenomena for analog single-event transient (ASET) mitigation in fully-differential analog/mixed-signal (A/MS) designs are experimentally explored in a 65 nm CMOS process. Benefits of the proposed RHBD layout techniques are illustrated through circuit simulations. Preliminary RHBD layout guidelines are discussed. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Crespo W.F., Mitsdarfer K.B., Hoover L.
Title: The next generation radar component analyzer (RCA)
Source title: Proceedings of the International Instrumentation Symposium
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Polyphase Microwave, 1111, 17th Street, Bloomington, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crespo, W.F., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Mitsdarfer, K.B., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Hoover, L., Polyphase Microwave, 1111, 17th Street, Bloomington, IN, United States
Abstract: The development of a second generation RCA (radar component analyzer) is reported. The RCA was developed by NSWC (Navy Surface Warfare Center) Crane to measure critical performance parameters of radar components and HPA (High Power Amplifiers) like TWT (Traveling Wave Tubes) and CFA (Cross Field Amplifiers) which are used in legacy and modern radar systems. The RCA is comprised of a rack mount 2-18 GHz dual channel receiver and ruggedized COTS computer system running N1 (National Instruments) LabVIEW™. The dual channel receiver down converts both microwave inputs to a common intermediate frequency (IF) using a patented offset local oscillator technique. Both IF channels are sampled using a new SOA (State Of the Art) COTS (Commercial off The Shelf) digitizer. This new version of the RCA utilizes a new modified dual channel microwave down converter and a SOA 16-bit high-speed digitizer as opposed to the previous version which only used a 12 bit, to directly sample the IF allowing digital demodulation of AM (Amplitude Modulation) and PM (Phase Modulation) noise simultaneously. This second generation RCA prototype is used as AM/PM noise measurement system and has been built with a measurement single sideband noise floor of -155 dBc/Hz at 100 kHz offset from the carrier.

Authors: Crespo W.F., Mitsdarffer K.B., Hoover L.
Title: IF Sampling of TWT AM and PM noise using cross-correlation
Source title: Proceedings of the International Instrumentation Symposium
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Polyphase Microwave, 1111, 17th Street, Bloomington, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crespo, W.F., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Mitsdarffer, K.B., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Hoover, L., Polyphase Microwave, 1111, 17th Street, Bloomington, IN, United States
Abstract: The development of a novel technique for measuring TWT AM and PM noise is reported. This technique was developed by NSWC Crane to measure critical performance parameters of radar components and HPA(High Power amplifiers) like TWT(travelling wave tubes) and CFA's (cross field amplifiers) which are used in legacy and modern radar systems. The second generation RCA (radar component analyzer), which is a prototype system implements this novel measurement technique of cross-correlation noise averaging to reduce the effects of digitizer quantization noise. By sampling 0 and 90 degree versions of the IF(intermediate frequency) signals, the system can identify and remove digitizer-generated spurious tones from the noise measurement. This novel technique results in a processing gain of 5 to 10 dB increase of the noise floor as well as elimination or reduction of these spurious tones. This method takes advantage of using a SOA (state of the art) 16 bit digitizer with quad channel acquisitions to cross correlate the down converted signals and use phase detection algorithms to eliminate and reduce non DUT(device under test) induced noise creating a lower noise floor measuring a DUT.
Author Keywords: AM and PM; HSD; IF; Noise; Radar; Test; TWT

Authors: Mitsdarffer K.B., Crespo W.F., Hoover L.R.
Title: 7.5: Direct IF sampling of TWT AM and PM noise
Source title: 2010 IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2010
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Polyphase Microwave Inc., Bloomington, IN, United States

Abstract: The development of a novel technique for measuring TWT AM and PM noise is reported. The new method utilizes a dual channel microwave downconverter and a 16-bit high-speed digitizer to directly sample the IF allowing digital demodulation of AM and PM noise simultaneously. A prototype AM/PM noise measurement system has been built with a measurement single-sideband noise floor of -155 dBc/Hz at 100 kHz offset from the carrier. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Harms J.W.
Title: Revision of MIL-HDBK-217, reliability prediction of electronic equipment
Source title: Proceedings - Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Bldg 3334, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47421, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harms, J.W., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Bldg 3334, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47421, United States
Abstract: This paper will discuss current efforts in the revision of MIL-HDBK-217, Military Handbook, Reliability Prediction of Electronic Equipment. It has been over a decade since this reliability prediction handbook was last updated, yet it remains the most widely used reliability prediction method for electronic equipment. In February 2008, the Defense Standardization Program Office (DSPO) tasked the Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), as the Preparing Activity, to revise MIL-HDBK-217. A plan has been created to refresh the handbook and to look at adding a new approach to better reflect reliability of electronic equipment. A working group of individuals representing Department of Defense (DoD) and industry has been established to conduct this revision. Development and implementation of solutions that reflect industry best practices and DoD needs is critical for success. Results of this task are planned to be new revisions of MIL-HDBK-217. These revisions will provide an updated reliability prediction tool that will assist reliability engineers in performing their work.

Authors: Liu S., Titus J.L., Zafrani M., Cao H., Carrier D., Sherman P.
Title: Worst-case test conditions of SEGR for power DMOSFETs
Affiliations: International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Titus, J.L., NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Zafrani, M., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Cao, H., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Carrier, D., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Sherman, P., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States
Abstract: Heavy ion test results show worst-case test conditions for single-event gate rupture (SEGR) of power MOSFETs. Contrary to common belief, the worst-case ion condition for SEGR is not the ion with the deepest penetration depth in the device or highest LET at the die surface, but the ion beams with Bragg Peak positioned at or near the interface of the epitaxial layer and the highly doped substrate. The factors that have significant impact on SEGR thresholds are evaluated and discussed. The factors that are considered include: ion beam, drain bias, gate bias, ion species, ion range, surface LET and the construction layer of the power DMOSFET. An estimated worst-case ion range table for krypton, xenon and gold is provided for reference. Index Terms-MOSFET, Single Event Effect (SEE), Single Event Gate Rupture (SEGR), worst-case. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Crespo W.F., Mitsdarffer K.B., Hoover L.
Title: Radar Component Analyzer (RCA)
Source title: Proceedings of the International Instrumentation Symposium
Affiliations: Technology Service Corporation, 116 West Sixth Street, Bloomington, IN, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Polyphase Microwave, 1111, 17th Street, Bloomington, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crespo, W.F., Technology Service Corporation, 116 West Sixth Street, Bloomington, IN, United States; Mitsdarffer, K.B., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; Hoover, L., Polyphase Microwave, 1111, 17th Street, Bloomington, IN, United States
Abstract: The development of a 2-18 GHz Radar Component Analyzer (RCA) for Ballistic Missile Defense System (BMDS) test and measurement will be presented in this paper. The RCA was developed by NSWC Crane to measure critical performance parameters of the AN/SPY-1 radar's components. Typical measurements include clutter attenuation, clutter improvement factor, intra-pulse noise, Moving Target Indicator residues, random pulse jitter, systematic pulse jitter, phase noise, and amplitude noise. The RCA is comprised of a rack mount 2-18 GHz dual channel receiver and ruggedized COTS computer system running LabVIEW. The dual channel receiver downconverts both microwave inputs to a common intermediate frequency (IF) using a patented offset local oscillator technique. Both IF channels are sampled using COTS digitizers at 400 MSamples/s with 72 dBc spurious free dynamic range. The digitized signals are then transferred to an external COTS computer system for digital down conversion, signal processing, and display. The RCA can measure radar transmitter and receiver components in-system using the radar's own waveforms. The RCA is compatible with BMDS radars that employ frequency diversity, staggered pulse repetition frequencies, nonlinear chirp pulse compression, and phase coding. Radar communication waveforms using complex modulations are also supported.

Authors: Gouker P.M., Gadlage M.J., McMorrow D., McMarr P., Hughes H., Wyatt P., Keast C., Bhuva B.L., Narasimham B.
Title: Effects of ionizing radiation on digital single event transients in a 180-nm fully depleted SOI process
Affiliations: Lincoln Laboratory, Advanced Silicon Technology Group, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02420, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6812, Washington, DC 20375-0001, United States; Broadcom Inc., Irvine, CA 92617-3068, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gouker, P.M., Lincoln Laboratory, Advanced Silicon Technology Group, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02420, United States; Gadlage, M.J., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; McMorrow, D., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; McMarr, P., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Hughes, H., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wyatt, P., Lincoln Laboratory, Advanced Silicon Technology Group, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02420, United States; Keast, C., Lincoln Laboratory, Advanced Silicon Technology Group, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02420, United States; Bhuva, B.L., Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6812, Washington, DC 20375-0001, United States; Narasimham, B., Broadcom Inc., Irvine, CA 92617-3068, United States
Abstract: Effect of ionizing radiation on single event transients are reported for Fully Depleted SOI (FDSOI) technology using experiments and simulations. Logic circuits, i.e. CMOS inverter chains, were irradiated with cobalt-60 gamma radiation. When charge is induced in the n-channel FET with laser-probing techniques, laser-induced transients widen with increased total dose. This is because radiation causes charge to be trapped in the buried oxide, and reduces the p-channel FET drive current. When the p-channel FET drive current is reduced, the time required to restore the output of the laser-probed FET back to its original condition is increased, i.e. the upset transient width is increased. A widening of the transient pulse is also observed when a positive bias is applied to the wafer without any exposure to radiation. This is because a positive wafer bias reproduces the shifts in FET threshold voltages that occur during total dose irradiation. Results were also verified with heavy ion testing and mixed mode simulations. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Armstrong S.E., Olson B.D., Popp J., Braatz J., Loveless T.D., Holman W.T., McMorrow D., Massengill L.W.
Title: Single-event transient error characterization of a radiation-hardened by design 90 nm SerDes transmitter driver
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Solid State Electronics Development Group, Boeing Company, Seattle WA 98124-2207, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, S.E., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States, Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Olson, B.D., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Popp, J., Solid State Electronics Development Group, Boeing Company, Seattle WA 98124-2207, United States; Braatz, J., Solid State Electronics Development Group, Boeing Company, Seattle WA 98124-2207, United States; Loveless, T.D., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Holman, W.T., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; McMorrow, D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Massengill, L.W., Radiation Effects Group, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States
Abstract: The analysis and measurement of a radiation hardened by design 3.125 Gbps SerDes transmitter driver fabricated in commercial 90 nm CMOS is presented. The transmit driver is implemented in thick oxide 2.5 V devices. Testing and simulation of laser-induced single-event transients of a fabricated driver section are discussed. A highly-flexible data collection technique that allows post-processing of data for different error types and thresholds within a single data set is presented. This effort represents the first single-event effects measurement and analysis on a highly-scaled analog/RF CMOS circuit element operating at GHz frequencies. Sensitive nodes are identified through experiment and simulation. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Mitsdarffer K.B., Crespo W., Hoover L.
Title: Automated noise measurement system for radar and EW transmitter components
Source title: 2009 IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2009
Affiliations: Technology Service Corporation Bloomington, IN, United States; Polyphase Microwave Bloomington, IN, United States; Radar Technologies Division, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, 47522, United States

Abstract: The development of a 2-18 GHz instrument for radar and EW transmitter test and measurement is reported. The Transmitter Component Analyzer was developed by NSWC Crane to measure critical performance parameters of the AN/SPY-1 radar's components. Typical measurements include clutter attenuation, clutter improvement factor, intrapulse noise, Moving Target Indicator residues, random pulse jitter, systematic pulse jitter, phase noise, and amplitude noise. ©2009 IEEE.

Authors: Headrick W.J., Lopes T., Mikolaj J.A.
Title: Legacy support in a new age - A digital perspective
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin, 12506 Lake Underhill Road, Orlando, FL 32825-5002, United States; Teradyne, Inc., 700 Riverpark Drive, N. Reading, MA 01864, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Code WXSM Bldg. 3330C, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Headrick, W.J., Lockheed Martin, 12506 Lake Underhill Road, Orlando, FL 32825-5002, United States; Lopes, T., Teradyne, Inc., 700 Riverpark Drive, N. Reading, MA 01864, United States; Mikolaj, J.A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Code WXSM Bldg. 3330C, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Support of legacy Test Systems and Test program Sets (TPS) is a complex and often difficult task. The current trend to support systems with Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) systems complicates the process tremendously. In order to provide compatibility with legacy TPSs, and yet introduce new technology and capability, many compromises must be made. There is a tremendous amount of money spent in the development of Test Systems, TPSs (including TPS hardware), and support infrastructure. In this paper we will address the process involved in replacing a complex Digital Test Unit (DTU) with a new more complex and more capable system. ©2008 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Heat shielding; Light weight rolling stock; Testing; Current trends; Infra structures; New technologies; Support systems; Test programs; Legacy systems

Abstract: An on-chip charge-collection measurement circuit has been designed and fabricated in a 130 nm bulk CMOS process. Laser testing is used to verify the effectiveness of the on-chip charge-collection circuit technique for characterizing single event charge collection in advanced technologies. The on-chip charge-collection measurement circuit is used as an investigative tool for examining the effects of parasitic bipolar amplification for deep-submicron PMOS devices. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Casey M.C., Duncan A.R., Bhuva B.L., Robinson W.H., Massengill L.W.
Title: Simulation study on the effect of multiple node charge collection on error cross-section in CMOS sequential logic
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47533, United States; Motorola, Inc., Libertyville, IL 60048, United States
Authors with affiliations: Casey, M.C., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Duncan, A.R., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47533, United States, Motorola, Inc., Libertyville, IL 60048, United States; Bhuva, B.L., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Robinson, W.H., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Massengill, L.W., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States
Abstract: A technique for estimating error cross-section for combinational circuits based on charge collection at multiple nodes is presented. Ordinarily, charge collection from an ion strike is assumed to occur only on a single node, but with decreasing feature sizes in nanometer technologies, charge sharing among devices is worsening, leading to charge collection on multiple nodes. When multiple SETs are considered, simulation results show a $380\ times$increase in cross-section with a four-bit carry look-ahead generator, and a $27\times$ increase with a four-bit arithmetic logic unit. Additionally, both circuits show a linear increase in cross-section as frequency increases. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Casey M.C., Amusan O.A., Nation S.A., Loveless T.D., Balasubramanian A., Bhuva B.L., Reed R.A., McMorrow D., Weller R.A., Alles M.L., Massengill L.W., Melinger J.S., Narasimham B.
Title: Single-event effects on combinational logic circuits operating at ultra-low power
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Casey, M.C., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Amusan, O.A., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Nation, S.A., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Loveless, T.D., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Balasubramanian, A., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Bhuva, B.L., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Reed, R.A., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; McMorrow, D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Weller, R.A., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Alles, M.L., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Massengill, L.W., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States; Melinger, J.S., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Narasimham, B., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37206, United States
Abstract: The minimum laser energy required to cause sustained harmonic oscillations in a 201-stage ring oscillator varies little with increasing power supply voltage when operating in the subthreshold region. These small changes in threshold laser energy in the subthreshold region suggest that the cross-section curves as a function of power supply voltage remain relatively constant. Simulations show that the minimum pulsewidth required to generate higher-order oscillations decreases as operating voltage increases. Single-event transients are wider when circuits are operating in the subthreshold region than when operating at the nominal power supply voltages. Narrower single-event transients result for strikes on PMOS transistors as compared to those for strikes on NMOS devices in the subthreshold region; the opposite is observed when circuits are operating at the nominal power supply voltages. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Nation S.A., Massengill L.W., McMorrow D., Evans L., Straatveit A.
Title: Laser dose-rate simulation to complement LINAC discrete device data
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Radiation Effects Group, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Artep, Inc., Ellicott City, MD 21042, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nation, S.A., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Radiation Effects Group, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; Massengill, L.W., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Radiation Effects Group, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235-1863, United States; McMorrow, D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Evans, L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Straatveit, A., Artep, Inc., Ellicott City, MD 21042, United States
Abstract: Laser-induced dose-rate measurements prove useful for extending the range of LINAC data for statistical analysis and for model creation and validation. Results suggest the ability to generate LINAC-equivalent data for dose-rate model development with minimal LINAC correlation. Highly reliable and repeatable data can be produced through the use of a dedicated laser test bench. © 2006 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Discrete devices; Dose-rate; Laser application
Index Keywords: Linear accelerators; Discrete devices; Dose-rate; Laser application; Laser tests; Laser-induced; Model creations; Statistical analysis; Lasers

Authors: Fleetwood D.M., Schrimpf R.D., Pantelides S.T., Pease R.L., Dunham G.W.
Title: Electron capture, hydrogen release, and enhanced gain degradation in linear bipolar devices
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fleetwood, D.M., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Pantelides, S.T., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Dunham, G.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: We present evidence that enhanced low-dose-rate sensitivity (ELDRS) in lateral and substrate pnp bipolar devices can occur because of the much lower probability for electron capture by protons in ${\hbox {SiO}}-{2}$, as compared to mobile or trapped holes. New experimental results and a critical evaluation of previous work demonstrate that, at high dose rates and/or in oxides with low concentrations of hydrogen, electrons can more easily neutralize slowly diffusing or metastably trapped holes via annihilation (recombination) or compensation (offsetting trapping) before the holes can release ${\hbox {H}}^{+}$. In contrast, at low dose rates and/or in oxides with higher concentrations of hydrogen, which can react with and modify the structure of O-vacancy-related defects, it is more likely that holes can release ${\hbox {H}}^{+}$ during transport. This is because the cross section for electron capture by ${\hbox {H}}^{+}$ is several orders of magnitude smaller than the electron capture cross section for a slowly moving or metastably trapped hole. This enhanced proton release at low dose rates or in oxides with high hydrogen concentrations can lead to increased interface trap formation, which is the most common source of enhanced gain degradation in lateral and substrate pnp bipolar transistors. © 2006 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Enhanced low-dose-rate sensitivity (ELDRS); Hydrogen; Interface trap charge; Linear bipolar devices; Oxide trap charge; Vacancies

Authors: Liu S., Titus J.L., Dicienzo C., Cao H., Zafrani M., Boden M., Berberian R.
Title: Recommended test conditions for SEB evaluation of planar power DMOSFETs
Affiliations: International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; International Recti-fier Corporation, Leominster, MA 01254, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Titus, J.L., NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Dicienzo, C., International Recti-fier Corporation, Leominster, MA 01254, United States; Cao, H., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Zafrani, M., International Recti-fier Corporation, Leominster, MA 01254, United States; Boden, M., International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Berberian, R., International Recti-fier Corporation, Leominster, MA 01254, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses issues concerning single-event burnout (SEB) and single-event gate rupture (SEGR); explains and provides a basic overview of the preferred test conditions and procedures that would yield the most meaningful test results in evaluating power MOSFETs' SEB susceptibilities, describes how to correctly identify SEB and SEGR failure modes to derive the most feasible failure mechanisms. © 2006 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Heavy ions; Power MOSFET; Single-event burnout (SEB); Single-event gate rupture (SEGR)

Authors: Batyrev I.G., Hughart D., Durand R., Bounasser M., Tuttle B.R., Fleetwood D.M., Schrimpf R.D., Rashkeev S.N., Dunham G.W., Law M., Pantelides S.T.
Title: Effects of hydrogen on the radiation response of bipolar transistors: Experiment and modeling
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Penn State Erie, Behrend College, Erie, PA 16563, United States; Idaho National Laboratory, Idaho Falls, ID 83415, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Batyrev, I.G., Department of Physics, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Hughart, D., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Durand, R., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Bounasser, M., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Tuttle, B.R., Penn State Erie, Behrend College, Erie, PA 16563, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Rashkeev, S.N., Idaho National Laboratory, Idaho Falls, ID 83415, United States; Dunham, G.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Law, M., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Pantelides, S.T., Department of Physics, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States
Abstract: Reactions of ${\rm H}-{2}$ in lateral PNP BJTs are investigated through experiments and simulations. Pre-irradiation hydrogen exposure makes the devices more sensitive to ionizing radiation, which is explained through first-principles calculations and numerical simulations. Mechanisms for the cracking of hydrogen molecules and proton generation are proposed. We also suggest a mechanism of formation of border traps. When protons are trapped by oxygen vacancies right at or very near the interface, they form electrically active defects near the middle of the band gap. Activation energies of the reaction are used to construct rate equations. The rate equations are solved numerically to determine the spatial and temporal concentrations of hydrogen, holes, and protons. The calculated concentrations of interface and border traps agree well with the experimental results and help to explain the role of hydrogen in determining the total-dose response of BJTs. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Hoover L., Griffith H., Devries K.
Title: Low noise X-band exciter using a sapphire loaded cavity oscillator
Source title: 2008 IEEE International Frequency Control Symposium, FCS
Affiliations: Polyphase Microwave Inc., Bloomington, IN, United States; Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoover, L., Polyphase Microwave Inc., Bloomington, IN, United States; Griffith, H., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN, United States; Devries, K., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: The development of a programmable, ultra-low noise X-band radar exciter using a Sapphire Loaded Cavity Oscillator (SLCO) is reported. The exciter generates +26 dBm from 9.92 GHz to 10.80 GHz with single-sideband phase noise of -154 dBc/Hz at 10 kHz offset. © 2008 IEEE.

Authors: Adell P.C., McClure S., Pease R.L., Rax B.G., Dunham G.W., Barnaby H.J., Chen X.J.
Title: Impact of hydrogen contamination on the total dose response of linear bipolar microcircuits
Source title: Proceedings of the European Conference on Radiation and its Effects on Components and Systems, RADECS
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109-8099, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-5706, United States; Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adell, P.C., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109-8099, United States; McClure, S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109-8099, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Rax, B.G., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109-8099, United States; Dunham, G.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Barnaby, H.J., Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-5706, United States; Chen, X.J., Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Abstract: Several linear bipolar microcircuits commonly used in space have been selected to investigate whether hydrogen contamination has an impact on their total dose response. Results obtained from irradiations performed on the HSYEl17 linear voltage regulator from Intersil and the AD590 temperature transducer from Analog Devices show a causal relationship between in-package hydrogen content and total dose response. Silicon nitride passivation has been found to play a key role in this study. A recommended approach to hardening bipolar linear circuits with poor total dose response is to characterize them as processed through metallization. © 2007 IEEE.

Authors: Mitsdarffer K.B., Hoover L.R.
Title: A compact instrument for RF measurements of pulsed TWTs
Source title: 8th IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2007
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Polyphase Microwave, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mitsdarffer, K.B., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Hoover, L.R., Polyphase Microwave, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States
Abstract: The development of a new and compact instrument for the measurement of pulsed high-power amplifiers in-system is reported. The instrument incorporates dual wideband receivers, dual 400 MSamples/S 12-bit digitizers, and a CompactPCI optical bridge. This paper discusses the instrument hardware implementation, integration into a target system, and representative AM/PM noise measurements of a pulsed TWT.

Authors: Chen X.J., Barnaby H.J., Vermeire B., Holbert K., Wright D., Pease R.L., Dunham G., Platteter D.G., Seiler J., McClure S., Adell P.
Title: Mechanisms of enhanced radiation-induced degradation due to excess molecular hydrogen in bipolar oxides
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, X.J., IEEE, United States, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Barnaby, H.J., IEEE, United States, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Vermeire, B., IEEE, United States, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Holbert, K., IEEE, United States, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Wright, D., IEEE, United States, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Pease, R.L., IEEE, United States, RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Dunham, G., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Platteter, D.G., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Seiler, J., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; McClure, S., IEEE, United States, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Adell, P., IEEE, United States, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Abstract: Bipolar junction test structures packaged in hermetically sealed packages with excess molecular hydrogen (H 2) showed enhanced degradation after radiation exposure. Using chemical kinetics, we propose a model that quantitatively establishes the relationship between excess H 2 and radiation-induced interface trap formation. Using environments with different molecular hydrogen concentrations, radiation experiments were performed and the experimental data showed excellent agreement with the proposed model. The results, both experimentally and theoretically, showed increased radiation induced degradation with H 2 concentration, and device degradation saturate at both high and low ends of H 2 cocentrations. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bipolar oxide; Gated bipolar devices; Hydrogen; Interface traps; Radiation-induced
Index Keywords: Bipolar oxides; Interface traps; Concentration (process); Degradation; Hydrogen; Mathematical models; Radiation effects; Reaction kinetics; Bipolar transistors

Authors: Liu S., Titus J.L., Boden M.
Title: Effect of buffer layer on single-event burnout of power DMOSFETs
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., IEEE, United States, International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Titus, J.L., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Boden, M., IEEE, United States, International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States
Abstract: It has been shown, both experimentally and theoretically, that the addition of a buffer layer between the epitaxial layer and substrate can improve a device's single event burnout (SEB) survivability. Simulation results show that the choice of buffer, resistivity and thickness, is important in achieving the best device performance (i.e., to fabricate a device capable of withstanding a heavy ion environment under its full rated drain voltage without a significant increase in its on-resistance). Simulation results show that an optimized buffer layer is critical. In other words, if the resistivity is too low or high and/or the thickness is too thick or thin, the drain voltage at which SEB occurs decreases. This paper provides a methodology to select an optimized buffer layer resistivity and thickness. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Buffer layer; Power DMOSFET; Single-event burnout (SEB); Worst-case test condition

Authors: Pease R.L., Platteter D.G., Dunham G.W., Seiler J.E., Adell P.C., Barnaby H.J., Chen J.
Title: The effects of hydrogen in hermetically sealed packages on the total dose and dose rate response of bipolar linear circuits
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., IEEE, United States, RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Platteter, D.G., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States, ; Dunham, G.W., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Seiler, J.E., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Adell, P.C., IEEE, United States, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Barnaby, H.J., IEEE, United States, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Chen, J., IEEE, United States, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Abstract: It is demonstrated with test transistors and circuits that a small amount of hydrogen trapped in hermetically sealed packages can significantly degrade the total dose and dose rate response of bipolar linear microelectronics. In addition, we show that when exposed to an atmosphere of 100% molecular hydrogen dies with silicon nitride passivation are unaffected, whereas dies with silicon carbide or deposited oxides become very soft at high and low dose rate. © 2007 IEEE.

Authors: Depuy G.W., Usher J.S., Walker R.L., Taylor G.D.
Title: Production planning for remanufactured products
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522; Grado Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061
Authors with affiliations: Depuy, G.W., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292; Usher, J.S., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292; Walker, R.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522; Taylor, G.D., Grado Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061
Abstract: This paper presents a methodology for production planning within facilities involved in the remanufacture of products. Remanufacturing refers to the process of accepting inoperable units, salvaging good and repairable components from those units, and then re-assembling good units to be re-issued into service. These types of facilities are common, yet many suffer from the unpredictability of good and repairable component yields, as well as processing time variation. These problems combine to make it extremely difficult to predict whether overall production output will be sufficient to meet demand. Low yields of key components can lead to shortages which require the facility to purchase new components for legacy systems, often with long lead times, thus causing overall delays. The approach developed here is a probabilistic form of standard material requirements planning (MRP), which considers variable yield rates of good, bad, and repairable components that are harvested from incoming units, and probabilistic processing times and yields at each stage of the remanufacturing process. The approach provides estimates of the expected number of remanufactured units to be completed in each future period. In addition, we propose a procedure for generating a component purchase schedule to avoid shortages in periods with a low probability of meeting demand. The proposed methodology is applied to an antenna remanufacturing process at the Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC). In this case study the proposed methodology identifies a potential shortage of a key component and suggests a corrective action to avoid significant delay in the delivery of remanufactured units.
Author Keywords: MRP; Production planning; Variable processing time; Variable yield rate
Index Keywords: Manufacture; Planning; Probability; Material requirements planning (MRP); Production output; Remanufactured products; Time variation; Production engineering

Authors: Levush B., Abe D.K., Calame J.P., Danly B.G., Nguyen K.T., Dutkowski E.J., Abrams Jr. R.H., Parker R.K.
Title: Vacuum electronics: Status and trends
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6840, 4555 Overlook Ave. SW, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Beam-Wave Research, Inc., Bethesda, MD 20814, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; SAIC, MoLean, VA 22101, United States
Authors with affiliations: Levush, B., Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6840, 4555 Overlook Ave. SW, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Abe, D.K., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Calame, J.P., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Danly, B.G., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Nguyen, K.T., Beam-Wave Research, Inc., Bethesda, MD 20814, United States; Dutkowski, E.J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Abrams Jr., R.H., SAIC, MoLean, VA 22101, United States; Parker, R.K., SAIC, MoLean, VA 22101, United States
Abstract: The vast preponderance of U.S. radar transmitters today use vacuum electronic amplifiers, spanning the spectrum from UHF to EHF. Enhancements to performance, reliability, and cost of ownership are being applied continuously to these systems; routine in-service life extensions mandate continuing vacuum electronics research and development to support system needs for the foreseeable future. In addition, exciting advances in vacuum electronics will provide dramatic improvements in millimeter-wave radar resolution, broadband low-noise power at microwave frequencies, compact high power sources operating at lower voltages, and life-cycle cost improvement. Recent progress in key enabling technologies, e.g., advanced device modeling and micro-fabrication, is expected to continue. This paper reviews the status and trends of vacuum electronics, with selected applications emphasizing recent advances in device performance in the microwave regime: multiple-beam klystrons (MBKs), Microwave Power Modules (MPMs), and gyro-amplifiers in the millimeter-wave regime. © 2007 IEEE.

Authors: Levush B., Abe D.K., Calame J.P., Danly B.G., Nguyen K.T., Dutkowski E.J., Abrams Jr. R.H., Parker R.K.
Title: Vacuum electronics: Status and trends
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: US Naval Research Laboratory, United States; US Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6840, 4555 Overlook Avenue, SW, Washington, DC 20375, United States; US Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Beam-Wave Research, Inc., Bethesda, MD 20814, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; SAIC, McLean, VA 22101, United States

Abstract: The vast preponderance of US radar transmitters today use vacuum electronic amplifiers, spanning the spectrum from UHF to EHF. Enhancements to performance, reliability, and cost of ownership are being applied continuously to these systems: routine in-service life extensions mandate continuing vacuum electronics research and development to support system needs for the foreseeable future. In addition, exciting advances in vacuum electronics will provide dramatic improvements in millimeter-wave radar resolution, broadband low-noise power at microwave frequencies, compact high power sources operating at lower voltages, and life-cycle cost improvement. Recent progress in key enabling technologies, e.g., advanced device modeling and micro-fabrication, is expected to continue. This reviews the status and trends of vacuum electronics, with selected applications emphasizing recent advances in device performance in the microwave regime: multiple-beam klystrons (MBKs), Microwave Power Modules (MPMs), and gyro-amplifiers in the millimeter-wave regime. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Cost of ownership; Microwave Power Modules (MPM); Multiple-beam klystrons (MBK); Vacuum electronic amplifiers; Amplifiers (electronic); Broadband networks; Microwave frequencies; Millimeter wave devices; Radar transmitters
Funding Details: Office of Naval Research, ONR

Many of the technical strategies reported in this paper were directly influenced by his vision.

Authors: Pease R.L., Dunham G.W., Seiler J.E., Platteter D.G., McClure S.S.
Title: Total dose and dose rate response of an AD590 temperature transducer
Affiliations: IEEE; RLP Research, Los Limas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Jet Propulsion Lab., Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., IEEE, RLP Research, Los Limas, NM 87031, United States; Dunham, G.W., IEEE, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Seiler, J.E., IEEE, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Platteter, D.G., IEEE, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; McClure, S.S., IEEE, Jet Propulsion Lab., Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Abstract: The total dose response of the Analog Devices AD590 is presented for a variety of irradiation test conditions. The parts packaged in flat-packs show very large enhanced low dose rate sensitive (ELDRS) response for unbiased irradiation, starting at about 20 krad, whereas parts packaged in TO-52 cans are not ELDRS. The reason for this package sensitivity appears to be a result of hydrogen trapped in the cavity of the flat-pack package. The responses at 10 mrad/s and 3 mrad/s are essentially the same, indicating that the low dose rate enhancement factor has leveled off below 10 mrad/s. Elevated temperature irradiation at 100° C and 5 rad/s does not simulate the low dose rate response. © 2007 IEEE.

Authors: Chin A., Ellison D.S., Poehlein S.K., Ahn M.K.
Title: Investigation of the decomposition mechanism and thermal stability of nitrocellulose/nitroglycerine based propellants by electron spin resonance
Affiliations: Test and Evaluation Department, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Department of Chemistry, Indiana State University, Terre Haute, IN 47809, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chin, A., Test and Evaluation Department, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Ellison, D.S., Test and Evaluation Department, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Poehlein, S.K., Test and Evaluation Department, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Ahn, M.K., Department of Chemistry, Indiana State University, Terre Haute, IN 47809, United States
Abstract: Nitrocellulose based (NC) and nitroglycerin based (NG) propellants often have a fixed acid and water content during the manufacturing time. After manufacture, the quantity and ratio of acid/water will continue to vary depending upon the conditions of storage and operation. The level of variation depends on many factors such as loading density, temperature, volume of ullage and sealing condition of the containing cartridge, just to name a few. As described in this paper and other literature, the degradation mechanisms and aging processes of NC/NG based propellants are extremely complicated. This paper describes the details of the application of Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) to study if the free-radical mechanism is involved in the decomposition of nitrocellulose and nitroglycerin. Due to the high free-radical intensity possessed by the propellant composition, we believe that a π complex intermediate may be formed between DPA and NG and/or NC. The formation of a .complex intermediate is not preferred because it may enhance the rate of decomposition of nitrate esters. Correlation between heat flow curve, stabilizer depletion and free-radical distribution has been evaluated. An intramolecular decomposition mechanism is preferred, because it prevents the possibility that the NOx from NNODPA or NNDPA may interact with the NC and NG again during the rearrangement process. Since the acidity of the propellant composition continues to change during the aging process, multiple mechanisms may proceed simultaneously. © 2007 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA.

Abstract: Carrier generation based on nonlinear absorption in semiconductors has become an important tool for the investigation of single-event effects in modern microelectronic devices. TPA-induced single-event upset mapping and backside, through-wafer charge injection are described. © 2007 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Garich H., Sun J., Gebhart L., Inman M., Taylor E.J., Dalrymple T., Emami N., Smith R., Berg T., Thompson R., Richards W.
Title: The effect of plating cell configuration on the quality of copper deposit for printed circuit boards
Source title: IPC - Printed Circuits Expo, Apex, and the Designers Summit 2006: Perfectly Cutting Edge
Affiliations: Faraday Technology, Inc., Clayton, OH, United States; AFRL, SNDR, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center - Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garich, H., Faraday Technology, Inc., Clayton, OH, United States; Sun, J., Faraday Technology, Inc., Clayton, OH, United States; Gebhart, L., Faraday Technology, Inc., Clayton, OH, United States; Inman, M., Faraday Technology, Inc., Clayton, OH, United States; Taylor, E.J., Faraday Technology, Inc., Clayton, OH, United States; Dalrymple, T., AFRL, SNDR, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH, United States; Emami, N., AFRL, SNDR, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH, United States; Smith, R., Naval Surface Warfare Center - Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Berg, T., Naval Surface Warfare Center - Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Thompson, R., Naval Surface Warfare Center - Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Richards, W., Naval Surface Warfare Center - Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses the effect of pulse plating of electronic interconnects for advanced electronic modules. This paper builds on earlier work by correlating plating cell and tank design issues and tank characterization studies with standard mechanical and reliability tests. The current work evaluates the resulting copper deposits in terms of throwing power, mechanical and reliability tests and compares the results to a current state-of-the-art process. The present work relies on electrical mediation for a highly controlled electrodeposition process that results in a very uniform and reproducible deposit; selection of the electric mediation parameters is based on considerations of mass transfer as well as microprofiles and macroprofiles related to current distribution. Data for plating industry test panels containing PTHs of approximately 5:1, 10:1, and 15:1 aspect ratios are presented. Using a pulse waveform sequence, throwing powers of approximately 90-100% are observed at plating rates of approximately 20 ASF.

Authors: DePuy G.W., Usher J.S., Arterburn B., Walker R., Fredrick M.
Title: Workforce training schedule for logistics skills
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States; Microwave Technologies Division, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: DePuy, G.W., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States; Usher, J.S., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States; Arterburn, B., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292, United States; Walker, R., Microwave Technologies Division, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Fredrick, M., Microwave Technologies Division, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Workforce competency assessment and the resulting assignment of workers to tasks is a necessary management function in most organizations. This work for the US military, develops mathematical models to match employees to tasks based on the logistics skills of the employee and the skills necessary for the task. In cases where further training of employees is required to complete a task, another mathematical model is developed to determine which employees should be trained in which logistics skills to minimize the overall training cost. Several commercially available skills management software tools exist. While these software tools often have the capability to match employees to jobs based on skills/requirements profiles, they do not create an optimal training schedule to best address the identified skills gaps. Results and analysis are based on a profile of approximately 60 employees, 70 tasks, and 50 different skills with 5 competency levels of each skill.
Author Keywords: Assignment problem; Integer programming

Authors: Liu S., Boden M., Girdhar D.A., Titus J.L.
Title: Single-event burnout and avalanche characteristics of power DMOSFETs
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., IEEE, United States, International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Boden, M., IEEE, United States, International Rectifier Corporation, El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Girdhar, D.A., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Titus, J.L., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Analyses of quasi-stationary avalanche simulations on radiation-hardened power MOSFETs suggest that the single-event burnout (SEB) failure is determined by the device's avalanche characteristics and confirm SEB failure mechanism is due to the turn-on of parasitic bipolar transistor. The heavy ion beam is only acting as a trigger. Simulation results on various 600 V and 250 V radiation-hardened power MOSFETs from International Rectifier are compared to an extensive set of single event effect test results and prove quasi-stationary avalanche simulation is capable of evaluating and predicting SEB susceptibility. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Ramachandran V., Narasimham B., Fleetwood D.M., Schrimpf R.D., Holman W.T., Witulski A.F., Pease R.L., Dunham G.W., Seiler J.E., Platteter D.G.
Title: Modeling total-dose effects for a low-dropout voltage regulator
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Institute for Space and Defense Electronics (ISDE), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramachandran, V., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Narasimham, B., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Holman, W.T., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Witulski, A.F., IEEE, United States, Institute for Space and Defense Electronics (ISDE), Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Pease, R.L., IEEE, United States, RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Dunham, G.W., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Seiler, J.E., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Platteter, D.G., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Total ionizing dose effects in a low-dropout voltage regulator are explained based on experimental data and circuit simulations. Transistor gain degradation is shown to be the dominant cause of the circuit degradation at lower dose rates. In addition, collector-to-emitter leakage current in one of the NPN transistors of the bandgap reference part of the circuit is responsible for increasing the postirradiation output voltage at high dose rates. Parametric changes in the bandgap, differential amplifier, and output pass transistor circuit blocks are identified that are responsible for various aspects of the observed circuit degradation. The different annealing characteristics of oxide-trap and interface-trap charge are responsible for the complex postirradiation recovery of the output voltage. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Benedetto J.M., Eaton P.H., Mavis D.G., Gadlage M., Turflinger T.
Title: Digital single event transient trends with technology node scaling
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Micro-RDC, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benedetto, J.M., IEEE, United States, Micro-RDC, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Eaton, P.H., Micro-RDC, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Mavis, D.G., Micro-RDC, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Gadlage, M., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Turflinger, T., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: We have measured the single-event-transient (SET) width as a function of cross-section over three CMOS bulk/epitaxial technology nodes (0.25, 0.18 and 0.13 μm) using an identically scaled programmable-delay temporal-latch technique. Both the maximum width of the SET pulse and the cross-section are shown to depend primarily on the supply voltage, with a substantial increase in transient width and cross-section with lower operating potentials. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Gadlage M.J., Eaton P.H., Benedetto J.M., Carts M., Zhu V., Turflinger T.L.
Title: Digital device error rate trends in advanced CMOS technologies
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Microelectronics Research and Development Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; ATK Mission Research, Colorado Springs, CO 80919, United States; Muniz Engineering (NASA GSFC), Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States; Texas Instruments Incorporated, Dallas, TX 75266, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Eaton, P.H., Microelectronics Research and Development Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Benedetto, J.M., ATK Mission Research, Colorado Springs, CO 80919, United States; Carts, M., Muniz Engineering (NASA GSFC), Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States; Zhu, V., Texas Instruments Incorporated, Dallas, TX 75266, United States; Turflinger, T.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: In this paper, data are presented from test chips in four technology nodes. With this data, the trends in single event effects as feature sizes shrink are studied. Some of the trends discussed include upset thresholds, shrinking cross sections, multiple bit upsets, and per bit error rate trends. Also included in this paper is some of the first ever heavy ion data from a 65 nm CMOS technology. With data from the 250 nm, 180 nm, 90 nm, and 65 nm technology nodes, the past, present, and future of what the radiation effects community has dealt with and will be dealing with when it comes to single event effects is presented. © 2006 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Heavy ion; Ion radiation effects; Single-event upset (SEU)

Authors: Venter A., Ifa D.R., Cooks R.G., Poehlein S.K., Chin A., Ellison D.
Title: A desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry study of aging products of diphenylamine stabilizer in double-base propellants
Affiliations: Chemistry Department, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Venter, A., Chemistry Department, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, United States; Ifa, D.R., Chemistry Department, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, United States; Cooks, R.G., Chemistry Department, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, United States; Poehlein, S.K., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Chin, A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Ellison, D., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Double-base propellants consisting of nitrocellulose, nitroglycerin and stabilizer undergo chemical and physical changes upon aging, leading to changes in ballistic power and presenting explosive hazards. During aging, PTFE seals of the glass ampoules used in the aging studies undergo a yellow discoloration. This report studies the discoloration of the liners using desorption electrospray ionization (DESI). a gentle surface analysis technique based on electrospray ionization. The color bodies in the PTFE liners were identified by DESI together with tandem mass spectrometry to be the nitrated derivatives of the diphenylamine stabilizer: dinitro-, trinitro-. and tetranitrodiphenylamine. While increased nitration decreases vapor pressure of the DPA species, an increase in solubility in the PTFE liners occurs. This may account for these species not previously being observed during early aging studies as they are preferentially absorbed into the liners, which were not extracted prior to high performance liquid-chromatography analysis. © 2006 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA.
