Authors: Dressman L.J., McDermott D.B., Luhmann Jr. N.C.
Title: Design and test of a 34 GHz peniotron
Affiliations: University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dressman, L.J., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; McDermott, D.B., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Luhmann Jr., N.C., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: A peniotron, designed for optimized device efficiency and power output at 34 GHz, has been constructed at UC Davis. The device exploits the interaction of the second harmonic of an axis-encircling electron beam with the fundamental mode of a four-vane (magnetron like) slotted circuit. Output power and device efficiency have been predicted as 125 kW (peak) and 47% respectively. © 2005 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Construction of a Ka-Band cusp gun second-harmonic Gyro-TWT amplifier
Affiliations: University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harriet, S.B., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; McDermott, D.B., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Luhmann Jr., N.C., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: A novel Ka-Band TE21 second-harmonic gyro-TWT amplifier with a large-orbit axis-encircling beam from a Northrop Grumman Cusp gun is being fabricated and tested at UCD. Authors: Newman B.C., Waggoner S.M., Hamilton R.J.
Title: E-6 and E-3 main battery and charger upgrade
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division; L-3/Titan Corporation
Authors with affiliations: Newman, B.C., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division; Waggoner, S.M., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division; Hamilton, R.J., L-3/Titan Corporation
Abstract: Background Both the E-3 Centurion AWACS and E-6 Mercury TACAMO Aircraft have identical airborne battery and charger systems. High maintenance costs due to high failure rates of the battery components prompted NAVAIR to begin a program to replace the commercial battery with a high-reliability military specification battery. The new design, specified as the M81757/18-1, uses modern materials and low-maintenance vented nickel-cadmium (Ni-Cd) technology. The prototype batteries were developed by MarathonNorco Aerospace Inc. Realizing that the charge algorithm of the present airborne charger was a very mild charge for a 20-cell nickel-cadmium (Ni-Cd) battery, prototypes of the new batteries were tested to verify whether the airborne chargers could keep them adequately charged. The present airborne charger could not keep the new batteries charged. The initial plan to insert the new technology battery into the existing airborne system would not work without changing the present airborne charger. Although the charge algorithm was a very gentle charge, there were reports about the present batteries overheating on the aircraft. The empirical evidence appeared to strongly contradict all operating descriptions of the airborne charger. To understand the reason for the apparent contradiction between the system operating description and actual occurrences, we began to study the airborne charge system. The more we learned, the more we realized that the whole system should be replaced. Copyright © 2006 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Binary alloys; Cadmium alloys; Failure analysis; Nickel cadmium batteries; Airborne systems; Charge algorithms; Charger systems; High reliability; Low maintenance; Maintenance cost; Military specification; New technologies; Charging (batteries)

Conference name: Power Systems Conference

Authors: Pease R.L., Dunham G.W., Seiler J.E.
Title: Total dose and dose rate response of low dropout voltage regulators
Affiliations: IEEE; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., IEEE, RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Dunham, G.W., IEEE, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Seiler, J.E., IEEE, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The total dose response of three bipolar low dropout voltage regulators is presented for a variety of irradiation and anneal test conditions. Two of the part types were chosen for their known enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS) and the third for its known radiation tolerance. The two ELDRS parts show a dramatic sensitivity to irradiation bias with the all leads shorted being worst case at low dose rate. The responses at 10 mrad/s and 2.3 mrad/s are similar in magnitude, indicating that the low dose rate enhancement factor has leveled off below 10 mrad/s. Elevated temperature irradiation at 100°C and 5 rad/s does not simulate the low dose rate response. © 2006 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Dose rate; Radiation effects; Total ionizing dose; Voltage regulators
Index Keywords: Irradiation; Radiation effects; Thermal effects; Voltage regulators; Dose rate; Total ionizing dose; Dosimetry

Authors: Liu S., Boden M., Cao H., Sanchez E., Titus J.L.
Title: Evaluation of worst-case test conditions for SEE on power DMOSFETs
Affiliations: IEEE; International Rectifier Corp., El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; International Rectifier Corp., Leominster, MA 01435, United States; NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., IEEE, International Rectifier Corp., El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Boden, M., IEEE, International Rectifier Corp., El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Cao, H., IEEE, International Rectifier Corp., El Segundo, CA 90245, United States; Sanchez, E., International Rectifier Corp., Leominster, MA 01435, United States; Titus, J.L., IEEE, NAVSEA Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Extensive single event effects tests were performed on a new generation, the R6 process, of radiation-hardened 600-volt and 250-volt power metal-oxide semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) from International Rectifier using two different ions (Krypton and Xenon) at many different beam energies, Bragg Peak positions, and drain and gate biases. Results show that there is no worst-case test condition for single event burnout but positioning of the energy deposition is critical for single event gate rupture. ©2006 IEEE.

Authors: Fassino J., Maegerlein N., Southern D.
Title: Metallurgical testing of gun barrels
Source title: Essential Technologies for Successful Prognostics - Proceedings of the 59th Meeting of the Society for Machinery Failure Prevention Technology
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division (NSWC Crane), Explosive Sciences Branch, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fassino, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division (NSWC Crane), Explosive Sciences Branch, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Maegerlein, N., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division (NSWC Crane), Explosive Sciences Branch, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Southern, D., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division (NSWC Crane), Explosive Sciences Branch, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The demands on today's military for lighter, cheaper, longer lasting products only increase the risk for catastrophic failure of items already facing adverse service conditions. After a medium caliber barrel failure, the Explosive Sciences Branch (ESB) of Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC Crane) performed metallurgical investigations on one damaged gun barrel, six additional barrels pulled from service and one new gun barrel. to determine if any inherent flaws or service conditions could have caused the failure. The metallurgical analysis included detailed microhardness profiling on several areas of each barrel, complete microstructure examination with a metallurgical microscope, crack depth determination via optical comparator, optical microscopy and SEM analyses on down-bore sections of the barrels, and geometrical analysis on the rifling of the barrels. Hardness differences were found between the outside edge and/or inside edge of the barrels versus the center or core of the barrels. Additionally, areas of no chrome coating, cracked coating, base metal cracking, and stress corrosion cracking were evident in the breech end of the barrel, while land damage/deformation was prominent in down-bore barrel sections. The ESa determined coating cracking and slight interface corrosion between the base metal and coating would lead to accelerated degradation (erosion, corrosion, cracking, etc.) of barrels in service. These findings show that many barrels still in use should be pulled from service and that better erosion/corrosion monitoring techniques need to be in place to better assess the condition and risk of barrels in service.
Author Keywords: Barrel; Corrosion; Erosion; Failure; Gun; Metallurgy
Index Keywords: Accelerated degradation; Barrel; Base metals; Catastrophic failures; Crack depths; Geometrical analysis; Gun; Gun barrels; Metallurgical analysis; Metallurgical investigation; Metallurgical microscope; Metallurgical testing; Microstructure examination; Monitoring techniques; Naval Surface Warfare Center; Optical comparators; SEM analysis; Service conditions; Chromate coatings; Computer system recovery; Corrosion; Cranes; Erosion; Machinery; Optical microscopy; Stress corrosion cracking; Systems engineering; Technology; Metallurgy

Authors: Fassino J., Maegerlein N.
Title: Predictive analysis of corrosion
Source title: Essential Technologies for Successful Prognostics - Proceedings of the 59th Meeting of the Society for Machinery Failure Prevention Technology
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Explosive Sciences Branch, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fassino, J., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Explosive Sciences Branch, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Maegerlein, N., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Explosive Sciences Branch, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: One of the biggest problems faced by the U.S. Navy is corrosion. From the harsh environments experienced shipboard to erosion corrosion of gun barrels, there are continuing efforts to extend the life of products, reduce costs, and maintain superior quality. One way to achieve all these goals is to accurately predict corrosive environments and corrosion rates, and effectively minimize such atmospheres. The corrosive environments can be improved in several ways, innovative protective coatings, new materials, better monitoring, and new technologies to better predict corrosion and how it affects a given material. Predicting corrosion allows for service lives to be extended and maintenance costs to be reduced by knowing ahead of time what to expect and at what rate changes will occur. Peltier sensors and heat flow microcalorimetry (HFMC) allow for a determination if an environment is corrosive, the corrosion rate, and the predicted life of the test coupon. HFMC allows for service life predictions Abstract: opposed to the current salt flog testing which gives little meaningful data other than an item's condition after 48 hour exposure. The following study details how HFMC was able to determine the corrosive effects of several propellant formulations on gun barrel steel to aid in a product improvement plan. The HFMC analysis was coupled with standard chemical and metallurgical tests to validate the data.
Author Keywords: Barrel; Corrosion; Microcalorimetry; Predictive analysis; Propellant

Title: Construction of an experimental large-orbit second-harmonic gyro-TWT amplifier
Source title: The Joint 30th International Conference on Infrared and Millimeter Waves and 13th International Conference on Terahertz Electronics, 2005. IRMMW-THz 2005
Affiliations: University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harriet, S.B., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, United States, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, (NSWC Crane), Crane, IN, United States; McDermott, D.B., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, United States; Luhmann Jr., N.C., University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, United States
Abstract: A novel Ka-Band TE21 second-harmonic gyro-TWT amplifier with a large-orbit axis-encircling beam from a Northrop Grumman Cusp gun is being fabricated and tested at UCD. The device is predicted to produce 50 kW with 20% efficiency, 30 dB saturated gain and 3% bandwidth. © 2005 IEEE.

Authors: Dressman L.J., McDermott D.B., Luhmann Jr. N.C.
Title: Design and test of a 34 GHz harmonic peniotron
Source title: The Joint 30th International Conference on Infrared and Millimeter Waves and 13th International Conference on Terahertz Electronics, 2005. IRMMW-THz 2005
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Code 80943, 300 Hwy. 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dressman, L.J., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, United States, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Code 80943, 300 Hwy. 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; McDermott, D.B., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, United States; Luhmann Jr., N.C., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, United States
Abstract: A 34 GHz peniotron, designed for high device efficiency and power output has been constructed at UC Davis. The device is designed for second-harmonic interaction with the axis-encircling beam produced by a Northrop Grumman cusp gun and is predicted to produce 125 kW peak output power. Magnetics have been recently re-designed, built and tested. Recent efforts have concentrated on final assembly of the device and improvement of the modulator. © 2005 IEEE.

Authors: Chen X.J., Barnaby H.J., Pease R.L., Schrimpf R.D., Platteter D., Shaneyfelt M., Vermeire B.
Title: Estimation and verification of radiation induced not and Nit energy distribution using combined bipolar and MOS characterization methods in gated bipolar devices
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-5706, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Wintech Programs, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-8406, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, X.J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-5706, United States; Barnaby, H.J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-5706, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; Platteter, D., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Shaneyfelt, M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Vermeire, B., Wintech Programs, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287-8406, United States
Abstract: Complementary bipolar and MOS characterization techniques, specifically the gate sweep (GS) and sub-threshold sweep (SS), are used to estimate the radiation induced oxide charge (Not) and interface trap (N it) buildup in gated bipolar test devices. The gate sweep and sub-threshold sweep data from recent TID testing of gated lateral PNP devices suggests an asymmetric energy distribution of interface traps after ionizing radiation exposure. Charge pumping (CP) experiments were done on the test devices to estimate the energy distribution of interface traps induced by radiation. The CP results are used in this paper to confirm the analytical findings from the GS and SS techniques and solidify the use of the complementary method as a simple way of determining radiation induced interface trap distribution in gated bipolar devices. © 2005 IEEE.

Authors: Gadlage M.J., Eaton P.H., Benedetto J.M., Turflinger T.L.
Title: Comparison of heavy ion and proton induced combinatorial and sequential logic error rates in a deep submicron process
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Microelectronics Research and Development Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO 80919, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Eaton, P.H., Microelectronics Research and Development Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Benedetto, J.M., Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO 80919, United States; Turflinger, T.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Digital single event transients induced in combinatorial logic are quickly becoming a significant error source as circuit feature sizes shrink and digital circuits operate faster. In this paper, we are able to compare the combinatorial logic error rate to the sequential logic error rate in both heavy ion and proton environments in a simple digital circuit created in a 0.18 μm CMOS technology. We are able to do this by comparing data from two unique test chips. © 2005 IEEE.

Authors: Benedetto J.M., Eaton P.H., Mavis D.G., Gadlage M., Turflinger T.
Title: Variation of digital SET pulse widths and the implications for single event hardening of advanced CMOS processes
Affiliations: ATK Mission Research, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Microelectronics Research and Development Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benedetto, J.M., ATK Mission Research, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Eaton, P.H., Microelectronics Research and Development Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Mavis, D.G., Microelectronics Research and Development Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Gadlage, M., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Turflinger, T., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: Single event transient (SET) pulse widths produced from heavy ion irradiation in digital ICs are measured using a variable-delay temporal-latch test structure. We show for the first time that there is a wide distribution of SET pulse widths created by heavy ion radiation in digital CMOS logic at given linear energy transfer (LET) levels. We were able to measure SET pulse widths from as short as 344 ps to greater than 1.5 ns in 0.18 μm CMOS technology at LETs greater than 80 MeV-cm2/mg. Depending on LET, the cross section of the very long SET pulses were as much as four orders of magnitude smaller than for the shorter pulse widths. This has substantial implications for hardening techniques; specifically, we now know that we can dramatically improve the SET hardness without suffering the speed penalties required to remove the longest transients. © 2005 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Error rate; Heavy ion; Radiation effects; Single event effects; Single event transient; Single event upset; Transient propagation; Transient pulse width
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Energy transfer; Heavy ions; Integrated circuit testing; Irradiation; Radiation effects; Error rate; Single event transient (set); Single event upset; Transient propagation; Transient pulse width; Laser pulses

Authors: Wallis E., Griffin T.M., Popkie Jr. N., Eagan M.A., McAtee R.F., Vrazel D., McKinly J.
Title: Instrument response measurements of ion mobility spectrometers in situ: Maintaining optimal system performance of fielded systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: EG and G Technical Services, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; General Dynamics ATP, 4205 Westinghouse Commons Drive, Charlotte, NC 28277, United States; Night Vision/Electro Optics and Chemical Biological/Explosives Detection Group, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Kin-Tek Laboratories, Inc., 504 Laurel St., La Marque, TX 77568, United States; Code 805D, Bldg. 3324, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wallis, E., EG and G Technical Services, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States, Code 805D, Bldg. 3324, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Griffin, T.M., General Dynamics ATP, 4205 Westinghouse Commons Drive, Charlotte, NC 28277, United States; Popkie Jr., N., Night Vision/Electro Optics and Chemical Biological/Explosives Detection Group, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Eagan, M.A., Night Vision/Electro Optics and Chemical Biological/Explosives Detection Group, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; McAtee, R.F., Night Vision/Electro Optics and Chemical Biological/Explosives Detection Group, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Vrazel, D., Kin-Tek Laboratories, Inc., 504 Laurel St., La Marque, TX 77568, United States; McKinly, J., Kin-Tek Laboratories, Inc., 504 Laurel St., La Marque, TX 77568, United States
Abstract: Ion Mobility Spectroscopy (IMS) is the most widespread detection technique in use by the military for the detection of chemical warfare agents, explosives, and other threat agents. Moreover, its role in homeland security and force protection has expanded due, in part, to its good sensitivity, low power, lightweight, and reasonable cost. With the increased use of IMS systems as continuous monitors, it becomes necessary to develop tools and methodologies to ensure optimal performance over a wide range of conditions and extended periods of time. Namely, instrument calibration is needed to ensure proper sensitivity and to correct for matrix or environmental effects. We have developed methodologies to deal with the semi-quantitative nature of IMS and allow us to generate response curves that allow a gauge of instrument performance and maintenance requirements. This instrumentation communicates to the IMS systems via a software interface that was developed in-house. The software measures system response, logs information to a database, and generates the response curves. This paper will discuss the instrumentation, software, data collected, and initial results from fielded systems.
Author Keywords: Chemical Warfare Agent Detection; Ion Mobility Spectroscopy

Authors: Armstrong C.
Title: Modular Mission Payload Architecture
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Bldg 2035, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, C., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Bldg 2035, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The current problem of integrating new payloads into current Unmanned Vehicle Systems is becoming more prevalent as the vehicles become more capable. The increase in payload capacity allows for new types of payloads to be carried and facilitates the option of carrying multiple payloads per mission. This added capability creates integration difficulties. Modifying the vehicle and ground station software with each new payload is unacceptable. Software integration, regression and safety concerns make the integration effort costly and lengthy. The Modular Mission Payload Architecture addressed these issues with a web-centric network-based solution that migrates the command and control interface of modular mission payloads from inside the ground control station and vehicle management systems to a separate controller in the vehicle. This migration and a common interface minimize modifications to system hardware and software to incorporate new payloads, thus reducing engineering development time, facilitating quicker integration at lower costs and allowing payload commonality across services and platforms.
Author Keywords: Integration; Modular Mission Payload; Open Systems; Payloads; Unmanned Vehicles

Authors: Boris J., Fulton J., Obenschain K., Patnaik G., Young Jr. T.
Title: CT-Analyst: Fast and accurate CBR emergency assessment
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Lab. Compl. Phys. and Fluid Dynam., U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6400, Washington, DC 20375-5320, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boris, J., Lab. Compl. Phys. and Fluid Dynam., U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6400, Washington, DC 20375-5320, United States; Fulton, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Obenschain, K., Lab. Compl. Phys. and Fluid Dynam., U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6400, Washington, DC 20375-5320, United States; Patnaik, G., Lab. Compl. Phys. and Fluid Dynam., U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6400, Washington, DC 20375-5320, United States; Young Jr., T., Lab. Compl. Phys. and Fluid Dynam., U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Code 6400, Washington, DC 20375-5320, United States
Abstract: An urban-oriented emergency assessment system for airborne Chemical, Biological, and Radiological (CBR) threats, called CT-Analyst™ and based on new principles, gives greater accuracy and much greater speed than possible with current alternatives. This paper explains how this has been done. The increased accuracy derives from detailed, three-dimensional CED computations including, solar heating, buoyancy, complete building geometry specification, trees, wind fluctuations, and particle and droplet distributions (as appropriate). This paper shows how a very finite number of such computations for a given area can be extended to all wind directions and speeds, and all likely sources and source locations using a new data structure called Dispersion Nomographs™. Finally, we demonstrate a portable, entirely graphical software tool called CT-Analyst that embodies this entirely new, high-resolution technology and runs effectively on small personal computers. Real-time users don't have to wait for results because accurate answers are available with near zero-latency (that is 10 - 20 scenarios per second). Entire sequences of cases (e.g. a continuously changing source location or wind direction) can be computed and displayed as continuous-action movies. Since the underlying database has been precomputed, the door is wide open for important new real-time, zero-latency functions such as sensor data fusion, backtracking to an unknown source location, and even evacuation route planning. Extensions of the technology to sensor location optimization, buildings, tunnels, and integration with other advanced technologies, e.g. micrometeorology or detailed wind field measurements, will be discussed briefly here.

Authors: Dressman L.J., Warnick R.L., Qualls A.
Title: Cathode life test facility-historical review
Source title: IVESC2004 - 5th International Vacuum Electron Sources Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Code 80943, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dressman, L.J.; Warnick, R.L., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Code 80943, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Qualls, A., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN, United States
Abstract: The Cathode Life Test Facility(CLTE) has performed real-time life testing of various themionic cathode types V since 1980. The facility originated at Rome Laboratories, Griffiss AFB. In 1992 it was moved to it present location at NSWC Crane, Crane Indiana. Since its inception, the facility has accumulated approximated 4 million total life test hours on cathodes of at least eighteen different types. Historically, the most popular cathodes under test have include reservoir cathodes, designated MK(Siemens),RV and V(CPI), and Impregnated cathodes, Designated M(Semicon and Hughes),TM(CPI) and MMM(CPI). In addition, smaller numbers of more exotic cathode types have also been tested. Most cathode are life tested at loadings of 1,2,and 4 A/cm 2 in continuous emission mode. However, a number of cathode(e.g. cathode with 10 A/cm 2)have been tested with applied filament power only, Due to limitation on the test stations available. A summary of the cathodes testd over the entire life of facility will be given and the result obtained will compared. Test vehicle configuration and methods of data collection and analysis will be reviewed Emphasis will be placed on comparing different cathodes by type and Loading/The usefulness of data will be discussed. © 2004 IEEE.

Abstract: A second-harmonic TE 21 gyro-TWT is being fabricated at UCD that is predicted to produce 50 kW in Ka-band with 20% efficiency, 30 dB saturated gain and 3% bandwidth. Title: Efficient 34 GHz second-harmonic peniotron with cusp gun drive

Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; Northrop Grumman Corporation, Rolling Meadows, IL, United States; Air Force Research Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM, United States

Abstract: A 34 GHz peniotron, operating in the fundamental-mode of a slotted circuit, is under construction at UC Davis. The device is designed for second-harmonic interaction with the axis-encircling beam produced by a Northrop Grumman cusp gun. Recent efforts have concentrated on improving the magnetic field design and beam quality. Consequently, the cryogenic magnet of the initial design has been replaced with conventional coils and pole pieces. Measurement of the new magnet indicates that design goals for the magnetic field have been achieved and simulation of the beam predicts greatly improved quality. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Harriet S.B., McDermott D.B., Gallagher D.A., Luhmann Jr. N.C.
Title: TE 21 second-harmonic gyro-TWT amplifier with an axis-encircling beam
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; Northrop Grumman Corporation, Rolling Meadows, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harriet, S.B., Department of Applied Science, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; McDermott, D.B., Department of Applied Science, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Gallagher, D.A., Northrop Grumman Corporation, Rolling Meadows, IL, United States; Luhmann Jr., N.C., Department of Applied Science, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: A second-harmonic TE 21 gyro-TWT is being constructed at UCD that is predicted to produce 50 kW in Ka-band with 20% efficiency, 30 dB saturated gain and 3% bandwidth. The device utilizes a novel Northrop Grumman cusp gun that provides a high quality axis-encircling electron beam. The axis-encircling beam from the cusp gun provides a significantly more efficient gyrotron interaction for harmonic operation than a non-axis-encircling beam from a magnetron injection gun (MIG) because the electrons are not constrained to a fixed azimuth so they rotate through both the peaks and nulls of the linearly polarized mode. An important advantage of harmonic gyro-TWTs is that they are capable of higher power than at the fundamental cyclotron harmonic because they are more stable to the absolute instability at cutoff of the operating mode. Due to weaker strength of the harmonic interactions, the start-oscillation current is significantly higher for higher harmonic operation. This allows higher harmonic gyro-TWTs to operate stably with appreciably higher beam current. The magnetic circuit is designed to provide both the magnetic field reversal required in the cusp gun region to produce the axis-encircling beam and at the same time a constant axial magnetic field of 5.48 kG in the interaction circuit region over the 42 cm length of the circuit. Recently the magnetic circuit was reoptimized to provide a better field profile match to the field profile required by the cusp gun in the field reversal region. In addition the axial magnetic field is designed to ensure that each section of the device is free from oscillation. The magnetic circuit consists of water cooled copper magnet coils and iron pole pieces. Approved for public release; distribution is unlimited.

Authors: Dressman L.J., McDermott D.B., Hirata Y., Gallagher D.A., Spencer T.A., Luhmann Jr. N.C.
Title: 34 GHz cusp gun driven peniotron
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, NSWC Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Northrop Grumman Corp., Rolling Meadows, IL, United States; Air Force Research Lab., Directed Energy Directorate, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dressman, L.J., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, NSWC Crane, Crane, IN, United States; McDermott, D.B., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Hirata, Y., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Gallagher, D.A., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States, Northrop Grumman Corp., Rolling Meadows, IL, United States; Spencer, T.A., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States, Air Force Research Lab., Directed Energy Directorate, NM, United States; Luhmann Jr., N.C., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: A peniotron designed for optimum device efficiency is currently being assembled at UC Davis. The peniotron incorporates a four-vane slotted (magnetron-like) cavity operating in the fundamental waveguide mode, the π/2 mode. Interaction is at approximately 34 GHz with the second-harmonic beam mode. This interaction provides good separation from possible competing gyrotron modes. The cavity incorporates an output coupling iris which is required to achieve the desired loaded Q of 375 necessary for overcoupling of the device and optimum power output The predicted output power is approximately 125 kW (at 47% device efficiency as predicted with our large-signal code). Cold test of the cavity/iris combination shows good agreement with predictions from simulation with HFSS. The interaction is powered by a Northrop-Grumman cusp gun which provides the high quality axis-encircling electron beam required for efficient interaction. For the device to operate as predicted, the gun will supply 3.5 amps at 70 kV. The spent beam should be suitable for recovery with a single-stage depressed collector, raising the total device efficiency to 57%. Recently, the magnetics have been completely re-designed to improve beam quality and ensure proper and safe operation of the gun. The magnetics have been assembled and are currently undergoing test. The circuit and associated components have been fabricated and tested. Upon completion of the collector, the device will be assembled for test and preliminary results reported. Distribution Statement A: Approved for public release; distribution is unlimited.

Authors: McMorrow D., Buchner S., Lotshaw W.T., Melinger J.S., Maher M., Savage M.W.
Title: Demonstration of single-event effects induced by through-wafer two-photon absorption
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; QSS Group, Inc., Seabrook, MD 20706, United States; 7605 Grenada Drive, Bethesda, MD 20817, United States; National Semiconductor Corp., South Portland, ME 04106, United States; Navsea Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: McMorrow, D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Buchner, S., QSS Group, Inc., Seabrook, MD 20706, United States; Lotshaw, W.T., 7605 Grenada Drive, Bethesda, MD 20817, United States; Melinger, J.S., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Maher, M., National Semiconductor Corp., South Portland, ME 04106, United States; Savage, M.W., Navsea Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The first demonstration of through-wafer two-photon absorption (TPA) single-event effects (SEEs) testing is presented. We interrogate the single-event transient (SET) response of several different nodes of the LM124 operational amplifier via TPA carrier injection through both the front and back (substrate) chip surfaces. The results reveal that the SETs and sensitivities produced in several different nodes by front-side and back-side irradiation are effectively identical, confirming the validity of this approach for SEE studies.

Authors: Pease R.L., Platteter D.G., Dunham G.W., Seiler J.E., Barnaby H.J., Schrimpf R.D., Shaneyfelt M.R., Maher M.C., Nowlin R.N.
Title: Characterization of enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS) effects using gated lateral PNP transistor structures
Affiliations: RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87154, United States; National Semiconductor, South Portland, ME 04106, United States; ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Platteter, D.G., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Dunham, G.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Seiler, J.E., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Barnaby, H.J., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Shaneyfelt, M.R., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87154, United States; Maher, M.C., National Semiconductor, South Portland, ME 04106, United States; Nowlin, R.N., ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States
Abstract: The high and low dose rate responses of bipolar transistors in a bipolar linear circuit process technology have been studied with specially designed gated lateral pnp test transistors that allow for the extraction of the oxide trapped charge (Not) and interface trap (Nit) densities. The buildup of Not and Nit with total dose is investigated as a function of the irradiation gate voltage at 39 rad/s and 20 mrad/s for three variations of the final passivation layer (all variations had the same oxide covering the active region of the devices). The three variations in final passivation were selected to exhibit minimal degradation at high and low dose rate (no passivation), significant degradation at high and low dose rate (p-glass/nitride) and enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS) (p-glass only). It is shown that the increase in base current is dominated by increased N it and the "true" low dose rate enhancement in the ELDRS parts occurs for zero and negative gate voltage, but is eliminated for large positive gate voltage and elevated temperature irradiation. Implications for ELDRS models are discussed.
Author Keywords: Enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS); P-glass/nitride

Authors: Chen X.J., Barnaby H.J., Pease R.L., Schrimpf R.D., Platteter D.G., Dunham G.
Title: Radiation-induced base current broadening mechanisms in gated bipolar devices
Affiliations: University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, X.J., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Barnaby, H.J., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; Platteter, D.G., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Dunham, G., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Ionizing radiation experiments on gated lateral bipolar junction transistors (BJTs) show a broadening in the peak base current profile after irradiation. The primary mechanism for this effect is identified as the change in the charge state of interface traps in the oxide over the base. Simulations and theoretical analysis not only describe the mechanism in detail, but also suggest possible solutions for extracting information from the shape of the profile. The effects of the interface-trap energy distribution are investigated, showing that traps between flatband and threshold contribute to the width of the base-current peak.
Author Keywords: Bipolar; Energy distribution; Gated devices; Interface traps; Ionization; Radiation

Authors: Gadlage M.J., Schrimpf R.D., Benedetto J.M., Eaton P.H., Mavis D.G., Sibley M., Avery K., Turflinger T.L.
Title: Single event transient pulsewidths in digital microcircuits
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37332, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO 80919, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37332, United States; Benedetto, J.M., Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO 80919, United States; Eaton, P.H., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Mavis, D.G., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Sibley, M., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Avery, K., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Turflinger, T.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The radiation effects community has long known that single event transients in digital microcircuits will have an increasing importance on error rates as device sizes shrink. However separating these errors from static errors in latch cells has often proved difficult. Thus determining both the significance and the nature of these transient errors has not been easy. In this study, by utilizing a latch that is radiation hard at static clock frequencies the errors due to transients could be separated. By separating the transient error rate from the static upset error rate, the pulse structure of the propagating transients was studied using SPICE. The implications of these pulsewidths will also be discussed.
Author Keywords: Digital single event transients (DSETs); Heavy ions; Single event effects (SEEs); SPICE

Authors: Benedetto J., Eaton P., Avery K., Mavis D., Gadlage M., Turflinger T., Dodd P.E., Vizkelethyd G.
Title: Heavy ion-induced digital single-event transients in deep submicron processes
Affiliations: Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO 80919-3158, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Code 6054, Bldg. 3334, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benedetto, J., Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO 80919-3158, United States; Eaton, P., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Avery, K., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Mavis, D., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Gadlage, M., NAVSEA Crane, Code 6054, Bldg. 3334, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Turflinger, T., NAVSEA Crane, Code 6054, Bldg. 3334, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Dodd, P.E., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Vizkelethyd, G., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States
Abstract: Single-event transients (SETs) in digital circuits/processes are examined. SETs appear to substantially mitigate traditional SEU static-latch hardening techniques below 0.25μn. The resulting IC error rate for advanced technology node hardened-electronics is dominated by the combinational-logic SET rate.

Authors: Seiler J.E., Pease R.L., Platteter D.G., Maher M.C., Dunham G.W., Shaneyfelt M.R.
Title: Effect of passivation on the enhanced low dose rate sensitivity of national LM124 operational amplifiers
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; National Semiconductor Corporation, South Portland, ME 04106, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seiler, J.E., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Platteter, D.G., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Maher, M.C., National Semiconductor Corporation, South Portland, ME 04106, United States; Dunham, G.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Shaneyfelt, M.R., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States
Abstract: This paper presents high and low dose rate test results for LM124 operational amplifiers that were fabricated with six passivation layer types. Consistent with previous data, these results confirm that passivation layers play a significant role in determining ELDRS response. SIMS analysis suggests that an influential factor in determining the high and low dose rate response may be the location and concentration of hydrogen at the Si-SiO2 interface and in the passivation layers.

Authors: Eaton P., Benedetto J., Mavis D., Avery K., Sibley M., Gadlage M., Turflinger T.
Title: Single event transient pulsewidth measurements using a variable temporal latch technique
Affiliations: ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eaton, P., ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Benedetto, J., ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Mavis, D., ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Avery, K., ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Sibley, M., ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110, United States; Gadlage, M., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Turflinger, T., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: A new test structure was designed for measuring the pulsewidths of transients created by sets. Experimental data was gathered using heavy ions from lets of 11.5 to 84 mev -cm2/mg. The pulsewidths of sets generated using heavy ions are measured using a variable temporal latch. Our set's widths at low lets agree exceptionally well with previous localized beam measurements.
Index Keywords: Error analysis; Heavy ions; Particle accelerators; Probability; Problem solving; Synchronization; Localized beams; Pulsewidth measurements; Single event transient (SET); Variable temporal latch; Signal processing
Funding Details: Defense Threat Reduction Agency, DTRA
Funding Text 1: Manuscript received July 19, 2004. This work was supported by the DTRA DSET program. P. Eaton, J. Benedetto, D. Mavis, K. Avery, and M. Sibley are with the ATK Mission Research, Albuquerque, NM 87110 USA (e-mail: Peaton@mrcmicroe. com). M. Gadlage and T. Turflinger are with the NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522 USA. Digital Object Identifier 10.1109/TNS.2004.840020 Fig. 1. Schematic representation of variable temporal latch device. The top part of the figure shows a wide pulse passing through unfiltered and causing a bit flip, while the bottom half of the schematic shows a short transient being filtered. By varying this pass/block point of the temporal latch, we can determine the actual SET pulsewidth.

Authors: Savage M.W., Titus J.L., Turflinger T.L., Pease R.L., Poivey C.
Title: A comprehensive analog single-event transient analysis methodology
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NASA, GSFC, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States
Authors with affiliations: Savage, M.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Titus, J.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Turflinger, T.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Poivey, C., NASA, GSFC, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States
Abstract: A new method for analyzing analog single-event transient (ASET) data has been developed. The approach allows for quantitative error calculations, given device failure thresholds. The method is described and employed in the analysis of an OP-27 op-amp.
Author Keywords: Analog; Heavy ions; OP-27; Operational-amplifier; Single-event transient (SET)
Index Keywords: Data acquisition; Error analysis; Heavy ions; Microelectronic processing; Parameter estimation; Voltage measurement; Analog; OP-27; Operational-amplifier; Single-event transient (SET); Operational amplifiers
Funding Details: Defense Threat Reduction Agency, DTRA

Authors: Minson E., Sanchez I., Barnaby H.J., Pease R.L., Platteter D.G., Dunnam G.
Title: Assessment of gated sweep technique for total dose and dose rate analysis in bipolar oxides
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; NAVSEA CRANE, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Minson, E., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States; Sanchez, I., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States; Barnaby, H.J., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States; Platteter, D.G., NAVSEA CRANE, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Dunnam, G., NAVSEA CRANE, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The efficacy of a gate sweep characterization technique for extracting radiation defect densities in bipolar devices as a function of total dose, dose rate, irradiation bias and device geometry has been studied. The parts analyzed were all NP type gated diodes formed with the n-type emitter and p-type base of a standard linear bipolar process. Diodes, having either 7 or 14 μm gate widths, were exposed to ionizing radiation at dose rates of 17 and 0.017 rad(Si)/s with either 0 or 10 V gate biases. Characteristics at several doses were measured using a step stress approach. The majority of the experimental results are shown to be consistent with the space charge model for enhanced- low-dose-rate sensitivity (ELDRS) in bipolar technologies. The results also show, as expected, that gate width has no influence on fixed oxide trapped charge buildup. However, the results suggest the need to refine the standard technique for extracting interface trap densities; where the area of the gate electrode is a critical parameter.
Author Keywords: Bipolar transistor; Diodes; Dose rate; ELDRS; Gate sweep; Ionizing radiation; Radiation effects
Index Keywords: Bipolar technologies; Enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS); Gate sweep; Gated diodes; Bipolar transistors; Carrier concentration; Defects; Diodes; Electron traps; Ionizing radiation; Irradiation; Oxides; Radiation effects; Dosimetry

Abstract: This paper will review the performances of nickel/cadmium and nickel/hydrogen Geocentric Earth Orbital (GEO) satellite battery packs which have been evaluated at NAVSEA Crane for the Air Force and NASA-Glenn. The nickel/cadmium data will deal, in part, with the attempts to find space-qualified substitutes for the disappearance of Pellon 2505 as a separation material. The nickel/hydrogen data will illustrate the development of this chemistry as a substitute for nickel/cadmium batteries. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Cusp gun Ka-band second-harmonic TE 21 gyro-TWT amplifier
Source title: 5Th IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2004
Affiliations: University of California Davis, Department of Applied Science, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States

Abstract: A second harmonic TE 21 gyro-TWT amplifier was developed at University of California Davis (UCD) to produce 50 kW in Ka-band with 20% efficiency. The device employs a sliced mode-selective circuit to suppress odd-order azimuthal modes by interrupting the wall currents. The gyro-TWT amplifier dispersion diagram showed a number of possible competing modes. An axial magnetic field was designed to ensure that each section of the device is free from oscillations.

Source title: 5Th IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2004
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; Northrop Grumman Corporation, Rolling Meadows, IL, United States; Air Force Research Laboratory, Albuquerque, NM, United States

Abstract: The design of UCD peniotron for optimum device efficiency and output power in second-harmonic operation at a 34 GHz fundamental-mode resonance was discussed. The UCD device incorporates over-coupling of the cavity to achieve the desired increased device efficiency. The intercation cavity was EDM fabricated from copper and cold testing has been performed using a 50 GHz HP 8510 network analyzer. The improvements in design were expected to provide higher beam quality and the predicted peak power output and efficiency is 130 kW at 58% (electronic) and 47% (device).

Title: Modeling and verification of single event transients in deep submicron technologies
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Vanderbilt University, Crane, IN, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane, Vanderbilt University, Crane, IN, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States; Benedetto, J.M., Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Eaton, P.H., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Turflinger, T.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: The importance of knowing the pulse structure of the transient while dealing with submicron technologies was discussed. To characterize the single event transient (SET) error rate, the test chip were designed with four parallel shift register chains. The transient errors were found to be caused by ion strikes in the combinatorial logic and propagation of the pulse into a register on a clock edge. It was observed that there was an increase in errors as the clock frequency increased, which was attributed due to transients induced in the inverter chain.

Authors: Gilmour Jr. A.S., Thelen D., MacMullen A., Kodis M.A., Reynolds R., Emerson R.
Title: Ion instabilities initiated in the gun of a linear beam microwave tube
Affiliations: Technology Service Corporation, IEEE, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States; University of Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14226, United States; Technology Service Corporation, IEEE, Los Angeles, CA 90025, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gilmour Jr., A.S., Technology Service Corporation, IEEE, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States, University of Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14226, United States; Thelen, D., Technology Service Corporation, IEEE, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States; MacMullen, A., Technology Service Corporation, IEEE, Los Angeles, CA 90025, United States; Kodis, M.A., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Reynolds, R., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Emerson, R., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: A theory is presented which offers an explanation for many of the causes of ion-induced instabilities of the phase and amplitude of the RF output of a solenoid-focused 10-kW continuous-wave coupled cavity traveling-wave tube (TWT). This theory is based on the effects of ions in the electron gun. Some of these ions enter the gun from the interaction region of the TWT. Ions generated in the gun can also have a significant effect on the instabilities. The characteristics (in particular, the timing and shapes) of the waveforms of the instabilities are discussed in detail. The sawtooth waveform often observed is explained by the rates of ion generation in the beam and then the rapid discharge of ions into the gun. When gas pressure in the gun is elevated because of relatively high pressure in the TWT, cathode evaporation, or sputtering, the waveforms can take on a complex double exponential shape that sometimes has a double period. Some of the reasons for these effects are given. The effects that are observed of solenoid current, cathode voltage, RF drive level, and collector voltage on the instabilities are explained by the effects of these parameters on an ion barrier at the collector end of the TWT. When these quantities are such that the barrier is small, the drainage of beam ions to the collector is increased and to the gun is decreased. With reduced ion flow to the gun, gas generation in the gun is reduced, and so the causes of the instabilities are suppressed. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric potential; Electron beams; Electron guns; Ion beams; Solenoids; Spurious signal noise; Sputtering; AM noise; Collector voltage; Continuous wave coupled cavity; FM noise; Ion induced instabilities; Linear beam microwave tube; Phase noise; Traveling wave tubes

Authors: Thelen D., Reynolds R., Emerson R., Pearson M., Gilmour Jr. A.S., MacMullen A.
Title: Characterization of relaxation-oscillation noise in continuous-wave traveling wave tubes
Affiliations: Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; University of Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14226, United States; Technology Service Corporation, IEEE, Los Angeles, CA 90025, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thelen, D., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States; Reynolds, R., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Emerson, R., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Pearson, M., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Gilmour Jr., A.S., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States, University of Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14226, United States; MacMullen, A., Technology Service Corporation, IEEE, Los Angeles, CA 90025, United States
Abstract: Extremely low noise levels are frequently required in radar and communication systems that utilize microwave tubes. A noise waveform frequently found in continuous-wave (CW) linear-beam microwave tubes is a relaxation-type oscillation that has a period typically on the order of several milliseconds. This paper provides an extensive experimental characterization of this relaxation-oscillation phenomenon by recording the corresponding signal modulations on the output of several solenoid-focused CW traveling wave tubes. The characteristics of these amplitude and phase modulations were studied during systematic variations of tube operating parameters that included magnetic field, cathode voltage, depressed collector voltage, heater filament voltage, and input drive level. A measurement technique was also developed with the capability to obtain detailed information on the growth of the relaxation-oscillation noise waveforms along the beam interaction region by comparing reflected and output noise waveforms. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Gadlage M.J., Schrimpf R.D., Benedetto J.M., Eaton P.H., Turflinger T.L.
Title: Modeling and verification of single event transients in deep submicron technologies
Source title: IEEE International Reliability Physics Symposium Proceedings
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane and Vanderbilt University, Crane, IN, United States; Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gadlage, M.J., NAVSEA Crane and Vanderbilt University, Crane, IN, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States; Benedetto, J.M., Mission Research Corporation, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Eaton, P.H., Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Turflinger, T.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: Digital single event transients (DSETs) are becoming an increasing concern for deep submicron ICs. As device feature sizes shrink, digital circuits become faster, have smaller parasitics, and become more susceptible to single event effects (SEEs). If an ionizing particle creates enough charge to be collected on a node within a combinatorial gate, a transient pulse will be formed that may propagate through the circuit and be latched in as bad data. In order to predict the response of a circuit to a single event, people have long used circuit and device level simulations. In this paper, we show that when dealing with deep submicron technologies, knowing the pulse structure of the transient is crucial to predicting its propagation distance accurately. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Shortridge R.G., Wilharm C.K.
Title: Improved infrared countermeasures with ultrafine aluminum
Source title: Collection of Technical Papers - AIAA/ASME/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics and Materials Conference
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Pyrotechnics Development Division, Environ. and Chem. Sciences Branch, Code 4073, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Pyrotechnics Development Division, Countermeasures Development Branch, Code 4071, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shortridge, R.G., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States, Pyrotechnics Development Division, Environ. and Chem. Sciences Branch, Code 4073, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Wilharm, C.K., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States, Pyrotechnics Development Division, Countermeasures Development Branch, Code 4071, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States
Abstract: In this paper we describe our efforts to increase aircraft survivability by improvements in decoy flare countermeasures. These improvements are necessary due to an increasingly sophisticated and widely proliferated arsenal of infrared-guided Man Portable Air Defense Systems (MANPADS) and other surface-to-air and air-to-air missile threats. Some of these threats now have the potential to fall into the hands of various terrorist groups, posing a serious threat to both military and civilian aircraft. Highly energetic fuel additives, such as ultrafine aluminum (UFAL), have been incorporated into both conventional magnesium-Teflon-Viton (MTV) and spectrally balanced decoy flare compositions. The latter type of composition enables the flare to have a closer infrared spectral match to the target aircraft than does the conventional MTV composition. Nanoscale materials have increased in popularity in recent years. Their chief advantage in the present flare compositions is the increase in burn rate and infrared emission intensity caused by their greatly increased surface area, as compared with conventional micron-scale fuel ingredients. The efforts reported here were performed at laboratory scale and led to the characterization of a number of promising conventional and spectrally balanced UFAL-containing compositions. The dangerously high electrostatic sensitivity of UFAL and the compositions made from it complicated their scale-up to prototype size flare candles (150-200 gram form factors). However, pre-coating the UFAL ingredient with Viton binder has shown promise for mitigating these electrostatic sensitivity safety concerns.

Authors: Wilharm C.K.
Title: Combustion Model for Pyrophoric Metal Foils
Affiliations: Ordnance Engineering Directorate, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilharm, C.K., Ordnance Engineering Directorate, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: A model for the combustion of pyrophoric metal foils has been developed. The diffusive mass transport, heat transport, and chemical reactions of porous iron foils have been described. The temperature and radiated energy of these materials has been predicted as a function of the physical characteristics of the material (porosity, pore size, specific surface area) for different atmospheric conditions (temperatures and oxygen concentrations varied with altitude and wind velocity).

Authors: Cressler J.D., Krithivasan R., Sutton A.K., Seiler J.E., Krieg J.F., Clark S.D., Joseph A.J.
Title: The Impact of Gamma Irradiation on SiGe HBTs Operating at Cryogenic Temperatures
Affiliations: Sch. of Elec./Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0250, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; IBM Microelectronics, Essex Junction, VT 05401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cressler, J.D., Sch. of Elec./Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0250, United States; Krithivasan, R., Sch. of Elec./Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0250, United States; Sutton, A.K., Sch. of Elec./Computer Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0250, United States; Seiler, J.E., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Krieg, J.F., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Clark, S.D., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Joseph, A.J., IBM Microelectronics, Essex Junction, VT 05401, United States
Abstract: We show that silicon-germanium (SiGe) heterojunction bipolar transistors (HBTs) are naturally suited for space applications requiring operation of electronics at cryogenic temperatures, and present the first comprehensive investigation of the effects of gamma irradiation on the characteristics of SiGe HBTs operating at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K). We find that exposure to 1 Mrad total dose at 77 K produces significantly less base current degradation than exposure at 300 K, and hence the total dose tolerance of SiGe HBTs, which is already excellent at room temperature without intentional hardening, improves with cooling. We compare 77 and 300 K radiation results in order to better understand the damage mechanisms.
Author Keywords: Cryogenic temperatures; Gamma irradiation; Radiation; SiGe; SiGe heterohunction bipolar transistor (HBT)

Authors: Titus J.L., Su Y.-S., Savage M.W., Mickevicius R.V., Wheatley C.F.
Title: Simulation Study of Single-Event Gate Rupture Using Radiation-Hardened Stripe Cell Power MOSFET Structures
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Integrated Systems Engineering, Inc., San Jose, CA 95113, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Su, Y.-S., Integrated Systems Engineering, Inc., San Jose, CA 95113, United States; Savage, M.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Mickevicius, R.V., Integrated Systems Engineering, Inc., San Jose, CA 95113, United States; Wheatley, C.F.
Abstract: A two-dimension simulation study of single-event gate rupture (SEGR) in radiation-hardened stripe cell power MOSFETs is reported. Simulations are performed on stripe-cell structures employing three different neck widths. A simple methodology is presented showing how these simulations can be used to approximate the drain and gate biases required to induce SEGR. These biases are then compared with the experimental data and found to be in good agreement. By means of simulations, we investigated the effects of various physical mechanisms and input parameters, which are likely to be important in SEGR and found that impact ionization plays a crucial role in the process. The simulations show that the N+ source and P+ plug are critical to the hardened design (narrower neck widths). Clearly, simulations could become a useful tool in evaluating certain design and processing variations.

Title: Eldrs in Space: An Updated and Expanded Analysis of the Bipolar ELDRS Experiment on MPTB
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; NRL, Brookneal, VA 24528, United States; RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turflinger, T.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Campbell, A.B., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Schmeichel, W.M., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wallers, R.J., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Krieg, J.F., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Titus, J.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Reeves, M., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Marshall, P.W., NRL, Brookneal, VA 24528, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Los Lunas, NM 87031, United States
Abstract: The MPTB experiment established enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS) in space for bipolar linear circuits. Data are updated through orbit 3719, dosimetry corrected, and displacement damage and the rate of degradation as a function of dose rate are examined with new analyses.

Authors: Titus J.L., Wheatley C.F.
Title: SEE Characterization of Vertical DMOSFETs: An Updated Test Protocol
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wheatley, C.F.
Abstract: The test protocols for power MOSFETs used in the manufacturer's specification sheets are inadequate in that they do not represent a realistic worst-case condition. In addition, the applicable single-event effects (SEE) test methods and guidelines do not provide sufficient details to the user as to what conditions should be used, placing an undue burden on them. This paper addresses several of these deficiencies and others. We present a new test protocol; we suggest a new approach to describe the SEE response; and we provide a model to predict critical ion energies that should produce a worst-case response.

Authors: Mitsdarffer K.B., Hoover L.R., Thelen D.
Title: In-System Phase Measurement of Pulsed Microwave Amplifiers
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane, Code 80941, Bldg 3168 Attn K.B. Mitsdarffer, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mitsdarffer, K.B., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane, Code 80941, Bldg 3168 Attn K.B. Mitsdarffer, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Hoover, L.R., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN, United States; Thelen, D., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses measurement techniques that can estimate the phase of pulsed microwave amplifiers. In addition to the traditional techniques that use a phase bridge or vector network analyzer, a dual channel downconverter (DCD) technique was developed. The use of this patent-pending DCD unit offers ease of installation, complex stimulus modulation compatibility, low-cost, supportability, stability, and accuracy.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Frequencies; Pulse modulation; System stability; Transmitters; Dual channel downconverter (DCD); Microwave amplifiers

Authors: Harriet S.B., McDermott D.B., Luhmann N.C., Jr.
Title: Investigation of a smooth bore harmonic cusp gun gyro-TWT
Source title: 4th IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2003 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, University of Califomia Davis, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA  95616, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harriet, S.B., Department of Applied Science, University of Califomia Davis, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA  95616, United States, Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; McDermott, D.B., Department of Applied Science, University of Califomia Davis, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA  95616, United States; Luhmann, N.C., Jr., Department of Applied Science, University of Califomia Davis, 3001 EU3, Davis, CA  95616, United States
Abstract: For the stability of any amplifier, it is desirable to suppress as many unnecessary circuit modes as possible. Figure 1 shows the dispersion diagram for the Ka-band Cusp gun second-harmonicm TE (2)21 gyro-TWT amplifier [I] currently being developed at UC Davis. The dispersion diagram show tlie gazing intersection of the second-harmonic cyclotron resonance and the TE21 mode of the circular waveguide circuit which represents the mode of operation. The diagram also shows other potential oscillating modes. The modeselective circuit shown in Fig. 2 is employed in the device to destroy the odd-order Tem1 modes. The circuit is sliced with two orthogonal slices through the axis to interrupt the admuthal wall currents. Surrounding the interaction circuit is a lossy cylinder to absorb the Wated power. The remaining even-order modes are suppressed by adding msmbuted loss to the circuit. It would be desirable for ease of fabrication, cost and reliability to replace the sliced circuit with and smooth bore circular waveguide circuit. A smooth bore waveguide design is investigated and simulated performance characteristics are compared to the sliced circuit Ka-band Cusp gun second:harmonic TE(2)21 gyro-TWT amplifier design. In the proposed design the odd-order modes are suppressed by adding additional distributed loss to the circuit instead of by slicing. © 2003 IEEE.

Authors: Lewis H.L., Baer J.M., Manzo M.A.
Title: A comparative Examination of performance for air Force/Nasa Nckel hydrogen packs in LEO cycling
Source title: 1st International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference IECEC
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Crane IN 47522, United States; Aerospace Corporation, Los Angeles CA 900009, United States; Nasa Glenn, Cleveland OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, H.L., NAVSEA Crane, Crane IN 47522, United States; Baer, J.M., Aerospace Corporation, Los Angeles CA 900009, United States; Manzo, M.A., Nasa Glenn, Cleveland OH 44135, United States
Abstract: Since 1987, a total of twenty-nine nickel hydrogen packs of several ampere-hour ratings from four manufacturers have been in LEO cycling at NAVSEA Crane. The manufacturers are Eagle-Picher, Gates, Hughes, and Yardney. The packs are in IPV, CPV, and SPV configurations. The largest number of packs has come from Eagle-Picher, eleven in number. Currently, fourteen packs remain on test. We take this opportunity to attempt to draw some general conclusions regarding pack performance as a function of several variables in LEO cycling, storage prior to cycling, and pack construction.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Manufacture; Naval vessels; Air force; Several variables; Hydrogen
Publisher: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc.

Abstract: We present data on the vulnerability of a variety of candidate spacecraft electronics to proton and heavy ion induced single event effects. Devices tested include digital, analog, linear bipolar, and hybrid devices, among others. © 2003 IEEE.

Authors: Alsman D., Paul C., Sartor M.
Title: Machine vision image analysis capability for image intensifier tubes and systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Code 805, Bldg 3291, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Xybion Corporation, 240 Cedar Knolls Road, Cedar Knolls, NJ 07927, United States; Sarnoff Corporation, 201 Washington Road, Princeton, NJ 08543, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alsman, D., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Code 805, Bldg 3291, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Paul, C., Xybion Corporation, 240 Cedar Knolls Road, Cedar Knolls, NJ 07927, United States; Sartor, M., Sarnoff Corporation, 201 Washington Road, Princeton, NJ 08543, United States
Abstract: The Automated Intensifier Measurement System (AIMS) was shown to be both effective in the automated measurement of image intensifier tube (IIT) modulation transfer function (MTF) and visual quality. The algorithms were tested and shown to be correctly measuring tube quality metrics with an accuracy and repeatability heretofore unavailable. Through its automation and traceability, AIMS have the potential to significantly improve the overall quality measurement system for tube acceptance, including improving the false rejection rate of good tubes, and false acceptance rate of bad tubes.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Cameras; Charge coupled devices; Computer vision; Image analysis; Image quality; Optical instrument lenses; Optical transfer function; Photocathodes; Automated intensifier measurement system; Bright spots; Dark spots; Gross distortion; Image intensifier tubes; Shear distortion; Image intensifiers (electron tube)
