Authors: Pease R.L., Maher M.C., Shaneyfelt M.R., Savage M.W., Baker P., Krieg J., Turflinger T.L.
Title: Total-dose hardening of a bipolar-voltage comparator
Affiliations: RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; National Semiconductor, South Portland, ME 04106, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87101, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Maher, M.C., National Semiconductor, South Portland, ME 04106, United States; Shaneyfelt, M.R., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87101, United States; Savage, M.W., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Baker, P., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Krieg, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Turflinger, T.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The total-dose hardening of a bipolar-voltage comparator was presented. A radiation-tolerant bipolar-voltage comparator experienced severe degradation of radiation hardness when layout of the part was redrawn and the process moved from a 4-in wafer to a 6-in wafer line. The reasons for the loss in the hardness were also identified.
Author Keywords: Bipolar analog circuits; Comparator; Ionization; Linear circuits; Radiation effects; Radiation hardening

Authors: Sternberg A.L., Massengill L.W., Buchner S., Pease R.L., Boulghassoul Y., Savage M.W., McMorrow D., Weller R.A.
Title: The role of parasitic elements in the single-event transient response of linear circuits
Affiliations: Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; QSS, Lanham, MD 20771, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States

Sci., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Buchner, S., QSS, Lanham, MD 20771, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Boulghassoul, Y., Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Savage, M.W., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; McMorrow, D., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Weller, R.A., Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States
Abstract: The role of parasitic elements in the single-event transient response of linear circuits was discussed. Three case studies in which ASET-sensitive parasitic elements were identified using a pulsed laser and then implemented in SPICE were also presented. The importance of parasitics in the simulation response of linear circuits was shown.

Authors: Chen T., Luo Z., Cressler J.D., Isaacs-Smith T.F., Williams J.R., Chung G., Clark S.D.
Title: The effects of NO passivation on the radiation response of SiO2/4H-SiC MOS capacitors
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Department of Physics, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Sterling Semiconductor, Tampa, FL 33619, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Department of Materials Science and Engineering, 420 Broun Hall, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, T., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Luo, Z., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Cressler, J.D., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, 420 Broun Hall, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Isaacs-Smith, T.F., Department of Physics, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Williams, J.R., Department of Physics, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Chung, G., Sterling Semiconductor, Tampa, FL 33619, United States; Clark, S.D., NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The radiation response of SiO2 gate oxides grown on 4H-SiC to NO passivation is presented for the first time. The effects of gamma radiation on Qeff are similar for n-4H-SiC MOS capacitors both with and without NO passivation, but are different in sign (negative) compared to SiO2 on Si. The variation in Dit with total dose, however, is different for the passivated versus the unpassivated samples. Comparisons between Si SOI and 4H-SiC suggest that properly passivated SiC MOSFETs should have good radiation tolerance. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Harriet S.B., McDermott D.B., Gallagher D.A., Luhmann Jr. N.C.
Title: Cusp gun TE21 second-harmonic Ka-band gyro-TWT amplifier
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Northrop Grumman Corporation, Rolling Meadows, IL 60008, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harriet, S.B., Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States, Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; McDermott, D.B., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Gallagher, D.A., Northrop Grumman Corporation, Rolling Meadows, IL 60008, United States; Luhmann Jr., N.C., Department of Applied Science, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: A second-harmonic TE21 gyrotron traveling-wave tube (gyro-TWT) amplifier with an axis-encircling electron beam is being constructed at the University of California-Davis that is predicted to double the efficiency of our previous 200-kW 12%-efficient magnetron injection gun (MIG) TE21(2) gyro-TWT. Both devices employ a sliced mode-selective circuit to suppress the odd-order azimuthal modes. The new device will avoid the loss in efficiency that is due to off-axis electrons interacting with the resulting linearly polarized mode. The amplifier is predicted by our large signal code to produce 50 kW in Ka-band with 20% efficiency, 30 dB saturated gain, and 3% bandwidth. The 70-kV 3.5-A axis-encircling electron beam with v⊥/vz = 1.2 and Δvz/vz = 7% will be produced by a Cusp electron gun delivered by Northrop Grumman. The amplifier has been designed using linear theory to provide a 30% safety margin from absolute instability. Distributed loss is added to the first 30.5 cm of the circuit to ensure the device is stable to harmonic gyro-BWO. The last 11.5 cm of the circuit is standard copper to avoid attenuating the wave at high power levels.
Author Keywords: Axis-encircling electron beam; Cusp gun; Gyro-traveling-wave tube (gyro-TWT); Gyro-TWT amplifier; Millimeter-wave amplifier; Mode-selective circuit; Second-harmonic

Title: Comparative analysis of low dose-rate, accelerated, and standard cobalt-60 radiation response data for a low-dropout voltage regulator and a voltage reference
Affiliations: Harris Corporation, Melbourne, FL  32950, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM  87122, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN  47522, United States; RTI, Research Triangle Park, NC  27709, United States

Abstract: This paper presents the results of cobalt-60 response measurements made on a low dropout voltage regulator and a shunt reference for three different radiation test conditions: low dose rate, accelerated (elevated temperature irradiation) and standard (50-300 rad(SiO2)/s). The accelerated test is shown to correlate well with the low dose rate failure of the reference but not for the failure of the regulator. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Freeland J.
Title: Variance reduction in aged sample data by the use of lot acceptance test data [missile primary cell testing]
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane Division, Code 6093, Building 3235, Crane, IN  47522-5001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Freeland, J., NAVSEA Crane Division, Code 6093, Building 3235, Crane, IN  47522-5001, United States
Abstract: NAVSEA Crane Division performs ongoing quality evaluation test (QET) programs to evaluate the steady deterioration with age of critical performance parameters (such as risetime and runtime) of Navy Fleet-aged missile primary batteries. The goal is to estimate service life (SL), the age at which these batteries must be replaced. QET data is obtained by sampling a few dozen units of various ages throughout the range of date of manufacturing (DOM) of the inventory. It is expensive to obtain; few data points are available. Typically, a QET is performed every 3-5 years on 22 samples. Abundant lot acceptance test (LAT) data usually is available; it is used to perform lot sentencing (accept or reject) before shipping. Here, the authors show new mathematical methods which improve the accuracy of service life estimation, and which also may be a significant advance in the general mathematical theory of regression analysis. The enhanced delta method also eliminates the well-known problem that arises when QET and LAT raw data sets are combined in one analysis. © 2002 IEEE.

Abstract: We present data on the vulnerability of a variety of candidate spacecraft electronics to proton and heavy ion induced single event effects, proton-induced damage, and total ionizing dose. Devices tested include optoelectronics, digital, analog, linear bipolar, hybrid devices, analog-to-digital converters (ADCs), digital-to-analog converters (DACs), and DC-DC converters, among others. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Fulton J., Griffin M.T., Gao R., Tsoukalas L.
Title: Increasing specificity in a low resolution ion mobility spectrometer
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE-The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Night Vision/Electro Optics and Chemical/Biological Detection Group, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361 Code 805D Bldg. 3324, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Applied Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Purdue University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fulton, J., Night Vision/Electro Optics and Chemical/Biological Detection Group, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361 Code 805D Bldg. 3324, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Griffin, M.T., Night Vision/Electro Optics and Chemical/Biological Detection Group, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, 300 Highway 361 Code 805D Bldg. 3324, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States; Gao, R., Applied Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Purdue University, United States; Tsoukalas, L., Applied Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Purdue University, United States
Abstract: Novel methodology has been developed that simultaneously improves sensitivity and specificity of a low-resolution ion mobility spectroscopy (IMS) sensor. Wavelet transforms have been applied to IMS spectra in order to de-noise and enhance spectral features. Next, trigger metrics of the spectra were derived using a statistical evaluator (SE) and optimized using a genetic algorithm (GA). The combination of wavelets, SE, and GA has been demonstrated to differentiate between background, analyte, interferent, and a binary mixture of analyte and interferent. This results in an overall increase in resolving power. The new system is less sensitive to false positives due to increased selectivity, shows the ability to yield quantitative data at ultra-low concentrations for low level toxicity, has the ability to detect binary mixtures of compounds, and shows great potential in significantly improving chemical warfare detection capabilities under field conditions. © 2002 SPIE · 0277-786X/02/$15.00.

Authors: Klausmeier R.E., Appleton J.A., Dupre E.S., Tenbarge K.
Title: The enzymology of trinitrotoluene reduction
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klausmeier, R.E., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, United States, ; Appleton, J.A., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, United States, ; Dupre, E.S., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, United States, ; Tenbarge, K., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, United States,
Abstract: Bacillus subtilis, whose growth is inhibited by 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), possesses the ability to metabolically reduce TNT to a variety of amino- and hydroxylaminotoluene derivatives. Cell-free extracts of this culture are capable of reducing TNT, utilizing either nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD) or nicrotinamide-adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP) as co-factors. The NAD-linked system has a narrower pH range and is more sensitive to heat than the NADP-mediated system. Both react with essentially the same nitroaromatic substrates, elute from Sephadex columns at the same time, and show the same solubilities in ammonium sulphate solutions. The cell-free extract from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, whose growth is not inhibited by TNT, also has NAD- and NADP-linked TNT reductases with almost identical characteristics as those from B. subtilis.

Authors: Garner D., Tierney W., Voltmer D.
Title: Visual Electromagnetics (VEM): A student learning tool
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane, United States; Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; Navy's Land Attack Destroyer Program, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Solid State Microwave Devices Group, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garner, D., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane, United States, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States, Navy's Land Attack Destroyer Program, United States; Tierney, W., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Solid State Microwave Devices Group, United States; Voltmer, D., Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: Visual ElectroMagnetics (VEM) is a 2-D static electromagnetic simulator designed as a visualization aid for students in undergraduate electromagnetic courses. VEM utilizes finite difference techniques in conductive, dielectric, and magnetic environments. The VEM code, written in MATLAB for Windows 95/98, provides an inexpensive, user-friendly graphical interface that is platform independent. VEM consists of a structure window in which the user enters electromagnetic materials and sources via common drawing tools and pop-up menus. The solver button generates the system matrix, solves it, and activates the solutions window in which the results are displayed in a variety of user-selected viewing modes. Though the solution region is finite in extent, a compact simulation of the open boundaries of infinite extent is achieved via the Transparent Grid Termination (TGT). Preliminary evaluations of the enhancement of student learning by VEM are promising. A full demonstration of VEM will be included in the presentation.

Authors: Sheridan D.C., Chung G., Clark S., Cressler J.D.
Title: The effects of high-dose gamma irradiation on high-voltage 4H-SiC Schottky diodes and the SiC-SiO2 interface
Affiliations: Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Physics Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sheridan, D.C., Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Chung, G., Physics Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Clark, S., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Cressler, J.D., Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States
Abstract: The effects of radiation on high-voltage 4H-SiC Schottky diodes for use in extreme environment power supplies are investigated for the first time. Diodes were fabricated with a wide range of barrier heights (1.06-1.60 eV) and were evaluated after being exposed to a 60Co gamma radiation source. DC current-voltage characteristics were measured after several radiation doses, with no observable degradation in the diode forward or reverse characteristics up to a total dose of 4 Mrad(Si). Measured breakdown voltages of postirradiated diodes increase approximately 200 V compared to the virgin devices and are attributed to increased negative interface charge, as determined by MOS capacitor measurements and correlated with numerical breakdown simulations.
Author Keywords: Diodes; Gamma radiation; Schottky barrier; Silicon carbide (SiC)
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Computer simulation; Current voltage characteristics; Electric breakdown; Gamma rays; MOS capacitors; Power supply circuits; Radiation effects; Silicon carbide; Gamma irradiation; Schottky barrier diodes

Authors: McNulty P.J., Scheick L.Z., Yow S., Campbell A.B., Savage M.W.
Title: Single-chip dosimeters to accompany photometric systems flown in space
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29634-0978, United States; Electronic Parts Engineering Department, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91101, United States; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29634, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29634-0978, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: McNulty, P.J., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29634-0978, United States; Scheick, L.Z., Electronic Parts Engineering Department, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91101, United States; Yow, S., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29634, United States; Campbell, A.B., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Savage, M.W., Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29634-0978, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Modern photometer systems need to be accompanied by dosimeters that monitor exposure to total ionizing dose, ultra-violet light, and the flux of particles with linear energy transfer above some threshold value. These detectors should minimize space, weight, power, cost, and telemetry. A new approach is described in which single-chip, two-chip, or three-chips systems incorporated into the photometer's interface circuits measure the above while including information on the status of charge trapping in oxides and thermal noise at p-n junctions.
Index Keywords: Chip scale packages; Elementary particle sources; Energy transfer; Fluxes; Ionizing radiation; Photometry; Semiconductor junctions; Thermal noise; Single-chip dosimeters; Dosimeters

Authors: Pease R.L., Sternberg A., Massengill L., Schrimpf R., Buchner S., Savage M., Titus J., Turflinger T.
Title: Critical charge for single-event transients (SETs) in bipolar linear circuits
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; SFA, Inc., Largo, MD 20774, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., IEEE, United States, RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Sternberg, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Massengill, L., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Schrimpf, R., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Buchner, S., IEEE, United States, SFA, Inc., Largo, MD 20774, United States, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Savage, M., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Titus, J., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Turflinger, T., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: Laser and heavy-ion irradiation was used to determine the critical charge for single-event transients (SET) in a comparator and an operational amplifier. The critical charge was simulated and measured in bipolar linear circuits under several bias conditions. The threshold linear energy transfer was less than 2 Mev cm 2/mg in many cases. The minimum critical charge was on the order of 0.3 pC-1 pC.

Authors: MacMullen A., Hoover L.R., Justice R.D., Callahan B.S.
Title: A programmable ultra-low noise X-band exciter
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Ultrasonics, Ferroelectrics, and Frequency Control
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Technology Service Corporation, Los Angeles, CA 90064-1550, United States; Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacMullen, A., IEEE, United States, Technology Service Corporation, Los Angeles, CA 90064-1550, United States; Hoover, L.R., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States; Justice, R.D., Technology Service Corporation, Bloomington, IN 47404, United States; Callahan, B.S., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States
Abstract: A programmable ultra-low noise X-band exciter has been developed using commercial off-the-shelf components. Its phase noise is more than 10 dB below the best available microwave synthesizers. It covers a 7% frequency band with 0.1-Hz resolution. The X-band output at +23 dBm is a combination of signals from an X-band sapphire-loaded cavity oscillator (SLCO), a low noise UHF frequency synthesizer, and special-purpose frequency translation and up-conversion circuitry.

Authors: Lewis H., Jackson P., Salkind A., Danko T., Bell R.
Title: Advanced membranes for alkaline primary and rechargeable alkaline cells with zinc anodes
Affiliations: NAVSEA Crane, Code 609, B3287, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; College of Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08855, United States; Viskase Corporation, 6855 W. 65th Street, Chicago, IL 60638, United States; UCB Films Plc, Wigton, Cumbria, Ca7 9BG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, H., NAVSEA Crane, Code 609, B3287, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Jackson, P., NAVSEA Crane, Code 609, B3287, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Salkind, A., College of Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08855, United States; Danko, T., Viskase Corporation, 6855 W. 65th Street, Chicago, IL 60638, United States; Bell, R., UCB Films Plc, Wigton, Cumbria, Ca7 9BG, United Kingdom
Abstract: Several advanced cellulosic and radiation grafted polypropylene membrane materials are currently under evaluation in the laboratories at Navsea Crane and Rutgers University, for application to alkaline primary and rechargeable cell chemistries which employ zinc as the anode material. A portion of these tests involve model cell evaluations of cellulosic membranes for silver migration rates through the membranes as a function of separation layers and changes in the degree of polymerisation (DP), wet tensile strength (WTS) and voltage changes at both electrodes as a function of model rechargeable cell life cycle. Other testing on the actual membranes is generating data for both cellulosic and polypropylene materials on impedance, swelling properties, and silver and zinc penetration rates. The overall goal of these investigations is to obtain candidate separation membranes which will reduce zinc anode shape change and shedding and resist alkaline oxidative degradation to extend the active wet life in primary cells and both wet and life cycle in rechargeable cells. © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V.

Authors: Sarvestani S.S., Siahmakoun A., Duree G.C., Johnson K.
Title: Electrical fixing of photorefractive gratings in SEN:60
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarvestani, S.S., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Siahmakoun, A., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Duree, G.C., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Johnson, K., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Abstract: We present the result of our investigations on electrical fixing in Sr0.60Ba0.40Nb2O6 (SEN:60). Two electrical fixing techniques which result in very high diffraction efficiencies are discussed and compared to previous publications on electrical fixing. Constant and varying depoling voltages around the coercive field are applied along the c-axis during and after holographic recording in the crystal. The holographic grating is written with two mutually coherent, ordinarily polarized Argon beams at 514 nm. The diffraction efficiency is monitored with an extraordinarily polarized, low power He-Ne beam. The writing beams are expanded to fill the crystal to improve the stability of the reversed domains. The diffraction efficiency in the recording stage is more than an order of magnitude higher than that of a grating written without an external field. We achieve diffraction efficiencies as high as 95% with a gradually increasing negative voltage, while a positive voltage produces a revealed grating with a diffraction efficiency of up to 15%. © 2001 Optical Society of America.
Index Keywords: Barium compounds; Diffraction gratings; Holography; Niobium compounds; Strontium compounds; Argon beams; Coercive field; Depoling; External fields; Higher diffraction; Holographic recordings; Low Power; Orders of magnitude; Photorefractive gratings; Writing beams; Diffraction efficiency

Abstract: We present the design and construction of a two-channel MUX/DEMUX at 1310 nm with a channel spacing of 0.8 nm, using a photorefractive LiNbO3. Fe crystal. To achieve polarization independence, four holographic gratings are superimposed in the crystal, two per wavelength, in order to satisfy the Bragg condition for both polarization-modes of the birefringent LiNbOs. Theoretical studies investigating the feasibility of matched diffraction efficiencies for each polarization component are presented. The gratings are written in transmission geometry with the 514 nm line of an Argon-ion laser; the infrared readout is carried out in reflection geometry. Thermal fixing is used to achieve non-destructive readout, and the results of several modified fixing procedures are compared. Preliminary experimental results with a HeNe readout beam in transmission geometry are discussed. Fixed diffraction efficiencies of about 50% per channel for the superposition of 4 gratings in a 0.05 wt.% iron-doped LiNbO3 crystal are achieved. We describe similar experiments in a 0.1 wt.% iron-doped LiNbO3 and a BaTiO3 crystal for comparison purposes. An active phase stabilization setup is incorporated in order to stabilize the interference pattern during the writing process. © 2001 Optical Society of America.
Index Keywords: Argon lasers; Barium titanate; Diffraction efficiency; Diffraction gratings; Geometry; Iron; Lithium; Lithium compounds; Channel spacings; Design and construction; Fe crystals; Iron-doped; Lithium niobate crystal; MUX/DEMUX; Photorefractives; Polarization independent; Transmission geometries; Two channel; Niobium compounds

Authors: Puttappa J., Siahmakoun A., Chestnut J.
Title: Photorefractive laser beam modulator
Affiliations: Dept. of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane division, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Puttappa, J., Dept. of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Siahmakoun, A., Dept. of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Chestnut, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane division, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Abstract: We create an interferometric closed-loop by recording a set of three volume gratings inside a photorefractive BaTiO3 crystal. These gratings divide a single input beam into two beams that interfere in the far-field. The diffraction efficiency of the gratings depends on the angle between the grating vector and the c-axis, the full angle between the writing beams and their intensity ratio. A PZT-driven mirror phase modulates one of the writing beams that result in a beam modulation rate of up to 700 Hz. This demonstrates the feasibility of a photorefractive crystal as a laser beam modulator. Laser beam modulation is also carried out in LiNbO3 crystal. Two physical geometries have been considered with this crystal. We record only two gratings to form an interferometric path. In this case, applying an external ac electric field to the crystal along the path of one arm of the interferometer results in the desired modulated output. We also describe a theoretical model for an efficient photorefractive beam modulator. © 2001 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Sarvestani S.S., Siahmakoun A., Duree G.C., Johnson K.
Title: An optical method for the determination of the coercive field in ferroelectric crystals
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarvestani, S.S., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Siahmakoun, A., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Duree, G.C., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, 5500 Wabash Avenue, Terre Haute, IN  47803, United States; Johnson, K., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Abstract: We propose an optical method for determining the value of the coercive field in a ferroelectric crystal. The experiment is carried out in photorefractive Sr0.60Ba0.40Nb2O6 (SBN:60), where the crystal is used as a Fabry-Perot interferometer. An extraordinarily polarized He-Ne beam enters the a face of the crystal, while a single 20 V/s triangular electrical pulse (from 0 to 1.9 kV) is applied to the crystal along the c-axis and opposite to the direction of the initial poling field. We describe how the number and direction of fringe shifts with respect to the applied field is used to obtain the value of the coercive field. We find the coercive field value of SBN:60 to be 1.55 kV ± 20 V. We present a similar technique, using an electric pulse in the same direction as the initial poling field to measure the electro-optic coefficient of the crystal. We measure a value of 147 ± 6 pm/V for the r33 coefficient at 632.8 nm. © 2001 Optical Society of America.

Abstract: This work investigates the effects of gamma irradiation on the residual phase noise performance of SiGe HBTs. The excellent phase noise capability of SiGe HBTs is retained after 1 Mrad(Si) irradiation. The observed radiation hardness is attributed to the minor changes in the low frequency noise and device nonlinearities after irradiations, as well as the nonlinearity cancellation mechanism. The radiation-induced defects do not significantly add to the low frequency noise in these SiGe HBTs, even though they produce a large space-charge-region recombination component in the base current. The inherent excellent linearity of these SiGe HBTs makes the up-conversion from device low frequency noise to phase noise inefficient, and helps to retain the low phase noise after irradiations.

Authors: Siahmakoun A., Granieri S., Johnson K.
Title: Double and single side-band suppressed-carrier optical modulator implemented at 1320 nm using LiNbO3 crystals and bulk optics
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN, 47803, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; 5500 Wabash Ave., P. O. Box 192, IN 47803, United States

Abstract: We perform double sideband and single sideband suppressed-carrier modulators using a Mach-Zehnder interferometer in free space. Two bulk LiNbO3 crystals are used to modulate the optical beam at 1319 nm in both branches of the interferometer. We present experimental results of the optical spectrum using heterodyne measurement technique. These results show maximum carrier and sideband suppression of 24 dB and 12 dB respectively for 1 GHz modulation frequency.

Authors: Granieri S., Siahmakoun A., Hughes S., Black B., Chestnut J., Thelen D.
Title: Single side-band suppressed carrier RF processing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, Indiana 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Granieri, S., Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Siahmakoun, A., Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Hughes, S., Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Black, B., Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Chestnut, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, Indiana 47522, United States; Thelen, D., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, Indiana 47522, United States
Abstract: We present a simple scheme for implementation of optical single sideband suppressed carrier (OSSB-SC) modulation based on the use of standard MZM and passive fiber optic components. The function of the proposed modulator is also theoretically predicted. A Sagnac interferometer structure is used for sideband suppression. The light propagating in one direction is orthogonally linearly polarized to the oppositely propagating light. The orthogonal polarization is implemented by a non-reciprocal optical element. The optical carder is attenuated by appropriately setting the Mach-Zender Modulator (MZM) at quadrature bias point. We will experimentally demonstrate sideband suppression and carrier attenuation up to 28 dB by using all commercially available components.

Title: Early lethal SEGR failures of VDMOSFETs considering nonuniformity in the rad-hard device distribution
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; 102 Washington Street, Timonium, MD 21093, United States; 181 Middle Road, Drums, PA 18222, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522-5001, United States

Abstract: In 1999, Titus et al. studied single-event gate rupture failures of vertical MOSFETs for many parameters where the MOSFET universe was assumed to consist of homogenous devices. A nonhomogenous universe is now considered. Time-to-failure is studied using Monte Carlo methods. Boundaries are ascribed applying the empirical equation presented by Titus et al.

Authors: Jay B., Datta A., Goodman A., Johnson W.R.
Title: Military qualification of a high-reliability, light-weight 24 V/30 Ah aircraft battery
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Electrosource Incorporated, 2809 IH 35 South, San Marcos, TX 78666, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Naval Air Systems Command, 48298 Shaw Road, Lexington Park, MD 20670, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jay, B., Electrosource Incorporated, 2809 IH 35 South, San Marcos, TX 78666, United States; Datta, A., Electrosource Incorporated, 2809 IH 35 South, San Marcos, TX 78666, United States; Goodman, A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Johnson, W.R., Naval Air Systems Command, 48298 Shaw Road, Lexington Park, MD 20670, United States
Abstract: The United States Navy has flown Valve Regulated Lead-Acid Batteries (VRLA) for approximately 18 years. The first VRLA aircraft batteries were cylindrical cell design and evolved to a prismatic design to save weight, volume, and to increase rate capability. This paper discusses the next generation of the VRLA aircraft battery. The HORIZON composite grid VRLA design reduces weight, increases high rate performance, and is expected to increase service life. This Commercial Operations and Support Cost Savings Initiative (COSSI) is being jointly funded by Electrosource, Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) - Joint Dual Use Program Office, and Naval Air Systems Command. This paper discusses the weight reduction over the present 30 Ah prismatic VRLA aircraft battery design; improvements in high rate engine start performance, and present status of the development effort. Finally, the paper discusses the applications for the 30 Ah composite grid VRLA aircraft battery, and shows the future application opportunities for light-weight VRLA, both in the military and commercially.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric potential; Military aircraft; Reliability; Aircraft batteries; Aircraft parts and equipment
Funding Details: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, DARPA; Naval Air Systems Command, NAVAIR

Authors: Sarvestani S.S., Siahmakoun A., Duree G., Johnson K.
Title: High diffraction efficiency in SBN with applied fields near the coercive field
Source title: Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarvestani, S.S., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Siahmakoun, A., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Duree, G., Department of Physics and Applied Optics, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Terre Haute, IN 47803, United States; Johnson, K., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: We present the experiments and results of our investigation of electrical fixing in SBN:60. We propose an optical method for determining the value of the coercive field in ferroelectric crystals. An interferometric method is used to map the change in the index of refraction with negative applied fields, where the minimum of the index change is an indication of the coercive field. From this experiment, values of 1.55 kV ± 20 V for the coercive voltage and 147 ± 6 pm/V for the linear electro-optic coefficient are found. Two electrical-fixing techniques that result in very high diffraction efficiencies are presented, discussed and compared to previous publications on electrical fixing in SBN. High diffraction efficiencies of about 95% were achieved with the application of negative fields near the coercive region, during and after holographic recording in the crystal.
Index Keywords: Coercive force; Crystals; Diffraction; Electric potential; Electrooptical effects; Holography; Interferometry; Optical phase conjugation; Photorefractive materials; Refraction; Electrical fixing; Ferroelectric materials

Authors: Barnaby H.J., Cirba C.R., Schrimpf R.D., Fleetwood D.M., Pease R.L., Shaneyfelt M.R., Turflinger T., Krieg J.F., Maher M.C.
Title: Origins of total-dose response variability in linear bipolar microcircuits
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barnaby, H.J., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Cirba, C.R., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., IEEE, United States, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Pease, R.L., IEEE, United States, RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Shaneyfelt, M.R., IEEE, United States, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Turflinger, T., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Krieg, J.F., IEEE, United States, NAVSEA Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Maher, M.C., IEEE, United States
Abstract: LM111 voltage comparators exhibit a wide range of total-dose-induced degradation. Simulations show this variability may be a natural consequence of the low base doping of the substrate PNP (SPNP) input transistors. Low base doping increases the SPNPs collector to base breakdown voltage, current gain, and densities. The build-up of oxide trapped charge (N OT) and interface traps (N IT) is shown to be a function of pre-irradiation bakes. Experimental data indicate that, despite its structural similarities to the LM111, irradiated input transistors of the LM124 operational amplifier do not exhibit the same sensitivity to variations in pre-irradiation thermal cycles. Further disparities in LM111 and LM124 responses may result from a difference in the oxide defect build-up in the two part types. Variations in processing, packaging, and circuit effects are suggested as potential explanations.
Index Keywords: Current gain; Linear bipolar microcircuits; Substrate input transistors; Total dose response; Bipolar integrated circuits; Bipolar transistors; Comparator circuits; Composition effects; Degradation; Dosimetry; Electric breakdown; Electric current collection; Irradiation; Semiconductor device structures; Semiconductor doping; Thermal cycling; Radiation effects

Authors: Zhang S., Niu G., Cressler J.D., Mathew S.J., Gogineni U., Clark S.D., Zampardi P., Pierson R.L.
Title: A comparison of the effects of gamma irradiation on SiGe HBT and GaAs HBT technologies
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Auburn University, AL 36849, United States; Micron Technology Inc., Boise, ID 83707-0006, United States; IBM Microelectronics, Essex Junction, VT 05452, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Conexant Systems, Inc., 2427 Hillcrest Drive, Newbury Park, CA 91320, United States; Rockwell Science Center, 1049 Camino Dos Rios, Thousand Oaks, CA 91360, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, S., IEEE, United States, Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Auburn University, AL 36849, United States; Niu, G., IEEE, United States, Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Auburn University, AL 36849, United States; Cressler, J.D., IEEE, United States, Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Auburn University, AL 36849, United States; Mathew, S.J., IEEE, United States, Micron Technology Inc., Boise, ID 83707-0006, United States; Gogineni, U., IEEE, United States, IBM Microelectronics, Essex Junction, VT 05452, United States; Clark, S.D., IEEE, United States, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Zampardi, P., IEEE, United States, Conexant Systems, Inc., 2427 Hillcrest Drive, Newbury Park, CA 91320, United States; Pierson, R.L., IEEE, United States, Rockwell Science Center, 1049 Camino Dos Rios, Thousand Oaks, CA 91360, United States
Abstract: A comparison of the effects of gamma irradiation on Silicon-Germanium (SiGe) Heterojunction Bipolar Transistor (HBT) and Gallium-Arsenide (GaAs) HBT technologies is reported. DC and Radio Frequency (RF) performance as well as the low frequency noise are investigated for gamma doses up to 1 Mrad(Si). The results indicate that both SiGe and GaAs HBT technologies are tolerant to gamma irradiation.
Index Keywords: Gamma irradiation; Radiation tolerant devices; Gamma rays; Heterojunction bipolar transistors; Irradiation; Natural frequencies; Semiconducting gallium arsenide; Semiconducting silicon; Radiation effects

Authors: Chen M.-S., Dulcey C.S., Brandow S.L., Leonard D.N., Dressick W.J., Calvert J.M., Sims C.W.
Title: Patterned metallization of diamond and alumina substrates
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5348, United States; Shipley Company, Marlborough, MA 01752, United States; Nav. Surf. Warfare Ctr.-Crane Div., Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, M.-S., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5348, United States; Dulcey, C.S., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5348, United States; Brandow, S.L., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5348, United States; Leonard, D.N., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5348, United States; Dressick, W.J., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5348, United States; Calvert, J.M., Shipley Company, Marlborough, MA 01752, United States; Sims, C.W., Nav. Surf. Warfare Ctr.-Crane Div., Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: High-density microelectronics increasingly requires advanced cooling strategies to ensure reliable, high performance. The use of substrates with high thermal conductivity, e.g., diamond, is an attractive approach to managing heat dissipation; however, the fabrication of metal circuitry on diamond films is hindered by the chemical inertness of the surface. In this paper, we present an additive, channel constrained metallization process for the fabrication of metal circuitry on diamond surfaces. We address several issues specific to this application, including photoresist lithography and metal adhesion on substrates with significant surface roughness (peak-to-valley roughness approximately 4 to 5 μm) and the fabrication of circuitry with sufficient electrical conductivity. Fabricated circuitry exhibits suitable resolution (approximately 10 μm), metal thickness (≥2 μm), effective electrical resistivity (approximately 10 μΩ-cm for composite Ni/Cu/Au traces), and adhesion (passes tape peel test) for operation at power levels of at least 22 W (i.e., 1 A, 22 V) without failure or delamination. Thermal modeling and IR images of operating circuitry show an approximately 50% decrease in component junction temperature rise (from ambient) on diamond (k to approximately 1200 W/m K) vs. alumina (k to approximately 20 W/m K), consistent with thermal conductivity differences between these substrate materials.
Index Keywords: Adhesion; Alumina; Electric conductivity of solids; Metallizing; Photoresists; Semiconducting aluminum compounds; Semiconducting diamonds; Subscription television; Surface roughness; Channel constrained metallization (CCM); Microelectronic processing

Authors: Leifer J.H., Pusey H.C., Parkes J.A.
Title: A history of the techniques and equipment used for dynamic testing
Source title: 41st  Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: Shock and Vibration Information Analysis Center, Falls Church, VA, United States; Society for Machinery Failure Prevention Technology, Haymarket, VA, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leifer, J.H., Shock and Vibration Information Analysis Center, Falls Church, VA, United States; Pusey, H.C., Society for Machinery Failure Prevention Technology, Haymarket, VA, United States; Parkes, J.A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: This paper provides a brief overview of the environments faced by designers of equipment from the period preceding World War I to the present. Highlights of how different organizations reacted to those environments are presented, including standards and specifications, test equipment, and test procedures. We touched on the armed services, NASA, the National Labs and industry, describing the effects shock & vibration have had on the design of ships, automobiles, tanks, structures, airplanes, jets, missiles, and spacecraft. The survey is by no means complete; the subject is too broad to handle in one paper.
Index Keywords: Equipment testing; Military operations; NASA; Structural dynamics; Armed services; Dynamic testing; Test equipments; Test procedures; World war I; Dynamic analysis

Authors: Singh H., Palanisamy T., Rudai P., Hoenig S., Mains D., Johnson W.R.
Title: Advanced state of charge measurement technique for silver-zinc batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: AlliedSignal Inc., Defense and Space Systems, Teterboro, NJ  07608, United States; AlliedSignal Inc., Research and Technology, Morristown, NJ  07962, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center NSWC, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States; Naval Air Systems Command, Electrical Power Systems Division, Patuxent River, MD  20670, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, H., AlliedSignal Inc., Defense and Space Systems, Teterboro, NJ  07608, United States; Palanisamy, T., AlliedSignal Inc., Research and Technology, Morristown, NJ  07962, United States; Rudai, P., AlliedSignal Inc., Defense and Space Systems, Teterboro, NJ  07608, United States; Hoenig, S., AlliedSignal Inc., Defense and Space Systems, Teterboro, NJ  07608, United States; Mains, D., Naval Surface Warfare Center NSWC, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States; Johnson, W.R., Naval Air Systems Command, Electrical Power Systems Division, Patuxent River, MD  20670, United States
Abstract: AlliedSignal has developed innovative battery analysis and charging technologies for lead acid, nickel cadmium, and silver-zinc battery families, under the Navy's new technology development initiative. Commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) equipment has been used to develop and implement technologies to meet the growing analysis and maintenance needs of secondary batteries. One highlight of the capabilities developed under this program, is a technique for electrochemically measuring the state of charge (SOC) of silver-zinc (Ag-Zn) batteries. This paper presents the developed technique and outlines a three-stage test procedure for determining SOC. The technique takes a minimal amount of time and provides results of high accuracy. This development meets a longstanding need for the immediate verification of Ag-Zn battery readiness. © 1999 IEEE.

Authors: Jay B., Datta A., Goodman A., Johnson W.R.
Title: Military qualification of a high-reliability, light-weight 24 V/30 Ah aircraft battery
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Electrosource Incorporated, 2809 IH 35 South, San Marcos, TX  78666, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States; Naval Air Systems Command, 48298 Shaw Road, Lexington Park, MD  20670, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jay, B., Electrosource Incorporated, 2809 IH 35 South, San Marcos, TX  78666, United States; Datta, A., Electrosource Incorporated, 2809 IH 35 South, San Marcos, TX  78666, United States; Goodman, A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522, United States; Johnson, W.R., Naval Air Systems Command, 48298 Shaw Road, Lexington Park, MD  20670, United States
Abstract: The United States Navy has flown valve regulated lead-acid batteries (VRLA) for approximately 18 years. The first VRLA aircraft batteries were cylindrical cell design and evolved to a prismatic design to save weight, volume, and to increase rate capability. This paper discusses the next generation of the VRLA aircraft battery. The HORIZON composite grid VRLA design reduces weight, increases high rate performance, and is expected to increase service life. This paper discusses the weight reduction over the present 30 ah prismatic VRLA aircraft battery design; improvements in high rate engine start performance, and presents the status of the development effort. Finally, the paper discusses the applications for the 30 Ah composite grid VRLA aircraft battery, and shows the future application opportunities for light weight VRLA both in the military and commercially. © 1999 IEEE.

Authors: Titus J.L.
Title: Enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS) of linear circuits in a space environment
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: To investigate the ELDRS effect in a real space environment, an experiment was designed, launched, and placed in a highly elliptical orbit in November 1997. After its deployment, the electrical responses of several bipolar transistors and linear circuits have been and continue to be recorded once during every 12-hour orbit. System dosimeters are monitored to establish an average accumulated dose per orbit. With this information, the electrical parameter data are correlated with the dosimetry data to determine the total dose response of each device. This paper updates information on the ELDRS experiment through May 14, 1999. As of this date, the experiment has been in flight for a period of 18 months and has accumulated an approximate dose of 18 krd(Si), For comparison, devices, specifically linear circuits with the same date code, were irradiated using Co-60 sources, herein defined as ground-based tests. The ground-based tests are used to evaluate two hardness assurance tests, a room temperature irradiation at 10 mrd(Si)/s and an elevated temperature irradiation at 100°C and 10 rd(Si)/s and to evaluate the ELDRS response. To that end, irradiations were performed at room temperature, approximately 22 °C, at fixed dose rates of 100, 1, and 0.01 rd(Si)/s and at elevated temperature, approximately 100°C, at a fixed dose rate of 10 rd(Si)/s. Currently, irradiations are being performed at room temperature at a fixed dose rate of 0.001 rd(Si)/s. Comparing the ground-based data to the flight data clearly demonstrates that enhanced parametric degradation has occurred in the flight parts. The two hardness assurance screens predicted ELDRS but the design margin for the elevated . temperature test may not be adequate.
Index Keywords: Enhanced low dose rate sensitivity; Ground based tests; Bipolar transistors; Dosimeters; Gamma rays; Irradiation; Linear integrated circuits; Radiation hardening; Space applications; Temperature; Radiation effects

Authors: Titus J.L.
Title: Prediction of early lethal SEGR failures of VDMOSFETs for commercial space systems
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Quantitative risk assessments are presented for two radiation-hardened MOSFETs (Harris FSL11AO and FRL11AO) using an extracted expression, integral flux curves representing different conditions, and experimentally-determined signature curves taken at different ion impact angles. The effectiveness of certain parameters including the selected orbit, spacecraft shielding thickness, drain and gate biases, device hardness, and time of exposure are discussed. Failures are studied using normalized Monte Carlo simulations validated by statistical methods. These validated Monte Carlo simulations are then used to extract and present an extracted expression. The concept of a lethal ion rate is discussed. Single event gate rupture (SEGR) failure thresholds at different ion impact angles are measured and reported on the Harris FSL11AO and FRL11AO (radiation-hardened vertical MOSFETs having similar layouts but with different SEGR sensitivities). Integral flux curves are presented for various orbits and conditions. Predictions of very early failures are performed using the extracted expression, the integral flux curves, and the new signature curves. Based upon these predictions, the influence of selected parameters are evaluated. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Commercial space systems; Integral flux curves; Ion impact angles; Lethal ion rate; Single event gate rupture; Computer simulation; Failure analysis; Monte Carlo methods; Radiation hardening; Reliability; Risk assessment; Threshold voltage; MOSFET devices

Abstract: Since December 1992, Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane Division (NSWCCD) has logged over 1,318,000 h of cathode life testing on 6 different cathode systems in the Triservice/NASA Cathode Life Test Facility. These include two types of reservoir cathodes designated as MK (Siemens), and RV (CPI, formerly Varian), and impregnated matrix cathodes designated M type (manufactured by Semicon and Hughes), TM (Transition Metal cathodes-CPI) and MMM (Mixed Metal Matrix cathodes-CPI). This paper will present results of the cathode life testing at this facility.

Authors: Smith D.F., Gucinski J.A.
Title: Synthetic silver oxide and mercury-free zinc electrodes for silver-zinc reserve batteries
Affiliations: EMF Systems, 14670 Highway 9, Boulder Creek, CA 950065, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.F., EMF Systems, 14670 Highway 9, Boulder Creek, CA 950065, United States; Gucinski, J.A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: Reserve activated silver oxide-zinc cells were constructed with synthetic silver oxide (Ag2O) electrodes with Pb-treated zinc electrodes produced by a non-electrolytic process. The cells were tested before and after thermally accelerated aging. At discharge rates up to 80 mA cm-2, the discharge was limited by the Ag2O electrode, with a coulombic efficiency between 89-99%. At higher rates, the cells are apparently zinc-limited. Test cells were artificially aged at 90 °C for 19 h and discharged at 21 °C at 80 mA cm-2. No capacity loss was measured, but a delayed activation rise time was noted (192 ms fresh vs. 567 ms aged). The delay is thought to be caused by zinc passivation due to the outgassing of cell materials.
Index Keywords: Activation analysis; Aging of materials; Anodes; Degassing; Electric discharges; Passivation; Silver compounds; Silver-zinc reserve batteries; Secondary batteries

Authors: Lewis H.L., Danko T., Himy A., Johnson W.
Title: Alternative separation evaluations in model rechargeable silver-zinc cells
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Code 6091, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Viskase, Chicago, IL 60638, United States; J.J. McMullen Association, Arlington, VA 22202, United States; Naval Air Warfare Center, Aircraft Division, Patuxent River, MD 20670, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, H.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Code 6091, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Danko, T., Viskase, Chicago, IL 60638, United States; Himy, A., J.J. McMullen Association, Arlington, VA 22202, United States; Johnson, W., Naval Air Warfare Center, Aircraft Division, Patuxent River, MD 20670, United States
Abstract: Several varieties of standard and reinforced, cellulose-based, sausage casing films derived from wood pulp have been evaluated in model (nominal 28 A h) rechargeable silver-zinc cells. The cell performance data for both cycle life and wet stand life have been compared with cells equipped with conventional 1 mil (0.025 mm) cellophane. Although shorting was the most common failure mode in the cells with sausage casing separation, remarkably good cycle and wet life were obtained when the separation wrap also included PVA film. This paper reports the cycle and wet life comparison data for these substitute separators, with respect to conventional cellophane separation, as well as separation physical property data and silver migration rates in the cells as a function of cell life.
Index Keywords: Cellulose; Plastic films; Polyvinyl alcohols; Separators; Zinc-silver oxide rechargeable batteries; Secondary batteries

Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Mission Research Corp., 1720 Randolph Rd. S. E, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States
Abstract: Bipolar devices, most notably circuits fabricated with lateral PNP transistors (LPNP) and substrate PNP transistors (SPNP), have been observed to exhibit an enhanced low dose rate sensitivity when exposed to ionizing radiation. These dose rate sensitive bipolar devices exhibited enhanced degradation of base current in transistors and of input bias current, offset current, and/or offset voltage in linear circuits at dose rates less than 0.1 rd(Si)/s) compared to devices irradiated at dose rates greater than 1 rd(Si)/s). The total dose responses of several bipolar transistors and linear circuits in a space environment are demonstrated to exhibit enhanced degradation comparable, in magnitude, to ground-based data irradiated at a dose rate of 10 mrd(Si)/s indicating that enhanced low dose rate sensitivities (RLDRS) do indeed exist in space. © 1998 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bipolar transistors; Current voltage characteristics; Integrated circuit testing; Ionizing radiation; Irradiation; Linear integrated circuits; Radiation effects; Radiation hardening; Enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS); Bipolar integrated circuits

Authors: Titus J.L., Whealley C.F., Van Tyne K.M., Krieg F., Burton D.I., Campbell A.B.
Title: Effect of ion energy upon dielectric breakdown of the capacitor response in vertical power mosfets
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy. 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; R.R. 2, Box 1120, Drums, PA 18222, United States; Harris Semiconductor, 125 Crestwood Rd, Mountaintop, PA, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., IEEE, United States, Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy. 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Whealley, C.F., R.R. 2, Box 1120, Drums, PA 18222, United States, Harris Semiconductor, 125 Crestwood Rd, Mountaintop, PA, United States; Van Tyne, K.M., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Krieg, F., IEEE, United States, Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy. 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States, R.R. 2, Box 1120, Drums, PA 18222, United States; Burton, D.I., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Campbell, A.B., Harris Semiconductor, 125 Crestwood Rd, Mountaintop, PA, United States, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Abstract: The effect of ion energy upon the ion-induced dielectric breakdown response of the capacitor response in vertical power rnelal-oxide semiconductor field effect transistors (MOSFETs) was investigated. The single event gate rupture response was experimentally determined using mono-energetic ion beams of copper, niobium, and gold. Irradiations were conducted using an ion species tuned to different energies, producing a range of linear energy transfer (LET) values for that ion. Numerous MOSFETs were characterized to identify the onset of ioninduced dielectric breakdown. These data along with previously taken data demonstrated that the ion-induced dielectric breakdown cannot be adequately described in terms of LET, but is better described in terms of atomic number (Z). Based upon these observations, a new semi-empirical expression is presented describing the critical inn-induced breakdown response in terms of Z instead of LET. This expression is shown to be a better single evenl gate rupture model of the capacitor response. © 1998 IEEE.

Authors: Pease R.L., Gehlhausen M., Krieg J., Titus J., Turflinger T., Emily D., Cohn L.
Title: Evaluation of proposed hardness assurance method for bipolar linear circuits with enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS)
Affiliations: RLP Research, 1718 Quail Run Court NE, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Defense Special Weapons Agency, Alexandria, VA 20122, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., RLP Research, 1718 Quail Run Court NE, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Gehlhausen, M., RLP Research, 1718 Quail Run Court NE, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Krieg, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Titus, J., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Turflinger, T., Defense Special Weapons Agency, Alexandria, VA 20122, United States; Emily, D., Defense Special Weapons Agency, Alexandria, VA 20122, United States; Cohn, L., Defense Special Weapons Agency, Alexandria, VA 20122, United States
Abstract: Data are presented on several low dose rate sensitive bipolar linear circuits to evaluate a proposed hardness assurance method. The circuits include primarily operational amplifiers and voltage comparators with a variety of sensitive components and failure modes. The proposed method, presented in 1997, includes an option between a low dose rate test at 10mrd(Si)/s and room temperature and a 100°C elevated temperature irradiation test at a moderate dose rate. The results of this evaluation demonstrate that a 10 mrd(Si)/s test is able (in all but one case) to bound the worst case response within a factor of 2. For the moderate dose rate, 100°C test the worst case response is within a factor of 3 for 8 of 11 circuits, and for some circuits averpredicts the low dose rate response. The irradiation bias used for these tests often represents a more degrading bias condition than would be encountered in a typical space system application. © 1998 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bipolar integrated circuits; Comparator circuits; Integrated circuit testing; Irradiation; Operational amplifiers; Radiation effects; Radiation hardening; Enhanced low dose rate sensitivity (ELDRS); Radiation hardness; Linear integrated circuits

Authors: Titus J.L., Wheatley C.F.
Title: Proton-induced dielectric breakdown of power mosfets
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wheatley, C.F., Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Hwy 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Proton-induced dielectric breakdown of vertical power metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistors (MOSFETs) is reported for the first time and compared to the heavy-ioninduced gate rupture response. Power MOSFETs from five variants were fabricated with nominal gate oxide thicknesses of 30, 50, 70, 100, and 150 nm. Devices from each variant were characterized to several heavy ion beams as previously reported; and then other devices from each variant were subsequently characterized to 200-MeV protons, as reported here. In addition, a limited characterization was performed using 44-MeV protons. Employing a similar test methodology, failure thresholds for the onset of proton-induced dielectric breakdown were determined for each gate oxide variant. The measured proton-induced dielectric breakdown thresholds induced by 200- and 44-MeV protons are compared to the measured heavy-ion induced failure thresholds. © 1998 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric breakdown of solids; Failure analysis; Proton irradiation; Radiation damage; Semiconductor device manufacture; Proton induced dielectric breakdown; MOSFET devices

Authors: Stuffle B., Harris M.
Title: Updating the Navy's parts derating requirements and application manual to include GaAs-based components
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47522-5080, United States; Electro-optics Environment and Materials Laboratory, Atlanta, GA  30332-0826, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stuffle, B., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47522-5080, United States; Harris, M., Electro-optics Environment and Materials Laboratory, Atlanta, GA  30332-0826, United States
Abstract: The Microelectronics Component Engineering Branch at Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC/CD) is in the process of updating the Navy's Parts Derating Requirements and Application Manual for Navy Electronic Equipment (TE000-AB-GTP-O10). The military parts community has migrated from a Qualified Parts Listing (QPL) philosophy to a Qualified Manufacturers Listing (QML) and has also implemented the use of performance specifications. GaAs-based components are now being used in Navy electronic equipment and need to be included in TE000-AB-GTP-010. NSWC/CD's goal is to make this document as accurate as possible by seeking guidance from the GaAs-based component supplier community. This paper describes the work that is being performed in the area of GaAs-based components. The derating of a number of GaAs technologies are being addressed in the updated manual. The manual addresses failure mechanisms and derating parameters for three environmental categories, which are based upon MIL-HDBK-179 (Microcircuit Acquisition Handbook). © 1998 IEEE.

Authors: Harris M., Wagner B., Halpern S., Dobbs M., Pagel C., Stuffle B., Henderson J., Johnson K.
Title: Full two-dimensional electroluminescent analysis of GaAs/AlGaAs HBTs
Affiliations: Georgia Tech Research Institute, Electro-optics Environment and Materials Laboratory, Atlanta, GA  30332-0826, United States; Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47522-5080, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harris, M., Georgia Tech Research Institute, Electro-optics Environment and Materials Laboratory, Atlanta, GA  30332-0826, United States; Wagner, B., Georgia Tech Research Institute, Electro-optics Environment and Materials Laboratory, Atlanta, GA  30332-0826, United States; Halpern, S., Georgia Tech Research Institute, Electro-optics Environment and Materials Laboratory, Atlanta, GA  30332-0826, United States; Dobbs, M., Georgia Tech Research Institute, Electro-optics Environment and Materials Laboratory, Atlanta, GA  30332-0826, United States; Pagel, C., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47522-5080, United States; Stuffle, B., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47522-5080, United States; Henderson, J., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47522-5080, United States; Johnson, K., Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47522-5080, United States
Abstract: Full two-dimensional electroluminescent techniques have been developed and applied to HBTs for the first time to reveal the growth and progression of dark-line defects in AlGaAs HBTs at elevated current densities. Bias studies have shown that at high current densities, HBT base-emitter junctions degrade resulting in regions that exhibit non-radiative recombination. Defects in the epitaxial material can lead to current driven dislocation propagation caused by recombination enhanced dislocation climb and recombination enhanced dislocation glide. At current densities on the order of 100 KA/cm2, formation of dark-line defects occurs within 92 hours. At current densities approaching 150 KA/cm2, rapid changes (within hours) are observed in the EL pattern; however, little change in the dc and RF characteristics are seen in the short term. This demonstrates that the EL technique is a sensitive indicator of material changes in devices well before any electrical manifestation. © 1998 IEEE.

Title: Gamma radiation tolerance of UHV/CVD SiGe BiCMOS technology operated at cryogenic temperatures
Affiliations: Alabama Microlectron. Sci. T., Electrical Engineering Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; IBM Microelectronics, Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States

Sci. T., Electrical Engineering Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Niu, G., Alabama Microlectron. Sci. T., Electrical Engineering Department, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Clark, S.D., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Nguyen-Ngoc, D., IBM Microelectronics, Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States
Abstract: This paper presents for the first time the effects of ionizing gamma rays on a high-performance UHV/CVD SiGe BiCMOS technology irradiated at both 300K and 77K. The SiGe HBTs show a degradation in current gain below 10% at 300K and no observable shifts in current gain at 77K. The Si pFETs are radiation hard to 1.0 Mrad(Si) at both 300K and 77K, while the Si nFETs are able to withstand 100 krad(Si). In this work, we examine the total dose response of SiGe HBTs and concentrate on the post-radiation behavior of the nFETs and pFETs irradiated under bias at both 300K and 77K.

Authors: Burch D., Johnson M., Sims K.
Title: Value added products from reclamation of military munitions
Affiliations: Crane Division (Code 4073), Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burch, D., Crane Division (Code 4073), Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Johnson, M., Crane Division (Code 4073), Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Sims, K., Crane Division (Code 4073), Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: The Department of Defense has a backlog of excess, obsolete and unserviceable munitions for disposal. For many of these munition items the only method of disposal is open burning/open detonation (OB/OD) which destroys valuable resources which can be reclaimed and converted to useful products. The Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NAVSURFWARCENDIV Crane) in support of the Navy's Ordnance Reclamation Program and the Joint Service Large Rocket Motor Disposal Program has been developing technology for the removal and reclamation of the energetics from munitions. The University of Missouri-Rolla has demonstrated the use of high pressure waterjet technology for removal of PBX explosives from projectiles and warheads. Development work is nearing completion for demonstrating the capability to remove Class 1.1 propellent from strategic rocket motors using high pressure waterjets. Current projects are under way focusing on resource recovery and recycling (R3) of the reclaimed energetics while minimizing disposal. The current reclamation projects include reformulation of the explosives and Class 1.1 propellants into commercial blasting agents, reuse of Navy gun propellent for various applications including agriculture and oil-gas well stimulation. Other projects include the recovery of RDX/HMX from Class 1.1 explosives and propellants and the conversion of Explosive D into higher value products. Lab/bench scale testing has been completed on many of these processes, and for some pilot scale demonstrations have been or are scheduled to be completed during 1997.The Department of Defense has a backlog of excess, obsolete and unserviceable munitions for disposal. For many of these munition items the only method of disposal is open burning/open detonation (OB/OD) which destroys valuable resources which can be reclaimed and converted to useful products. The Crane Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center (NAVSURFWARCENDIV Crane) in support of the Navy's Ordnance Reclamation Program and the Joint Service Large Rocket Motor Disposal Program has been developing technology for the removal and reclamation of the energetics from munitions. The University of Missouri-Rolla has demonstrated the use of high pressure waterjet technology for removal of PBX explosives from projectiles and warheads. Development work is nearing completion for demonstrating the capability to remove Class 1.1 propellant from strategic rocket motors using high pressure waterjets. Current projects are under way focusing on resource recovery and recycling (R3) of the reclaimed energetics while minimizing disposal. The current reclamation projects include reformulation of the explosives and Class 1.1 propellants into commercial blasting agents, reuse of Navy gun propellant for various applications including agriculture and oil-gas well stimulation. Other projects include the recovery of RDX/HMX from Class 1.1 explosives and propellants and the conversion of Explosive D into higher value products. Lab/bench scale testing has been completed on many of these processes, and for some pilot scale demonstrations have been or are scheduled to be completed during 1997.
