Authors: Lewis H., Grun C., Salkind A.
Title: Cellulosic separator applications: New and improved separators for alkaline rechargeable cells
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; College of Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08855, United States; UMDNJ-Robert Wood Johnson Med. Sch., Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, H., Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Grun, C., College of Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08855, United States, UMDNJ-Robert Wood Johnson Med. Sch., Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States; Salkind, A., College of Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08855, United States, UMDNJ-Robert Wood Johnson Med. Sch., Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States
Abstract: A study has been established at Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division (NAVSURFWARCENDIV) and Rutgers University to obtain material analysis data on cellulosic separator properties such as tensile strength and swelling of alkaline-soaked film samples, degree of polymerization and crystallinity, cationic and anionic diffusion and penetration rates in alkaline media, and X-ray diffraction for crystallinity. These data are then related to cycle-and wet-life information from model electrochemical cells as a function of separator composition on an alkaline chemistry rechargeable cell set. The first examples used in this program are silver-zinc rechargeable cells of 28 Ah capacity, identical in every respect except for the separator composition, which are being tested in statistically significant numbers under identical temperature and relative humidity conditions, with 45% KOH as the electrolyte. The cycle-life test regime of continuous cycling is: C/5 discharge to 1.30 V, and C/30 and C/60 charge to 2.03 V, while the wet-life test regime includes a 30-day wet-stand at full charge between cycles. At the outset of the cell testing, a baseline cell was selected from each set in the matrix after the so-called formation cycling was complete, and the physical properties of crystallinity, tensile strength, and degree of polymerization were re-measured. Then, at intervals during cycle-and wet-life cycling, and as cells fail the life tests, these properties will be measured again for selected cells. In this way a correlation will be established between separator life under charge/discharge conditions in actual cells and the critical physical properties of each separator film. Eight separator compositions, all cellulose-based, are being evaluated. The purpose of the study is to utilize the cycle-and wet-life data which are a function of separator composition and physical properties in the alkaline chemistry rechargeable cell set, to designate a 'best' separator for incorporation into actual production cells by the manufacturing community for silver/zinc rechargeable cells. The recommendations will take the form of minimum separator physical properties which are beneficial to cell performance and long life, resulting in an improvement in the assets available for Fleet use in the US Navy. This paper discusses the data available to date on cycle-and wet-life, and their relationship to separator physical properties before and at several stages during cycling.
Author Keywords: Alkaline rechargeable cells; Cellulosic separators; Separators

Authors: Roldán J.M., Ansley W.E., Cressler J.D., Clark S.D., Nguyen-Ngoc D.
Title: Neutron radiation tolerance of advanced uhv/cvd sige hbt bicmos technology
Affiliations: IEEE, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Electrical Engineering Department, 200 Broun Hall, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; IBM Microelectronics, Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roldán, J.M., IEEE, Auburn, AL 36849, United States, Electrical Engineering Department, 200 Broun Hall, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Ansley, W.E., Electrical Engineering Department, 200 Broun Hall, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Cressler, J.D., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Clark, S.D., IBM Microelectronics, Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States; Nguyen-Ngoc, D., IBM Microelectronics, Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States
Abstract: The effects of 1.0 MeV neutron irradiation on both SiGe heterojunction bipolar transistors (HBTs) and Si CMOS transistors from an advanced ultra high vacuum chemical vapour deposition (UHV/CVD) SiGe BiCMOS technology are examined for the first time over the temperature range of 300K to 84K. Results at 300K indicate that this SiGe technology is robust with respect to neutron radiation. At fluences as high as 1015 n/cm2 (1.0 MeV equivalent) the devices exhibited a degradation of less than 30% in peak current gain. The SiGe HBTs maintain a current gain of 60 after 1015 n/cm2 at 84K, compared to the Si BJT which degrades with cooling to a current gain of 20 at 84K. The cutoff frequencies of both the Si and SiGe transistors are unaffected by neutron irradiation, and only a slight degradation in the maximum oscillation frequency of the transistors was observed. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bipolar integrated circuits; Chemical vapor deposition; CMOS integrated circuits; Electric currents; Neutron irradiation; Oscillations; Radiation damage; Semiconducting silicon compounds; Vacuum applications; Neutron radiation tolerance; Ultrahigh vacuum chemical vapor deposition (UHV/CVD); Heterojunction bipolar transistors

Title: A proposed hardness assurance test methodology for bipolar linear circuits and devices in a space ionizing radiation environment
Affiliations: 'Rlp Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Defense Special Weapons Agency, Alexandria, VA 22310, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States

Abstract: A hardness assurance test approach has been developed for bipolar linear circuits and devices in space. It consists of an initial test for dose rate sensitivity and a characterization test method to develop the conditions for a lot acceptance test at high dose rate. For parts with adequate design margin and/or well behaved parts a generic elevated temperature irradiation test is proposed. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bipolar integrated circuits; Integrated circuit testing; Linear integrated circuits; Radiation damage; Space applications; Thermal effects; Hardness assurance test; Radiation hardness; Bipolar semiconductor devices

Authors: Simons M., Pease R.L., Fleetwood D.M., Schwank J.R., Krzesniak M.F.
Title: Dose enhancement in a room cobalt-60 source1
Affiliations: Research Triangle Institute, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane Div., Crane, IN 47522, United States

Abstract: A room Co-60 source was characterized using thermoluminescent dosimeters (TLDs) and pMOS RADFETs. Measurements were made over a range of dose rates between 0.8 and 100 mrad(Si)/s. Dose enhancement (DE) was measured using RADFETs with and without gold-flashed kovar lids. DE factors ranged from 1.05 to 2.35. A method was developed to predict dose enhancement as a function of position and test configuration. This method involves separation of direct and scattered gamma dose rate contributions. ©1997 IEEE.

Title: Reformulation of Solid Propellants and High Explosives: An Environmentally Benign Means of Demilitarizing Explosive Ordnance
Affiliations: D. S. Abstract: Polymer Bound Explosives (PBXs) and Class 1.1 Military Propellants have been reformulated for use in the mining industry. There is a minimal waste stream. The explosives are sensitive to initiation by a #8 cap. Impact sensitivities have routinely passed 5 kg meter stimuli, initiation by 50,000 V AC and the BAM friction protocols at 1000 rpm under a 11 kg load for 10 seconds. The explosives were packed into sticks, slurried or used as pourable mixes. VoDs of 2.4 to 6.2 km/s were realized with ρ = 0.9 - 1.35 t/m3. The explosives have powers comparable to a range of dynamites. The Beaver Code based upon Lotus 1.2.3 -5™ was developed to predict explosive properties.
Author Keywords: Commercial explosives; Demilitarization; Military explosives/propellants; Resource reuse; Waste free

Authors: Smith D.F., Graybill G.R., Grubbs R.K., Gucinski J.A.
Title: New developments in very high rate silver oxide electrodes
Affiliations: EMF Systems, Inc., Boulder Creek, CA, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.F., EMF Systems, Inc., Boulder Creek, CA, United States; Graybill, G.R., EMF Systems, Inc., Boulder Creek, CA, United States; Grubbs, R.K., EMF Systems, Inc., Boulder Creek, CA, United States; Gucinski, J.A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN, United States
Abstract: Cathodes for primary silver/zinc cells were prepared using chemically synthesized silver oxides (both monovalent and divalent). The oxides were mixed with PTFE binder but with no conductive fillers for this work. The electrodes were discharged galvanostatically over a broad range of current densities (40-500 mA cm-2) and temperature (7-40°C) in 6.3 M KOH electrolyte. The discharge capacity was greater than 90% of the theoretical value for both oxides under such conditions. At high rate (500 mA cm-2) the overvoltage of the monovalent oxide is about 50 mV less than that for the divalent oxide. A 42% improvement in energy density over anodized silver cathodes was demonstrated with the chemical AgO electrodes.
Author Keywords: Silver oxides; Zinc anode reserve batteries

Authors: Mouret I., Calvel P., Allenspach M., Titus J.L., Wheatley C.F., LaBel K.A., Calvet M.-C., Schrimpf R.D., Galloway K.F.
Title: Measurement of a cross-section for single-event gate rupture in power MOSFET's
Affiliations: IEEE; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Aérospatiale, Les Mureaux, 71833, France; Alcatel Espace, Toulouse, 31037, France; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; RR2, Drums, PA 18222, United States; NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States; Aérospatiale, Les Mureaux, 78133, France
Authors with affiliations: Mouret, I., IEEE, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States, Aérospatiale, Les Mureaux, 71833, France; Calvel, P., IEEE, Alcatel Espace, Toulouse, 31037, France; Allenspach, M., IEEE, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Titus, J.L., IEEE, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wheatley, C.F., IEEE, RR2, Drums, PA 18222, United States; LaBel, K.A., IEEE, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States; Calvet, M.-C., IEEE, Aérospatiale, Les Mureaux, 78133, France; Schrimpf, R.D., IEEE, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Galloway, K.F., IEEE, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: The heavy-ion fluence required to induce Single-Event Gate Rupture (SEGR) in power MOSFET's is measured as a fraction of the drain bias, VDS and as a function of the gate bias, VGS. These experiments reveal the abrupt nature of the SEGR-voltage threshold. In addition, the concepts of cross-section, threshold, and saturation in the SEGR phenomenon are irtroduced. This experimental technique provides a convenient method to quantify heavy-ion effects in power MOSFET's.

Authors: Hillenberg S., Thelen D.
Title: Highly accurate techniques to measure SNR and phase of non-linear RF amplifiers
Source title: 48th ARFTG Conference, ARFTG 1996 Digest - Fall 1996: RF Non-Linearitv Measurements, ARFTG 1996
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane, Crane, IN  47522, United States; Technology Service Corporation, 116 W. 6th St., Suite 200, Bloomington, IN  47404, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hillenberg, S., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane, Crane, IN  47522, United States; Thelen, D., Technology Service Corporation, 116 W. 6th St., Suite 200, Bloomington, IN  47404, United States
Abstract: Techniques for accurate measurements of the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and insertion phase of non-linear amplifiers will be discussed. These techniques remove the effect of linear and non-linear measurement equipment distortions in software. The vector demodulator (VDM) is the largest source of these linear and non-linear distortions. Data distortion also originates because of electromagnetic interference from the wall voltage. A description of the measurement equipment required for accurate SNR and phase measurements will be given. A non-standard piece of equipment required in this technique is an electronic phase shifter. The use of this electronic phase shifter allows the linear and non-linear VDM distortions to be characterized by sweeping the VDM through several different operating points. Details of the software algorithms for measuring SNR and phase will be discussed. The non-linear data analysis algorithm estimates SNR values in two steps: [1] Estimating the distortion levels by making a Fourier Transform of pulse-averaged I/Q values and [2] calculating an SNR value from amplitude and phase noise fluctuations derived from the measured VQ values by using a small-signal espansion of the noise fluctuations about the non-linear VDM operating points. Phase measurements are also corrupted due to the presence of VDM distortions. We will introduce phase measurement techques that minimize the effects of these distortions. The presence of line voltage interference is detectable from the Fourier analysis of collected data. Experiments have indicated a detectable level of contamination at frequencies of 60 Hz, 120 Hz: and 180 Hz. © 48th ARFTG Conference, ARFTG 1996 Digest - Fall 1996: RF Non-Linearitv Measurements, ARFTG 1996. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic pulse; Fourier analysis; Mathematical transformations; Phase measurement; Phase noise; Phase shifters; Accurate measurement; Data analysis algorithms; Electronic phase shifter; Measurement equipment; Noise fluctuations; Nonlinear measurement; Operating points; Software algorithms; Signal to noise ratio
Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
Conference name: 48th ARFTG Conference, ARFTG 1996
Abbreviated Source Title: ARFTG Conf., ARFTG Dig.t - Fall: RF Non-Linearitv Meas., ARFTG

Title: A physical interpretation for the single-event-gate-rupture cross-section of N-channel power MOSFETs
Affiliations: University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5000, United States; Universite Montpellier II, Montpellier, France
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, G.H., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Galloway, K.P., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5000, United States; Wheatley, C.F., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522-5000, United States; Allenspach, M., Universite Montpellier II, Montpellier, France; Dachs, C., Universite Montpellier II, Montpellier, France
Abstract: The single-event-gate-rupture cross-section is measured as a function of drain-source and gate-source bias for some n-channel power MOSFETs. The experimental techniques are explained, and the results are interpreted with the help of two-dimensional computer modeling. © 1996 IEEE.

Title: SEGR response of a radiation-hardened power MOSFET technology
Affiliations: RR2, Box 1120, Drums, PA 18222, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Harris Semiconductor, Crestwood Road, Mountaintop, PA 18707, United States; Box 591, Somerville, NJ 08876, United States

Abstract: SEGR response curves are presented for eighteen different device types of radiation-hardened power MOSFETs. Comparisons are made to demonstrate the technology's insensitivity to die size, rated blocking voltage, channel conductivity, and temperature. From this data, SEGR cross-sectional area curves are inferred. © 1996 IEEE.

Title: SEGR and SEB in N-channel power MOSFETs
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Centre d'Electronique de Montpellier, Université Montpellier II, Montpellier 34090, France; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Allenspach, M., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Dachs, C., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Johnson, G.H., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Centre d'Electronique de Montpellier, Université Montpellier II, Montpellier 34090, France; Lorfevre, E., Centre d'Electronique de Montpellier, Université Montpellier II, Montpellier 34090, France; Palau, J.M., Centre d'Electronique de Montpellier, Université Montpellier II, Montpellier 34090, France; Brews, J.R., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Galloway, K.P., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Titus, J.L.; Wheatley, C.F.
Abstract: For particular bias conditions, it is shown that a device can fail due to either single-event gate rupture (SEGR) or to single-event burnout (SEE). The likelihood of triggering SEGR is shown to be dependent on the ion impact position. Hardening techniques are suggested. © 1996 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Gates (transistor); Ion bombardment; Power electronics; Radiation effects; Radiation hardening; Single event burnouts (SEB); Single event gate rupture (SEGR); MOSFET devices

Authors: Titus J.L., Wheatley C.F., Allenspach M., Schrimpf R.D., Burton D.I., Brews J.R., Galloway K.F., Pease R.L.
Title: Influence of ion beam energy on SEGR failure thresholds of vertical power MOSFETs
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Harris Semiconductor, Mountaintop, PA 18707, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wheatley, C.F., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Allenspach, M.; Schrimpf, R.D.; Burton, D.I., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Brews, J.R., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Galloway, K.F., Harris Semiconductor, Mountaintop, PA 18707, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States
Abstract: For the first time, experimental observations and numerical simulations show that the impact energy of the test ion influences the single-event gate rupture (SEGR) failure thresholds of vertical power MOSFETs. Current testing methodology may produce false hardness assurance. © 1996 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Gates (transistor); Ion beams; Ion bombardment; Power electronics; Radiation effects; Radiation hardening; Semiconductor device testing; Single event gate rupture (SEGR); MOSFET devices

Authors: Witczak S.C., Galloway K.F., Schrimpf R.D., Titus J.L., Brews J.R., Prévost G.
Title: The determination of si-sio2 interface trap density in irradiated four-terminal vdmosfets using charge pumping
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721., United States; Advanced Technology Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522., United States
Authors with affiliations: Witczak, S.C., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721., United States; Galloway, K.F., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721., United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721., United States; Titus, J.L., Advanced Technology Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522., United States; Brews, J.R., Advanced Technology Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522., United States; Prévost, G., Advanced Technology Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522., United States
Abstract: The utility of charge pumping to measure Si-SiOs interface trap density in irradiated four-terminal VDMOSFETs is demonstrated. A modification of the conventional charge pumping approach is employed, where recombination of charge through interface traps in the neck region is measured in the drain. Three components of drain current resulting from the charge pumping measurement are identified. When the device is properly biased, charge pumping current can be separated from the other components of drain current and modeled over a wide range of interface trap densities using standard charge pumping theory. When sources of error are accounted for, radiation-induced interface trap densities measured with charge pumping are in good quantitative agreement with those estimated with the midgap charge separation and subthreshold hump techniques. © 1996 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Radiation effects; Semiconducting silicon; Semiconductor junctions; Silica; Charge pumping; Interface trap density; Vertical double diffused MOSFETs; MOSFET devices

Authors: Allenspach M., Brews J.R., Galloway K.F., Johnson G.H., Schrimpf R.D., Pease R.L., Titus J.L., Wheatley C.F.
Title: SEGR: A unique failure mode for power MOSFETs in spacecraft
Affiliations: Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Allenspach, M., Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Brews, J.R., Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Galloway, K.F., Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Johnson, G.H., Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wheatley, C.F.
Abstract: Power MOSFETs are vulnerable to catastrophic single-event phenomena when exposed to the radiation environment of space. In particular, single-event-gate-rupture (SEGR) is a failure mechanism unique to DMOS power transistors caused by the passage of a heavy ion through the neck region of the device and the subsequent transient electric field across the gate oxide. This paper will describe the failure mode, present supporting experimental data, and demonstrate an effective simulation tool for predicting gate rupture. Copyright © 1996 Elsevier Science Ltd.

Authors: Madhavan V., Farris T.N., Chandrasekar S., Craig L.
Title: Fem comparison of ball and roller bullgears
Affiliations: Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Madhavan, V., Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States; Farris, T.N., Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States; Chandrasekar, S., Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States; Craig, L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Abstract: A structural finite element model has been developed for calculating the forces transmitted through the rolling elements (load distribution) in a bullgear assembly. The elastic structural model consists of 3-D beam elements used to approximate the global race deflection and non-linear springs that approximate the combined rolling element/raceway contact deflections. For rollers, an upperbound on the contact stress (assuming linear variation of force along the length of the roller) is estimated by modeling the rollers as pairs of nonlinear springs. The finite element approach iteratively solves the contact forces at each, rolling element. Contact stresses are then calculated from the contact, forces using Hertz contact theory. This approach is applied to analyze two proposed designs of ball and crossed roller bearing, bullgear assemblies used for rotating the radar antenna on top of a ship's mast. The loads analyzed include those arising from wind loading and from out-of-flatness of the inner race of the bearings due to deflection of the mast. The distribution of the load and the maximum contact stresses for the proposed bullgear assemblies are estimated and compared. It is found that the maximum contact stress in the crossed roller bearing is less than that in the ball bearing for both types of loads. Furthermore, the analysis shows that the out-of-flatness loading produces significantly higher stresses than wind loading. © 1996 Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Contact mechanics; Rolling-element bearings; Stress analysis

Authors: Schrimpf R.D., Graves R.J., Schmidt D.M., Fleetwood D.M., Pease R.L., Combs W.E., DeLaus M.
Title: Hardness-Assurance Issues for Lateral PNP Bipolar Junction Transistors
Affiliations: University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington, MA 01887, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schrimpf, R.D., University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Graves, R.J., University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schmidt, D.M., University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Combs, W.E., Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN 47522, United States; DeLaus, M., Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington, MA 01887, United States
Abstract: The dose-rate dependence of gain degradation in lateral PNP transistors is even stronger than the dependence previously reported for NPN BJTs. In this work, several hardness-assurance approaches are examined and compared to experimental results obtained at low dose rates. The approaches considered include irradiation at high dose rates while at elevated temperature and high-dose-rate irradiation followed by annealing. The lateral PNP transistors continue to degrade during post-irradiation annealing, in sharp contrast to NPN devices studied previously. High-temperature conditions significantly increase the degradation during high-dose-rate irradiation, with the amount of degradation continuing to increase with temperature throughout the range studied here (up to 125°C). The high-temperature degradation is nearly as great as that observed at very low dose rates, and is even greater when differences between 60Co and x-ray irradiation are accounted for. Since high-temperature irradiation has previously been shown to enhance the degradation in NPN transistors, this appears to be a promising hardness-assurance approach for bipolar integrated circuits. Based on these results, preliminary testing recommendations are discussed. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Annealing; Degradation; Dosimetry; Radiation hardening; Semiconductor junctions; Thermal effects; Bipolar junction transistors; Dose rate dependence; Gain degradation; Bipolar transistors

Authors: Titus J.L., Wheatley C.F., Burton D.I., Mouret I., Allenspach M., Brews J., Schrimpf R., Galloway K., Pease R.L.
Title: Impact of Oxide Thickness on SEGR Failure in Vertical Power MOSFETs; Development of a Semi-Empirical Expression
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Consultant, Drums, PA 18222, United States; Harris Semiconductor, Mountaintop, PA 18707, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Wheatley, C.F., Consultant, Drums, PA 18222, United States; Burton, D.I., Harris Semiconductor, Mountaintop, PA 18707, United States; Mouret, I., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Allenspach, M., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Brews, J., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Galloway, K., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States
Abstract: This paper investigates the role that the gate oxide thickness (TOX) plays on the gate and drain failure threshold voltages required to induce the onset of single-event gate rapture (SEGR). The impact of gate oxide thickness on SEGR is experimentally determined from vertical power metal-oxide semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) having identical process and design parameters, except for the gate oxide thickness. Power MOSFETs from five variants were specially fabricated with nominal gate oxide thicknesses of 30, 50, 70, 100, and 150 nm. Devices from each variant were characterized to mono-energetic ion beams of Nickel, Bromine, Iodine, and Gold. Employing different bias conditions, failure thresholds for the onset of SEGR were determined for each oxide thickness. Applying these experimental test results, the previously published empirical expression [1] is extended to include the effects of gate oxide thickness. In addition, observations of ion angle, temperature, cell geometry, channel conductivity, and curvature at high drain voltages are briefly discussed. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Electric breakdown of solids; Failure (mechanical); Gates (transistor); Mathematical models; Oxides; Radiation effects; Gate oxide thickness; Single event gate rupture (SEGR); Threshold voltage; MOSFET devices

Authors: Allenspach M., Mouret I., Titus J.L., Wheatley C.F., Jr., Pease R.L., Brews J.R., Schrimpf R.D., Galloway K.F.
Title: Single-Event Gate-Rupture in Power MOSFETs: Prediction of Breakdown Biases and Evaluation of Oxide Thickness Dependence
Affiliations: The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Aérospatiale, Les Mureaux, France; Naval Surface Warfare Center – Crane, IN 47522, United States; RR2 Box 1120, Drums, PA 18222, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States

Abstract: Single-Event Gate-Rupture (SEGR) in Vertical Double Diffused Metal-Oxide Semiconductor (VDMOS) power transistors exposed to a given heavy ion LET occurs at a critical gate bias that depends on the applied drain bias. A method of predicting the critical gate bias for non-zero drain biases is presented. The method requires as input the critical gate bias vs. LET for VDS = 0V. The method also predicts SEGR sensitivity to improve for larger gate-oxide thicknesses. All predictions show agreement with experimental test data. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Babcock J.A., Cressler J.D., Vempati L.S., Clark S.D., Jaeger R.C., Harame D.L.
Title: Ionizing Radiation Tolerance of High-Performance SiGe HBT's Grown by UHV/CVD
Affiliations: On educational leave from Motorola Semiconductor Products Sector, ACT and Logic IC Division, Mesa, AZ 85202, United States; Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical Engineering Department, Auburn University, AL 36849, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center US Navy, Crane IN 47522, United States; IBM Microelectronics Division Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States
Authors with affiliations: Babcock, J.A., On educational leave from Motorola Semiconductor Products Sector, ACT and Logic IC Division, Mesa, AZ 85202, United States; Cressler, J.D., Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Electrical Engineering Department, Auburn University, AL 36849, United States; Vempati, L.S.; Clark, S.D., Naval Surface Warfare Center US Navy, Crane IN 47522, United States; Jaeger, R.C.; Harame, D.L., IBM Microelectronics Division Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States
Abstract: The ionizing radiation tolerance of high-performance SiGe HBT's, grown by UHV/CVD and optimized for 77 K, has been investigated for the first time. Results at both 300 K and 77 K indicate that this SiGe technology is inherently radiation tolerant without additional processing steps. Perimeter-to-area analysis show parallel shifts in the collector and base current density for total radiation doses below 1.0 Mrad(Si). Relatively minor degradation in the current gain characteristics is observed for SiGe HBT's exposed to 1.0 Mrad(Si) of Co60 gamma radiation, indicating that the technology is robust for many applications requiring a high degree of ionizing radiation tolerance. 1/f noise measurements made pre- and post-radiation show the appearance of a generation-recombination center in some of the SiGe HBT's after a total-dose exposure to 10.0 Mrad(Si). © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Chemical vapor deposition; Current density; Degradation; Epitaxial growth; Gamma rays; Radiation effects; Semiconducting silicon compounds; Semiconductor growth; Vacuum deposited coatings; Current gain; Ionizing radiation tolerance; Ultra high vacuum (UHV); Heterojunction bipolar transistors

Authors: Schmidt D.M., Fleetwood D.M., Schrimpf R.D., Pease R.L., Graves R.J., Johnson G.H., Galloway K.F., Combs W.E.
Title: Comparison of Ionizing-Radiation-Induced Gain Degradation in Lateral, Substrate, and Vertical PNP BJTs
Affiliations: The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schmidt, D.M., The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Graves, R.J., The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Johnson, G.H., The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Galloway, K.F., The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Combs, W.E., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: A comparison is presented of ionizing-radiation-induced gain degradation in lateral, substrate, and vertical PNPs. The dose-rate dependence of current gain degradation in lateral PNP BJTs is even stronger than the dependence previously reported for NPN BJTs. Various mechanisms are presented and their relative significance for gain degradation in the lateral, substrate, and vertical PNPs is discussed. A detailed comparison of the lateral and substrate PNP devices is given. The specific lateral and substrate devices considered here are fabricated in the same process and possess identical emitters. Even though these devices have identical emitters and undergo the same processing steps, the lateral devices degrade significantly more than the substrate devices. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Failure (mechanical); Integrated circuit testing; Radiation effects; Substrates; Bipolar junction transistors; Gain degradation; Bipolar transistors

Authors: Titus J.L., Gehlhausen M.A., Desko J.C., Jr., Nguyen T.T., Shibib M.A., Hollenbach K.E., Roberts D.J.
Title: Characterization of a Fully Resonant, 1-MHZ, 25-Watt, DC/DC Converter Fabricated in a Rad-Hard BiCMOS/High-Voltage Process
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; AT&T Bell Labs, Allentown, PA 18103, United States; AT&T Bell Labs, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; AT&T Bell Labs, Reading, PA 19603, United States; AT&T Bell Labs, Reading, PA 19603, United States; AT&T Bell Labs, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Gehlhausen, M.A., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Desko, J.C., Jr., AT&T Bell Labs, Allentown, PA 18103, United States; Nguyen, T.T., AT&T Bell Labs, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Shibib, M.A., AT&T Bell Labs, Reading, PA 19603, United States; Hollenbach, K.E., AT&T Bell Labs, Reading, PA 19603, United States; Roberts, D.J., AT&T Bell Labs, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the characterization of a DC/DC converter prototype when its power integrated circuit (PIC) chip is exposed to total dose, dose rate, neutron, and heavy ion environments. This fully resonant, 1-MHZ, 25-Watt, DC/DC converter is composed of a brassboard, populated with input/output filters, isolation transformers, output rectifier, capacitors, resistors, and PIC chip, integrating the primary-side control circuitry, secondary-side control circuitry, power switch, gate-drive circuitry, and voltage references. The brassboard is built using commercial off-the-shelf components; and the PIC chip is fabricated using AT&T's rad-hard, bipolar complementary metal-oxide semiconductor (BiCMOS)/high-voltage process. The intent of this paper is to demonstrate that the PIC chip is fabricated with a radiation-hardened process and to demonstrate that various analog, digital, and power functions can be effectively integrated. © 1995 IEEE

Title: Ionizing Radiation Tolerance and Low—frequency Noise Degradation in UHV/CVD SiGe HBT's
Affiliations: Alabama Microelectronics Science and Technology Center, Department of Electrical Engineering, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849–5201, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane. IN 47522, United States; Harame, D.L., IBM Microelectronics Division, Hopewell Junction, NY 12533, United States
Abstract: The effect of ionizing radiation on both the electrical and 1/f noise characteristics of advanced UHV/CVD SiGe HBT's is reported for the first time. Only minor degradation in the current–voltage characteristics of both SiGe HBT's and Si BJT's is observed after total radiation dose exposure of 2.0 Mrad(Si) of gamma-radiation. The observed immunity to ionizing radiation exposure suggests that these SiGe HBT's are well suited for many applications requiring radiation tolerance. We have also observed the appearance of ionizing-radiation-induced generation-recombination (G/R) noise in some of these SiGe HBT's. © 1995 IEEE

Abstract: Excess collector current in irradiated NPN BJT's is linked to an oxide-trapped-charge-induced inversion layer acting as an additional emitter. Excess collector current is modeled by interpreting the inversion layer as an extension of the emitter. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Kosier S.L., Wei A., Schrimpf R.D., Fleetwood D.M., DeLaus M.D., Pease R.L., Combs W.E.
Title: Physically Based Comparison of Hot-Carrier-Induced and Ionizing-Radiation-Induced Degradation in BJT's
Affiliations: VTC, Inc., Bloomington, MN 55425-1350, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Department 1322, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington. MA 01887, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN 47522-5002, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kosier, S.L., VTC, Inc., Bloomington, MN 55425-1350, United States; Wei, A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Department 1322, Albuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; DeLaus, M.D., Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington. MA 01887, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States; Combs, W.E., Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN 47522-5002, United States
Abstract: A physically based comparison between hot-carrier and ionizing radiation stress in BJT's is presented. Although both types of stress lead to qualitatively similar changes in the current gain of the device, the physical mechanisms responsible for the degradation are quite different. In the case of hot-carrier stress the damage is localized near the emitter-base junction, which causes the excess base current to have an ideality factor of two. For ionizing radiation stress, the damage occurs along all oxide-silicon interfaces, which causes the excess base current to have an ideality factor between one and two for low total doses of ionizing radiation, but an ideality factor of two for large total doses. The different physical mechanisms that apply for each type of stress imply that improvement in resistance to one type of stress does not necessarily imply improvement in resistance to the other type of stress. Based on the physical model, implications for correlating and comparing hot-carrier-induced and ionizing-radiation-induced damage are discussed. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Current voltage characteristics; Gates (transistor); Hot carriers; Ionization of solids; Radiation effects; Semiconductor device models; Semiconductor junctions; Stresses; Bipolar junction transistors; Hot carrier induced degradation; Ionizing radiation induced degradation; Bipolar transistors

Authors: Wei A., Kosier S.L., Schrimpf R.D., Fleetwood D.M., Combs W.E.
Title: Dose-rate effects on radiation-induced bipolar junction transistor gain degradation
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, 1515 Eubank SE, Albuquerque, NM 87123, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Building 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN 47522, United States

Abstract: Analysis of radiation damage in modern NPN bipolar transistors at various dose rates is performed with a recently introduced charge separation method and pisces simulations. The charge separation method is verified with measurements on metal-oxide-semiconductor capacitors. Gain degradation is more pronounced at lower dose rates. The charge separation technique reveals that depletion-region spreading and effective recombination velocity are both greater for devices irradiated at lower dose rates. © 1994 American Institue of Physics.

Authors: Schulte D.P.
Title: Factory to fleet maintenance concept
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522-5001, United States; DPS347%SMTPGAT@CRA-MAIL, NWSCC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schulte, D.P., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522-5001, United States, DPS347%SMTPGAT@CRA-MAIL, NWSCC, United States
Abstract: The recent designation of CASS as part of DoD's standard family of ATS gives us the opportunity to successfully implement the "factory to Fleet" concept [4]. CASS is a tool that can help meet the challenge of cost effective ATS for DoD in the 21st century. The requirement is enhanced maintenance as close to the source as practical. CASS can be a tool to help meet the requirement in a cost effective approach. "Factory to Fleet" testing will not occur on its own. It willrequire detailed planning early in the product life to develop an integrated development/test strategy that allows for factory acceptance testing, TPS development and life cycle support. Testability/diagnostics and life cycle maintenance must be integrated into the design process. Cooperation and communication between the program acquisition requirements and the OEM must be achieved. Successfulimplementation can provide significant marketing advantages both domestically and foreign. © IEEE.
Index Keywords: Acceptance tests; Cost effectiveness; Maintenance; Cost-effective approach; Design process; Detailed planning; Factory acceptance testing; Fleet maintenance; Integrated development; Life Cycle Maintenance; Life Cycle Support; Life cycle

Abstract: In 1992 Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane was tasked to develop a test program for the band 10 sector front end for the Consolidated Automated Support System (CASS) test bench. This paper provides a description of our experience at avionics test development on the CASS. A brief history and description of the CASS is given as background. © IEEE.

Authors: Kosier S.L., Wei A., Schrimpf R.D., Combs W.E., Fleetwood D.M., DeLaus M., Pease R.L.
Title: Bounding the Total-Dose Response of Modern Bipolar Transistors
Affiliations: University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington, MA, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kosier, S.L., University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ, United States; Wei, A., University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., University of Arizona, ECE Department, Tucson, AZ, United States; Combs, W.E., Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane, Crane, IN, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; DeLaus, M., Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington, MA, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: The excess base current in an irradiated BJT increases superlinearly with total dose at low-total-dose levels. In this regime, the excess base current depends on the particular charge-trapping properties of the oxide that covers the emitter base junction. The device response is dose-rate-, irradiation-bias-, and technology-dependent in this regime. However, once a critical amount of charge has accumulated in the oxide, the excess base current saturates at a value that is independent of how the charge accumulated. This saturated excess base current depends on the device layout, bulk lifetime in the base region, and the measurement bias. In addition to providing important insight into the physics of bipolar-transistor total-dose response, these results have significant circuit-level implications. For example, in some circuits, the transistor gain that corresponds to the saturated excess base current is sufficient to allow reliable circuit operation. For cases in which the saturated value of current gain is acceptable, and where other circuit elements permit such over-testing, this can greatly simplify hardness assurance for space applications. © 1994 IEEE
Index Keywords: Charge carriers; CMOS integrated circuits; Computational methods; Electric current control; Electric currents; Gain control; Junction gate field effect transistors; Oxides; Radiation effects; Semiconductor junctions; Base current; Bipolar junction transistors; Charge trapping; Emitter base junction; Bipolar transistors

Authors: Fleetwood D.M., Reber R.A., Jr., Winokur P.S., Kosier S.L., Schrimpf R.D., Wei A., Nowlin R.N., DeLaus M., Combs W.E., Pease R.L.
Title: Physical mechanisms contributing to enhanced bipolar gain degradation at low dose rates
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Alsbuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; University of Arizona, ECE Dept., Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Phillips Laboratory/VTE, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington, MA 01887, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fleetwood, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Alsbuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Reber, R.A., Jr., Sandia National Laboratories, Alsbuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Winokur, P.S., Sandia National Laboratories, Alsbuquerque, NM 87185-1083, United States; Kosier, S.L., University of Arizona, ECE Dept., Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., University of Arizona, ECE Dept., Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Wei, A., University of Arizona, ECE Dept., Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Nowlin, R.N., Phillips Laboratory/VTE, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; DeLaus, M., Analog Devices, Inc., Wilmington, MA 01887, United States; Combs, W.E., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM 87122, United States
Abstract: We have performed capacitance-voltage (C-V) and thermally-stimulated-current (TSC) measurements on non-radiation-hard MOS capacitors simulating screen oxides of modern bipolar technologies. For 0-V irradiation at ~ 25°C, the net trapped-positive-charge density (Nox) inferred from midgap C-V shifts is ~ 25-40% greater for low-dose-rate « 10 rad(SiO2)/S) than for high-dose-rate (> 100 rad(SiO2)/S) exposure. Device modeling shows that such a difference in screen-oxide Nox is enough to account for the enhanced low-rate gain degradation often observed in bipolar devices., due to the 2 ~exp(Nox) dependence of the excess base current. At the higher rates, TSC measurements reveal a ~10% decrease in trapped-hole density over low rates. Also, at high rates, up to ~2.5-times as many trapped holes are compensated by electrons in border traps than at low rates for these devices and irradiation conditions. Both the reduction in trapped-hole density and increased charge compensation reduce the high-rate midgap shift. A physical model is developed which suggests that both effects are caused by time-dependent space charge in the bulk of these soft oxides associated with slowly transporting and/or metastably trapped holes (e. g., in E centers). On the basis of this model, bipolar transistors and screen-oxide capacitors were irradiated at 60°C at 200 rad(SiO2)/s in a successful effort to match low-rate damage. These surprising results provide insight into enhanced low-rate bipolar gain degradation and suggest potentially promising new approaches to bipolar and BiCMOS hardness assurance for space applications. © 1994 IEEE
Index Keywords: Capacitance measurement; Capacitors; Carrier concentration; Charge carriers; Crystal defects; Electric current measurement; Electric space charge; MOS devices; Oxides; Radiation damage; Semiconductor device models; Voltage measurement; Charge trapping; Radiation hardness; Thermally stimulated current measurement; Trapped hole density; Bipolar integrated circuits

Title: Single event effects in analog-to-digital converters: Device performance and system impact

Abstract: Monolithic Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADCs) exhibit a large error rate in the single event effects (SEE) environment. Analysis of data from a high-performance ADC demonstrates the type of errors and their potential impact on system performance. © 1994 IEEE

Authors: Wheatley C.F., Titus J.L., Burton D.I.
Title: Single-Event Gate Rupture in Vertical Power MOSFETs; An Original Empirical Expression
Affiliations: Consultant, RR2 Box 1120, 18222, Drums, PA, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, 47522, Crane, IN, United States; Harris Semiconductor, Crestwood Road 18707, Mountaintop, PA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Wheatley, C.F., Consultant, RR2 Box 1120, 18222, Drums, PA, United States; Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, 300 Highway 361, 47522, Crane, IN, United States; Burton, D.I., Harris Semiconductor, Crestwood Road 18707, Mountaintop, PA., United States
Abstract: For the first time, an empirical expression is derived that describes the susceptibility of a power double-diffused metal-oxide semiconductor (DMOS) field-effect transistor (FET) to single-event gate rupture (SEGR) induced by the interaction of monoenergetic ions with regions of the n-epi, gate oxide, and polysilicon gate. Using this expression, the failure threshold voltages for the gate and drain can be analytically determined for any particular value of energy deposition along the ion's path or more commonly described as the ion's linear energy transfer (LET) function. This paper delineates our research, an in-depth study of vertical power DMOS transistors, having a 50-nm gate oxide and a strong SEGR response, subjected to various monoenergetic ions, representing particular values of LET between 0 and 83 MeV.cm2.mg-1. A description of the devices characterized, the test setup and test methodology employed, the failure threshold voltages measured, and the analysis techniques used are all summarized. Finally, an empirical equation is presented that portrays the locus of SEGR in the {-VGS, VDS} plane for all values of LET. © 1994 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric conductivity of solids; Electric currents; Energy transfer; Failure analysis; Gates (transistor); Ions; Numerical methods; Radiation damage; Semiconducting silicon; Linear energy transfer function; Power MOSFET devices; Single event gate rupture; MOSFET devices

Authors: Lim H.S., Zelter G.R., Smithrick J.J., Hall S.W.
Title: Destructive physical analysis results of Ni/H2 cells cycled in low earth orbit regime (II)
Affiliations: Industrial Electronics Group, Hughes Aircraft Company, Torrance, CA 90505, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lim, H.S., Industrial Electronics Group, Hughes Aircraft Company, Torrance, CA 90505, United States; Zelter, G.R., Industrial Electronics Group, Hughes Aircraft Company, Torrance, CA 90505, United States; Smithrick, J.J., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Hall, S.W., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Six 48-Ah individual pressure vessel Ni/H2 cells containing 26 and 31% KOH electrolytes have been on a low earth orbit cycle-life test. Three cells containing 31% KOH have failed after an average of 6400 cycles while the other three with 26% KOH have cycled for an average of 19 500 cycles. We have carried out post-cycle characterization tests and destructive physical analyses (DPA) of all cells. The DPA included visual inspections, measurements of electrode thickness, scanning electron microscopy, chemical analyses, and measurements of nickel electrode capacity in an electrolyte flooded cell. A gradual decrease of the usable cell capacity at high rate (1.4C) was the failure mode of all cells tested. Decrease of the usable capacity was due to decrease in the utilization of the active material with cycling mainly due to build-up of low rate capacity (residual capacity) and undischargeable active material. Cycle life of one of the cells might have been shortened prematurely due to the breakage of the cell core. Many gradual changes occurred with cycling at a rate which is independent of the KOH concentration. Each of these individual changes are difficult to be attributed to be the direct cause of the utilization decrease. However, an involved interaction of the changes might be responsible for the decrease. © 1994.
Index Keywords: Capacitance measurement; Characterization; Chemical analysis; Composition effects; Electric batteries; Electrodes; Inspection; Materials testing; Nickel compounds; Pressure vessels; Scanning electron microscopy; Thickness measurement; Active materials; Cycling; Destructive physical analysis; Electrolyte flooded cell; Low earth orbit cycle life test; Nickel electrode capacity; Post cycle characterization tests; Electrolytes

Authors: Pease R.L., Clark S.D., Cole P.L., Krieg J.F., Pickel J.C.
Title: Total Dose Response of Transconductance in MOSFETs at Low Temperature
Affiliations: RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; S-Cubed, Mission Viejo, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Clark, S.D., RLP Research, Inc., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Cole, P.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; Krieg, J.F., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; Pickel, J.C., S-Cubed, Mission Viejo, CA, United States
Abstract: N and p channel MOSFETs from four bulk CMOS technologies and two CMOS/SIMOX technologies were characterized for total dose response up to 1 Mrad(SiO2) at temperatures from 10K to 120K. The peak transconductance in the linear region increased in n channel devices and decreased in p channel devices for devices with lightly doped drain (LDD) implants. These changes were much larger as the temperature was decreased and were as much as a factor of 50 in P MOSFETs at 10K. The one technology without LDD showed only a minor change in gm with dose even at 10K. The changes in transconductance are most likely a result of hole trapping in the spacer oxide affecting the series resistance. © 1994 IEEE

Title: Effect of hydrogen on the properties of polycrystalline diamond thin films
Affiliations: Space Power Institute, 231 Leach Center, Auburn University, Auburn, Alabama, 36S49-5320, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Port Hueneme, California, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, Indiana, United States; State University of New York at Buffalo, Amherst, New York, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, Virginia, United States

Abstract: Microwave plasma-assisted chemical vapor deposition has been used to grow undoped and doped diamond on molybdenum and silicon substrates. Current-voltage (I—V) characteristics, secondary electron emission and depth profiles for various elements by secondary ion mass spectrometry of diamond films have been measured before and after annealing in nitrogen gas at 425°C. We have analyzed the films for morphology and chemical nature by scanning electron microscopy and Raman spectroscopy respectively. Hydrogen present in the as-deposited diamond films resulted in a decrease in the electrical resistivity and an increase in secondary electron yield. Furthermore, we have observed an increase in resistivity and decrease in yield on annealing. Comparison of these results is presented in this paper. © 1994, Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved. All rights reserved.

Abstract: The use of integrated ferroelectric capacitors as nonvolatile memory elements in semiconductor memory designs imposes additional electrical performance requirements on the capacitor which are not normally characterized in ferroelectric materials research. This paper will describe those requirements and present a suggested set of testing procedures we have developed for their standardized measurement. The most significant property for memory design is not the oft quoted traditional Sawyer-Tower continuous remanent polarization, but rather pulsed remanent polarization which can be broken down into transient. © 1993, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: Price R.L., Scott T.G., Bauer R.E.
Title: A generic controller
Source title: 1st IEEE Regional Conference on Aerospace Control Systems, AEROCS 1993 - Proceedings
Affiliations: System Engineering Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47552, United States
Authors with affiliations: Price, R.L., System Engineering Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47552, United States; Scott, T.G., System Engineering Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47552, United States; Bauer, R.E., System Engineering Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN  47552, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses the design of a Generic Controller Card Set (GCCS) which conforms to the Muitibus II protocol. The GCCS is designed in Navy Standard Electronic Module (SEM) format "E" and consists of eight "building block" cards (modules) that can be configured into many controller applications. The eight modules are a central Processing unit (CPU) card, controller card, central services module (CSM), analog to digital (A/D) card, digital to analog (D/A) card, discrete input and output (DI/O) card, random access memory (RAM) card, and erasable programmable read only memory (EPROM) card. Each of the cards within the set contain on-line and off-line built-in-test (BIT) to aid in diagnosing faults within the controller application. © 1993 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Program processors; Random access storage; Analog-to-digital; Building blockes; Built in tests; Controller card; Digital to analog; Electronic modules; Input and outputs; Random access memory; Controllers

Title: A Conceptual Model of Single-Event Gate-Rupture in Power MOSFET's
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane Division, Crane, IN, 47522–5060, United States; RR2 Box 1120, Drums, PA, 18222, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brews, J.R., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Allenspach, M., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Galloway, K.F., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Titus, J.L., Naval Surface Warfare Center-Crane Division, Crane, IN, 47522–5060, United States; Wheatley, C.F., RR2 Box 1120, Drums, PA, 18222, United States
Abstract: A physical model of hole-collection following a heavy-ion strike is proposed to explain the development of oxide fields sufficient to cause single-event gate rupture in power MOSFET's. It is found that the size of the maximum field and the time at which it is attained are strongly affected by the hole mobility. © 1993 IEEE

Title: Converting a Bulk Radiation-Hardened BiCMOS Technology into a Dielectrically-Isolated Process

Abstract: Development of a dielectrically-isolated (DI) radiation-hardened BiCMOS process is reported. The process is fabricated on a bonded-wafer silicon-on-insulator (SOI) substrate and employs deep trenches for lateral device isolation. © 1993 IEEE

Title: Single Event Gate Rupture of Power DMOS Transistors
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting, IEDM
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Laboratories, Allentown, PA  18103, United States; AT&T Bell Laboratories, Reading, PA  19603, United States; AT&T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Darwish, M.N., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Allentown, PA  18103, United States; Shibib, M.A., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Reading, PA  19603, United States; Pinto, M.R., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ, United States; Titus, J.L., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN  47522, United States
Abstract: Single Event Gate Rupture (SEGR) failure mechanism in power DMOS transistors is investigated experimentally and via numerical simulations. An increase in surface field at the surface is shown to be capable of causing SEGR. Modified DMOS transistors with thick gate oxide are shown to have consistent higher SEGR Vds threshold. © 1993 IEEE

Authors: Nowlin R.N., Schrimpf R.D., Fleetwood D.M., Pease R.L., Combs W.E.
Title: Hardness-Assurance and Testing Issues for Bipolar/BiCMOS Devices
Affiliations: Department of ECE, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States; RLP Research, Albuquerque, Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States; Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, 87106–4245, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nowlin, R.N., Department of ECE, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Department of ECE, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Fleetwood, D.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States; Pease, R.L., RLP Research, Albuquerque, Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States, Mission Research Corporation, Albuquerque, NM, 87106–4245, United States; Combs, W.E., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Abstract: Different hardness-assurance tests are often required for advanced bipolar devices than for CMOS devices. In this work, the dose-rate dependence of bipolar current-gain degradation is mapped over a wide range of dose rates for the first time, and it is very different from analogous MOSFET curves. Annealing experiments following irradiation show negligible change in base current at room temperature, but significant recovery at temperatures of 100°C and above. In contrast to what is observed in MOSFET’s, irradiation and annealing tests cannot be used to predict the low-dose-rate response of bipolar devices. A comparison of x-ray-induced and 60Co gamma-ray-induced gain degradation is reported for the first time for bipolar transistors. The role of the emitter bias during irradiation is also examined. Implications for hardening and hardness assurance are discussed. © 1993 IEEE
Index Keywords: Annealing; CMOS integrated circuits; Degradation; Dosimetry; Gamma rays; Hardness testing; Ionization; Radiation effects; Radiation hardening; Semiconductor device testing; Bi CMOS devices; Bipolar current gain degradation; Dose rate dependence; Hardness assurance; Irradiation; Bipolar transistors

Authors: Beasley Kevin G.
Title: Composites for thermal management in U.S. Navy's electronic packaging
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Authors with affiliations: Beasley, Kevin G., Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Abstract: The need for more efficient electronic packaging has required the U.S. Navy to investigate improved methods of thermal management. This may be accomplished by increased volume efficiency and improved thermal performance of electronic components that make up a `lectronic system. One of these components is the Standard Electronic Module(SEM). The structural component of these modules is the module frame, which also is the thermal conduction path for passive cooling of the SEM. Composites including aluminum/graphite, copper/graphite, and epoxy/graphite are the primary focus of this investigation. Properties that make these materials attractive for this application are high thermal conductivity of the graphite fibers and the tailorable coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) of the composite material. Weight savings is also a significant feature of these materials for avionics applications. The composite module frame was designed to meet the mechanical, environmental, and thermal performance requirements of the SEM Format E and evaluated in accordance with those requirements. Composite architecture issues for these module frames were also investigated. Other items being considered for composite materials include CTE controlled printed wiring boards and heat spreaders in electronic component packages. Discussion will address the continuing and future work in this area, which includes optimizing the composite architecture of the module frame and future applications of composites for thermal management in electronic packaging.
Index Keywords: Avionics; Composite materials; Copper; Fiber reinforced materials; Graphite fiber reinforced plastics; Graphite fibers; Optimization; Performance; Thermal conductivity; Thermal expansion; Aluminum graphite composites; Copper graphite composites; Environmental performance; Epoxy graphite composites; Mechanical performance; Standard electronic module (SEM); Thermal management (TM); Thermal performance; Electronics packaging

Abstract: tert-Butyldimethylantimony, (t-Bu)Me2Sb, was prepared by a one-pot reaction of SbCl3 with 1 equiv of (t-Bu)MgCl at −50 °C followed by 2 equiv of MeMgBr at 0 °C in diethyl ether. (t-Bu)Me2Sb was isolated in 64% yield (based on SbCl3) after fractional vacuum distillation (63 °C at 30 Torr) and can be used as a precursor in the chemical vapor deposition of antimony-containing semiconductor materials. © 1992, American Chemical Society. Authors: Hill C.A., Matsumoto J.M., Poston T.M., Prater A., Brown H., Hall S., House S.
Title: Air Force nickel hydrogen cell low earth orbit life test-update
Affiliations: Aerospace Corp.; Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division; Phillips Lab.
Authors with affiliations: Hill, C.A., Aerospace Corp.; Matsumoto, J.M., Aerospace Corp.; Poston, T.M., Aerospace Corp.; Prater, A., Aerospace Corp.; Brown, H., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division; Hall, S., Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division; House, S., Phillips Lab.
Abstract: There are currently 132 nickel hydrogen (NiH2) cells on test in a low earth orbit (LEO) regime at the Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division. There are also 10 NiH2 cells in a special pulse test at the Aerospace Corporation. The testing, which is sponsored by the Air Force Phillips Laboratory, began in 1987. The majority of the cells have over four years of real time LEO cycles. The purpose of this paper is to provide a description of the NiH2 low earth orbit life test plan and to present the current status of cells in the test.

Authors: Rodgers P.
Title: US Navy 2M/ATE program: Fleet self-sufficiency, readiness and progressive maintenance
Affiliations: US Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522-5060, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rodgers, P., US Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522-5060, United States
Abstract: The US Navy's 2M/ATE (miniature/microminiature/automatic test equipment) program is intended to provide the fleet with high reliability electronic module test, diagnostic, and miniature/microminiature (2M) repair capabilities. The author covers the program's current status and future directions and plans. The goal is to increase fleet self-sufficiency, readiness, and cost reduction. The 2M/ATE program's repair capabilities and automatic digital/analog testers provide for organizational (O) and intermediate (I) level fault isolation and repair of electronic assemblies. The 2M portion of the program strives to provide the repair capabilities and electronic documentation needed for electronic circuit card assemblies and equipment at the O and I levels. The 2M push is for progressive maintenance which yields self-sufficiency and, thereby, readiness. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Leistner A.J., Thwaite E.G., Lesha F., Bennett J.M.
Title: Polishing study using teflon and pitch laps to produce flat and supersmooth surfaces
Affiliations: Division of Applied Physics, National Measurement Laboratory, Common wealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, P.O. Box, Lindfield, NSW, 2070, Australia; Michelson Laboratory, Naval Weapons Center, CA, 93555, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leistner, A.J., Division of Applied Physics, National Measurement Laboratory, Common wealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, P.O. Box, Lindfield, NSW, 2070, Australia; Thwaite, E.G., Division of Applied Physics, National Measurement Laboratory, Common wealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, P.O. Box, Lindfield, NSW, 2070, Australia; Lesha, F., Division of Applied Physics, National Measurement Laboratory, Common wealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, P.O. Box, Lindfield, NSW, 2070, Australia; Bennett, J.M., Michelson Laboratory, Naval Weapons Center, CA, 93555, United States
Abstract: Teflon polishing is compared with pitch polishing as a method for achieving supersmooth and flat optical surfaces. Because a Teflon lap wears slowly, it will retain its surface shape to produce extremely flat optical surfaces, λ/100, consistently and reliably for extended periods of time, of the order of days. To compare the two methods, we polished 50-mm-diameter samples of various optical materials, using colloidal suspensions in water on both pitch and Teflon laps under the same polishing conditions. Flatness was maintained to better than λ/10, and roughness less than 10 Å rms was measured on all samples by two Talystep surface-profiling instruments, one in the United States and one in Australia, with excellent agreement between measurements made by the two instruments. It was possible to obtain flat and smooth surfaces (<4-Å rms roughness) on all materials (except for F4, flint glass), but only certain combinations of material, abrasive, and lap could be used to give the correct polishing conditions and surface chemistry. © 1992 Optical Society of America.
Author Keywords: Calcium fluoride; Lithium niobate; Magnesium fluoride; Optical fabrication; Optical polishing; Roughness; Silicon; Surfaces; Teflon lap; Zerodur
Funding Details: U.S. Department of Energy, USDOE
Funding Text 1: Ceramic Machining (CECM) Workshop. Oak Ridge, TN: Oak Ridge National Lab; 1991 Nov; ORNL/M-1745. 75 pages. A workshop on Cost Effective Ceramic Machining (CECM) was held at Oak Ridge Associated Universities Pollard Auditorium, Oak Ridge, Tennessee, May 1991. The purpose of this workshop was to present a preliminary project plan for industry critique and to identify specific components and cost-reduction targets for a new project on Cost Effective Ceramic Machining. The CECM project is an extension of the work on the Ceramic Technology for Advanced Heat Engines (CTAHE) Program sponsored by the Department of Energy, Office of Transportation Materials. The workshop consisted of fifteen invited papers, discussions, a survey of the attendee's opinions, and a tour of the High Temperature Materials Laboratory at ORNL. The total number of registrants was sixty-seven, including thirty-three from industry or private sector organizations, seven from universities, three from industry groups, fourteen from DOE laboratories (including ORNL, Y-12, and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory), three from trade associations, and three from other government organizations. Forty-one survey forms, which critiqued the proposed project plan, were completed by attendees, and the results are presented in this report. Valves, cam roller followers, water pump seals, and diesel engine head plates were rated highest fro application of ceramic machining concepts to reduce cost. Coarse grinding, abrasives and wheel technology, and fine grinding were most highly rated as regards their impact on cost reduction. Specific cost-reduction targets for given parts varied greatly in the survey results and were not felt to be useful for the purposes for the CECM plan development. A range of individual comments were obtained and are listed in an appendix. As a result of the workshop and subsequent discussions, a modified project plan, different in certain aspects from the original CECM plan, has been developed.

Title: Trends in the Total-Dose Response of Modern Bipolar Transistors
Affiliations: University of Arizona, Electrical and Computer Engineering, 1230 E. Speedway, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road, SE, Albuquerque, NM 87106-4245, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Building 2087 Code 6054, Crane, IN 47522, United States

Abstract: The primary degradation in modern bipolar transistors that are subjected to ionizing radiation is a reduction in current gain. There are many factors that influence the total-dose response of bipolar transistors, including emitter bias, transistor polarity, emitter technology, emitter geometry, base design, and dose rate. The effects of each of these factors are investigated. Physical mechanisms consistent with the observed effects are described. © 1992 IEEE

Authors: Remer N.A., Nolting J.
Title: Development and manufacture of a large, multi-cell lithium thionyl chloride reserve battery
Source title: Proceedings of the 35th International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Alliant Techsystems Inc., Horsham, PA, United States; Department of the Navy, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522-5011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Remer, N.A., Alliant Techsystems Inc., Horsham, PA, United States; Nolting, J., Department of the Navy, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, IN  47522-5011, United States
Abstract: A high power reserve battery has been developed to provide electrical energy for a family of ocean buoys. Some of the key development and manufacturing features of this program are outlined. The battery weighs approximately 145 lbs and is packaged in the nose of a MK 46 torpedo size store. Electrolyte, stored in a reservoir, is distributed to the 21 cells via a unique manifolding system. Activation is initiated by an explosive squib, and a stored energy system within the reservoir provides motive power. The 21 cells are divided into two sections. Performance requirements include extended operation at 4 kW constant power discharge. Each battery contains a large number of components, and automation has been developed to facilitate manufacture. A continuous coating process is used for the manufacture of cathode stock. Robots are used for the conversion of cathode stock into finished cathodes and for welding electrode tabs to current collectors. A comprehensive system of nonoperating electrical tests is used to determine product operability and safety. These tests include capacitance measurements to assure continuity of the unactivated series stacks and the integrity of the cell/manifold/activation system. © 1992 IEEE.

Title: Observations of secondary electron emission from diamond films
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting, IEDM
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Port Hueneme, CA, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; State University of New York at Buffalo, Amherst, NY, United States; Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane, IN, United States; Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, United States
