Abstract: Secondary electron yields have been measured at NASA Lewis Research Center on diamond and diamond-like-carbon (DLC) films prepared at Auburn University. These results have been obtained as part of a study initiated by the Naval Surface Warfare Center. Secondary yields as high as 27 have been measured for the diamond films; the DLC films have maximum yields near 1.5. Secondary yields from the diamond films decline when they are subjected to continuous electron bombardment, but emission can be restored or enhanced if the surface is annealed in vacuum or exposed to hydrogen gas. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Lewis H.
Title: Materials analysis for nickel-cadmium space cells
Source title: Proceedings of the 35th International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Electrochemical Power Sourcea Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division, Crane, IN  475226030, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, H., Electrochemical Power Sourcea Department, Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane Division, Crane, IN  475226030, United States
Abstract: Three sets of Ni-Cd space cells have been evaluated by destructive physical analysis procedures which involve extensive materials analysis. The author discusses the results of the materials analysis with particular attention to the NASA Goddard procedural process as modified by Crane Division, US Naval Surface Warfare Center, and the discrepancies between theoretical Cd:Ni electron exchange ratios and actual material analysis results on cells at complete discharge. The sets include baseline cells and cells after two shadow periods and five shadow periods of cycling in simulation of a polar low Earth orbit environment. The results of the chemical and physical characterizations are presented in a comparative manner, and the degradative effects on material properties are discussed. © 1992 IEEE.

Abstract: Final results are presented for the spin-spin correlation parameters CSL and CLL for np elastic scattering with a polarized neutron beam incident on a polarized proton target. The beam kinetic energies are 484, 634, and 788 MeV, and the c.m. angular range is 80°-180°. These data will contribute significantly to the determination of the isospin-0 amplitudes in the energy range from 500 to 800 MeV. © 1992 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Pease R.L., Combs W., Clark S.
Title: Long term ionization response of several bicmos vlsic technologies
Affiliations: Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road SE, Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pease, R.L., Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road SE, Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States; Combs, W., Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN, 47522, United States; Clark, S., Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Abstract: BiCMOS is emerging as a strong competitor to CMOS for gate arrays and memories because of its performance advantages for the same feature size. In this paper we examine the long term ionization response of five BiCMOS technologies by characterizing test structures which emphasize the various failure modes of CMOS and bipolar. The primary failure modes are found to be associated with the recessed field oxide isolation; edge leakage in the n channel MOSFETs and buried layer to buried layer leakage in the bipolar. The ionization failure thresholds for worst case bias were in the range of 5–20 Krad(Si) for both failure modes in all five technologies. © 1992 IEEE
Index Keywords: Bipolar transistors; CMOS Integrated circuits; Gates (transistor); MOSFET devices; VLSI circuits; BiCMOS technologies; Radiation effects
Funding Text 1: 'Work funded by Defense Nuclear Agency through Naval Weapons Support Center under contract N00164-87-0010/0028.

Authors: Snow J.M., Usher J.S., Stuckman B.E.
Title: On the effectiveness of the unit sample size for standard control charts: ARL VS. Aurl
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, Indiana, 475225, United States; Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky, 40292, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky, 40292, United States
Authors with affiliations: Snow, J.M., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, Crane, Indiana, 475225, United States; Usher, J.S., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky, 40292, United States; Stuckman, B.E., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky, 40292, United States
Abstract: In this paper we investigate the use of the average unit run length (AURL) as an important measure of the effectiveness of various quality control charting schemes. In particular we focus on its appropriateness for normally distributed processes that tend to produce units (or measurements) at slow rates. In our investigations with the standard Shewhart X̄ and R charts, as well as the CUSUM chart, AURL shows that a sample size of n=1 can yield the fastest means of detecting shifts. Copyright © 1992 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Average run length (ARL); Average unit run length (AURL); Shewhart charts
Index Keywords: Graphic Methods; Average Unit Run Length; Quality Control
References: Montgomery, D.C., (1991) Introduction to Statistical Quality Control, , Wiley, New York; Banks, J., (1989) Principles of Quality Control, , Wiley, New York; Wadsworth, H.M., Stephens, K.S., Godfrey, A.B., (1986) Modern Methods of Quality Control and Improvement, , Wiley, New York; Schilling, E.G., Nelson, P.R., The effect of nonnormality on the control limits of Xmacr; charts (1976) Journal of Quality Technology, 8, pp. 183-188; Duncan, A.J., (1986) Quality Control and Industrial Statistics, , 5th edition, Irwin, Homewood, IL; Champ, C.W., Woodall, W.H., Exact results for Shewhart control charts with supplemental runs rules (1987) Technometrics, 29 (4), pp. 393-399; Pearson, E.S., The probability integral of the range in samples of n observations from a normal population (1941) Biometrika, 32, pp. 301-308

Title: Preparation of Symmetrical Di-1-alkynyl Tellurides and Diynes by Reduction of TeCl4 with 1-Alkynyllithium Reagents

O′Connor, C.J., Chemistry Division, Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, California 93555, United States, Department of Synthetic Organic Chemistry, Debye Research Institute, University of Utrecht, Padualaan 8, 3584 CH Utrecht, Netherlands, Naval Weapons Center, United States
Abstract: Di-1-alkynyl tellurides ((RC≡C)2Te, where R = Me, Et, n-Pr, t-Bu, Me3Si, Ph) have been prepared in 42–69% yields by the reaction of TeCl4 with 4 equiv of the corresponding 1-alkynyllithiumreagents (RC≡CLi). Diynes (RC≡CC≡CR, where R = t-Bu, Me3Si, Ph) were isolated as major byproducts from these reactions. While tetra-1-alkynyltellurium(IV) or other possible organotellurium(IV) intermediates were not isolated, it is proposed that these intermediates decompose by a reductive-elimination pathway to afford (RC≡C)2Te and RC≡CC≡CR. These organotellurium compounds have been characterized by IR and 1H, 13C, and 125Te NMR spectroscopies. © 1992, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Herbert Hall J., Chien J.Y., Kauffman J.M., Litak P.T., Adams J.K., Henry R.A., Hollins R.A.
Title: Syntheses and photophysical properties of some 5(2)‐aryl‐2(5)‐(4‐pyridyl)oxazoles and related oxadiazoles and furans

Abstract: A number of 5‐aryl‐2‐(4‐pyridyl)oxazoles, a 2‐aryl‐5‐(4‐pyridyl)oxazole, the related oxadiazole and furan, several 2‐(4‐pyridyl)cycloalkano[d]oxazoles, and many of their quaternary salts were prepared. No single standard synthesis was effective for preparation of more than a few of the 25 free bases described; methods often unique to a base were employed. Minor variations in structure sometimes produced large differences in absorption and emission wavelengths, as well as in the magnitude of the extinction coefficient. The salts are of interest as laser dyes, scintillation fluors, biological stains, and shifters for luminescent solar concentrators. Copyright © 1992 Journal of Heterocyclic Chemistry

Authors: Crawford Jack, James Rick
Title: Surface mount technology rework and repair
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crawford, Jack, Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States; James, Rick, Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Abstract: The Chief of Naval Operations has implemented a Progressive Depot Level Repair Program in the effort to decrease the cost of ownership and extend the life cycle of sophisticated weapon systems. The Naval Sea System Command Miniature/Microminiature (2M) Electronic Repair Program has the responsibility of validating existing repair capabilities, developing new ones, and deploying them to U.S. Navy Organizational and Intermediate levels of repair. To support this effort, the 2M Program Manager initiated a repair study for electronic assemblies which employ surface mount technology (SMT). The study followed an initial SMT repair study that had been accomplished at Naval Undersea Warfare Engineering Station in 1987. The objective of the study was to evaluate SMT repair processes to determine if implementation would impact on the electronic hardware. Because of the increasing amount of SMT being used in new systems, the ability to accomplish field repairs will significantly affect life cycle costs and operational availability. The study required that suitable test assemblies be designed and fabricated, have components placed on them, and that they be reworked under controlled conditions to assure the integrity of the resultant data. The most significant findings are that all of the evaluated processes can accomplish SMT repairs; however, the processes must be understood and controllable if successful repairs are to be accomplished. No detrimental effects were identified that would preclude deploying these capabilities beyond the depot repair facility.
Index Keywords: Availability; Costs; Printed circuit boards; Printed circuit design; Printed circuit testing; Process control; Reliability; Service life; Surface mount technology; Depot repair facility; Life cycle; Operational availability; Rework; Repair

Authors: Dalton P.J., Hall S.W., Hwang W.C., Malachesky P.A.
Title: Air force nickel-cadmium cell qualification program
Source title: Proceedings of the International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dalton, P.J., US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA; Hall, S.W., US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA; Hwang, W.C., US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA; Malachesky, P.A., US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA
Abstract: A new program has been established by the Air Force to qualify aerospace flight quality nickel-cadmium cells from available manufacturers. The first cells received were from SAFT/France. SAFT/France VOS-A (24 Ah, 40 Ah) and VOS-B (20 Ah) cells have successfully completed acceptance, electrical characterization and special characterization cycle testing (550 cycles). A mechanical problem was observed with the SAFT/France VOS-A 40 Ah external cell terminals. Vibration testing has been performed on the SAFT/France VOS-A and the VOS-B cells. The 24 Ah cells passed the high level vibration. Four 40 Ah cells passed high level vibration. Two 20 Ah cells passed high level vibration. The SAFT/France VOS-A 40 and 24 Ah cells are currently in low earth orbit (LEO) and geosynchronous orbit (GEO) cycling. To date, there have been no failures. No performance anomalies have been observed. LEO and GEO life cycling have continued on the remaining cells in the first test program, the separator qualification program.
Index Keywords: Aerospace Engineering; Aircraft, Military; Vibrations--Testing; Aerospace Flight Qualities; Nickel Cadmium Cells; Electric Batteries

Authors: Hoover J.M., Henry R.A., Lindsay G.A., Lowe-Ma C.K., Nadler M.P., Nee S.M., Seltzer M.D., Stenger-Smith J.D.
Title: Langmuir-Blodgett multilayers of fluorinated, main-chain chromophoric, optically nonlinear polymers
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoover, J.M., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States; Henry, R.A., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States; Lindsay, G.A., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States; Lowe-Ma, C.K., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States; Nadler, M.P., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States; Nee, S.M., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States; Seltzer, M.D., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States; Stenger-Smith, J.D., Naval Weapons Cent, Lake, United States
Abstract: Preliminary results for this work indicate that accordion-like polymers can be appropriately designed and synthesized to produce oriented polymeric monolayers at the air-water interface. These polymer films have a noncentrosymmetric arrangement of molecular dipoles when composed of Y-type or Z-type multilayers. Additionally, these monolayer films are readily transferred to solid substrates to form multilayered macromolecular assemblies for subsequent characterization.

Authors: Enlow E.W., Pease R.L.
Title: Response of advanced bipolar processes to ionizing radiation
Affiliations: Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road SE, Albuquerque, NM 87106, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN 47522, United States; University of Arizona, Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Bldg. 104, Room 230, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Enlow, E.W., Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road SE, Albuquerque, NM 87106, United States, Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN 47522, United States, University of Arizona, Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Bldg. 104, Room 230, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Pease, R.L., Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road SE, Albuquerque, NM 87106, United States, University of Arizona, Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Bldg. 104, Room 230, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: Ionizing radiation induced gain degradation in microcircuit bipolar polysilicon and crystalline emitter transistors is investigated. In this work, 60Co irradiation testing was performed on bipolar test structures. The effects of collector bias, dose rate, and anneal temperature are discussed. Major differences in the radiation response of polysilicon emitter transistors are demonstrated as a function of dose rate. The worst-case gain degradation occurs at the lowest dose rate complicating hardness assurance testing procedures. The dose rate and anneal data suggest that MIL-STD-883B Test Method 1019.4 is non-conservative for polysilicon emitter transistors, which show enhanced radiation hardness over the crystalline emitter transistors. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Crystals; Electronic Circuits; Semiconducting Silicon; Ionizing Radiation; Polysilicon; Transistors, Bipolar

Authors: Schrimpf R.D., Galloway K.F.
Title: Effects of Ionizing Radiation on the Noise Properties of DMOS Power Transistors
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Motorola Semiconductor Products Sector, Mesa, AZ 85202, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schrimpf, R.D., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States, Motorola Semiconductor Products Sector, Mesa, AZ 85202, United States, Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Galloway, K.F., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: The 1/f noise properties of DMOS (double-diffused MOS) power transistors were examined as a function of total ionizing dose. The results indicate that radiation causes significant changes in the frequency dependence of the noise of the power MOSFETs studied. Before exposure to radiation, the noise power spectral density indicated a 1/fλ relationship where λ ranged from approximately 0.5 to 1.0. As the total dose level increased, λ approached unity, while the magnitude of the noise increased proportionally with the radiation-induced charge density. In addition, noise measurements were performed after irradiation, while the devices were annealing under a ±12 V bias. It was found that, under the +12 V bias, λ increased and under the −12 V bias, λ decreased. Finally, no correlation was found between the pre-irradiation 1/f noise magnitude and the radiation hardness of these DMOS power transistors. © 1991 IEEE

Authors: Titus J.L., Schrimpf R.D., Galloway K.F.
Title: Single-event burnout of power bipolar junction transistors
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522-5060, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522-5060, United States, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Schrimpf, R.D., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Galloway, K.F., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: Experimental evidence of single-event burnout of power bipolar junction transistors (BJTs) is reported for the first time. Several commercial power BJTs were characterized in a simulated cosmic ray environment using mono-energetic ions at the tandem Van de Graaff accelerator facility at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Most of the device types exposed to this simulated environment exhibited burnout behavior. The experimental technique, data, and results are presented, while a qualitative model is used to help explain those results and trends observed in this experiment. © 1991 IEEE
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Cosmic Rays; Transistors--Junctions; Single Event Burnout; Transistors, Bipolar

Authors: Ricks Douglas W., Ajmera Ramesh
Title: Light scattering from binary optics
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Cent., China Lake, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ricks, Douglas W., Naval Weapons Cent., China Lake, CA,, USA; Ajmera, Ramesh, Naval Weapons Cent., China Lake, CA,, USA
Abstract: We have calculated the angle-resolved scattering from several phase only Fresnel zone plates (lenses) and Dammann gratings (beam splitters). We simulate manufacturing errors by random perturbations of the surface-relief pattern, and calculate the irradiance in the far-field by evaluating the Fresnel diffraction integral. Scattering from perturbations of the etch depth is found to be proportional to the square of the ratio of the perturbation divided by the wavelength. Random perturbations of the pattern edges in Fresnel zone plates causes more scattering with shorter wavelengths than with longer wavelengths, but in Dammann gratings this scattering is independent of wavelength. Scattering increases for either small apertures or small f-numbers; but does not depend on either the number of levels in a Fresnel zone plate, the pattern in a Dammann grating, or the form of the probability distribution function.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Lenses; Light - Scattering; Optical Devices - Fabrication; Probability; Angle-Resolved Scattering; Binary Optics; Dammann Gratings; Fabrication Errors Simulation; Fresnel Zone Plates; Random Perturbations; Optical gratings

Authors: Crawford John A.
Title: Is SMT repair the impossible mission
Source title: National Electronic Packaging and Production Conference-Proceedings of the Technical Program (West and East)
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crawford, John A., Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Navy Miniature/Microminiature Electronic Repair Program (2M) provides equipment, tools and training to enable field activities to accomplish the repair or rework of deployed electronic systems. The 2M program supports the Chief of Naval Operations' Progressive Depot Level Repair (PDLR) directive which mandates repairs be accomplished at the lowest echelon practical. Electronic circuit card assemblies (CCAs) are becoming more complex in both functional and mechanical design. Naval Weapons Support Center Crane (NWSCC) has conducted a study to evaluate SMT repair processes. The results of the study will assist program managers and users in determining whether a repair or rework action is feasible. The study showed that the process can impact reliability. To reduce the reliability impact, rework factors which can have a negative effect must be identified and controlled. Examples of these factors are: component to component spacing, component lead spacing, clearance between the component and the CCA, cleaning, component lead pretinning, solder application, heat application parameters, and the effects of multiple heat cycles on solder joint integrity.
Index Keywords: Electronic Circuits; Electronic Equipment - Military Applications; SMT Repair; US Navy; Electronics Packaging

Authors: Hoffer Kip O.
Title: Solderability testing of Cu6Sn5 intermetallic
Source title: National Electronic Packaging and Production Conference-Proceedings of the Technical Program (West and East)
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoffer, Kip O., Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, United States
Abstract: Poor component and printed wiring board (PWB) solderability have been cited as a major problem of the military electronics assembly industry. A recent industry study hypothesized that sub-surface oxidation may correlate to solderability degradation. The 'layer' of material immediately below the tin/lead solder surface layer in most solder joints is a Cu6Sn5 intermetallic. The growth of this intermetallic and a Cu3Sn intermetallic (during long-term component storage) depletes the tin available in the solder coating, leaving a thin, porous layer of lead-rich material to protect the solderable intermetallics from oxidation. Hence, additional knowledge about the solderability of the Cu6Sn5 intermetallic is valuable for determining maximum allowable storage times for components while still maintaining a high degree of solderability. In this investigation, solderability of the Cu6Sn5 intermetallic, relative to normal and elevated temperature aging conditions, was determined using a solder area-of-spread test. The results show that oxides quickly form on the intermetallic which render it unsolderable without flux within 1.5 minutes of sample preparation. The oxides, formed at temperatures up to 110°C for up to 1000 hours, can be removed by using a type 'RMA' flux during the soldering operation, which results in solder wetting angles from 2.5° to 5.1°.

Abstract: Laser soldering of leadless devices is an issue that has not received a great deal of attention. This study will attempt to determine some of the values for the critical parameters of laser soldering. Although these parameters will be evaluated using an ILS-7210 Laser Soldering Workstation produced by Vanzetti Systems, the parameters considered are expected to be general concerns for laser soldering of leadless chip carriers onto ceramic substrates regardless of the equipment used.

Authors: Dalton Penni, Goliaszewski Laura
Title: Nickel-cadmium battery evaluation for Navy navigational satellites
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dalton, Penni, US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA; Goliaszewski, Laura, US Naval Weapons Support Center,, Crane, IN, USA
Abstract: There are no significant differences in electrical performance to date between Pellon 2505ML and Pellon 2536 separator material cell lots. Any differences observed at this time are considered minor and within acceptable limits. Following the completion of shadow season three, no cells have failed the test. These cells have been on test for one and a half years. Continued cycling will provide a comparison of performance characteristics of aerospace-qualified Pellon 2505ML separator cells with nonqualified Pellon 2536 separator cells. Under this benign type of simulated orbit, both types of cells will probably exhibit very slow degradation. It is intended that this program will demonstrate that any physical and chemical degradation due to design and separator changes in Pellon 2536 cells is slow enough that Pellon 2536 cells can perform successfully in the US Navy navigational spacecraft missions.

Title: Relaxation of ordered side chains near the glass-rubber transition temperature
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lindsay, G., Naval Weapons Cent, United States; Hoover, J., Naval Weapons Cent, United States; Knoesen, A., Naval Weapons Cent, United States; Mortazavi, M., Naval Weapons Cent, United States; Kowel, S., Naval Weapons Cent, United States
Abstract: In the course of the studies of nonlinear optical polymers (NLOP) in which the sidechain is a chromophore containing a large dipole moment, the authors have observed that the decay of second harmonic (SH) signal near the Tg may offer a new analytical tool for better understanding the three-dimensional molecular structure of the matrix below and near the Tg in amorphous polymers. The authors show here that the relaxation behavior of poled nonlinear optical films might be explained by the presence and absence of nanovoids or (local free volume) near the aligned chromophores.

Authors: Talukder M.A.H.
Title: Ring-opening polymerization of oxetanes by cationic initiators. Polymerization of azidomethylmethyloxetane with bis(chlorodimethylsilyl) benzene/silver hexafluoroantimonate initiating system
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Talukder, M.A.H., Naval Weapons Cent, United States
Abstract: Quasi-living cationic polymerization of AMMO was achieved with a BSB/AgSbF6 initiating system in methylene chloride at -78°C. The difunctional initiator was activated from both ends of the initiator during polymerization. The average molecular weight (Mn) increased linearly with an increasing monomer/initiator ([M]/[I]) ratio and a linear Mn vs. [M]/[I] ratio plot passes through the origin. Mn's observed were higher than the calculated values. The discrepancy may be due to the loss of the initiator, or slow initiation, or the combination of both. A limited study shows that the polymerization of oxetane monomers with a difunctional initiating system is fast.

Authors: Mansfield F.A., Burggraf O.R.
Title: Numerical investigation of laminar separated viscous trailing-edge flow using triple-deck theory
Source title: Flight Simulation Technologies Conference and Exhibit, 1990
Affiliations: Aerodynamics Branch, Code 3592, Naval Weapons Center, Mississippi State University, China LakeCA, United States; Dept. of Aero/Astro Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mansfield, F.A., Aerodynamics Branch, Code 3592, Naval Weapons Center, Mississippi State University, China LakeCA, United States; Burggraf, O.R., Dept. of Aero/Astro Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States
Abstract: A efficient time-marching numerical algorithm has been developed for solving the triple-deck problem for supersonic laminar separated trailing-edge flows. The accuracy of the numerical method is tested for the case of a flat plate at angle of incidence a below stall. A range of numerical solutions are then presented for angle of incidence beyond stall in the form of streamline and shear contour plots. Some numerical difficulties for α>2.7 were encountered. © 1990 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: McKenney R.L., Jr., Struck S.R., Ellison D.S.
Title: Deuterium isotope effects during the thermal decomposition of 1, 4-butanediammonium dinitrate and selected composites with ammonium and potassium nitrates
Affiliations: Air Force Armament Laboratory AFATL/MNE Eglin AFB, FL, 32542-5434, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center Explosives Sciences Branch (Code 3025), Crane, IN, 45722-5030, United States
Authors with affiliations: McKenney, R.L., Jr., Air Force Armament Laboratory AFATL/MNE Eglin AFB, FL, 32542-5434, United States, Naval Weapons Support Center Explosives Sciences Branch (Code 3025), Crane, IN, 45722-5030, United States; Struck, S.R., Air Force Armament Laboratory AFATL/MNE Eglin AFB, FL, 32542-5434, United States, Naval Weapons Support Center Explosives Sciences Branch (Code 3025), Crane, IN, 45722-5030, United States; Ellison, D.S., Air Force Armament Laboratory AFATL/MNE Eglin AFB, FL, 32542-5434, United States
Abstract: The thermal decomposition of 1, 4-butanediammonium dinitrate (BDD), selected BDD-based composites with ammonium/potassium nitrates (BAK), and specifically deuterated analogs, was investigated. A previous study showed that molten BDD decomposes thermally via a multistep process that produces a variety of condensed phase and gaseous products. The nature of the products suggested that proton transfer from cation to anion followed by C-N bond rupture occurred early in the decomposition process. During the present investigation condensed phase DSC induction period studies performed using specifically deuterated BDD analogs generally displayed inverse deuterium isotope effects. Impact sensitivities, times to explosion and critical temperatures were also determined for BDD, the BAK composites, and many of their N-deuterated analogs. While these studies did not unequivocally reveal the specific covalent bond rupture responsible for generating the conditions favorable for exothermic decomposition, they did provide a direct relationship between induction period chemistry and macroscopic thermal sensitivity properties. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Caldwell N.J., Rice J.K., Nelson H.H., Adams G.F., Page M.
Title: Theoretical and experimental investigation of the reaction BH+D 2→BHD2
Affiliations: Chemistry Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Ballistic Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD 21005, United States; Laboratory for Computational Physics and Fluid Dynamics, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, National Research Council; Ordnance Engineering Department, Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Caldwell, N.J., Chemistry Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States, Naval Research Laboratory, National Research Council, Ordnance Engineering Department, Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, United States; Rice, J.K., Chemistry Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Nelson, H.H., Chemistry Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Adams, G.F., Ballistic Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD 21005, United States; Page, M., Laboratory for Computational Physics and Fluid Dynamics, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States
Abstract: The rate of the association reaction, BH + D2→BHD 2 is determined both theoretically and experimentally. In the theoretical calculations, potential-energy surface information is obtained using multiconfiguration self-consistent-field and large-scale multireference configuration-interaction calculations with large correlation consistent basis sets. The preferred direction of approach is found to be along a non-least-motion pathway for which the BH and DD bonds come in nearly parallel to one another. The small computed activation energy of 2.6 kcal/mol for this highly exothermic reaction is found to arise almost exclusively from changes in zero-point vibrational energy. The experimental measurements of the BH disappearance rate are made at temperatures from 298 to 597 K and are shown to be only weakly dependent on total pressure over the range of 1-100 Torr. As a test of the proposed mechanism, we observe the growth of BD and find the BD appearance rate constant to be in excellent agreement with that for BH disappearance. The measured reaction rates are compared to the results of canonical variational transition-state theory calculations of the association rate and are found to be in excellent agreement. © 1990 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Nielsen A.T., Nissan R.A., Vanderah D.J., Coon C.L., Gilardi R.D., George C.F., Flippen-Anderson J.
Title: Polyazapolycyclics by Condensation of Aldehydes with Amines. 2. Formation of 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12-Hexabenzyl-2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12-hexaaza-tetracyclo[5.5.0.05.9.03, 11]dodecanes from Glyoxal and Benzylamines
Affiliations: Chemistry Division, Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, California 93555-6001, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, California 94550, United States; Laboratory for the Structure of Matter, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375-5000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nielsen, A.T., Chemistry Division, Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, California 93555-6001, United States; Nissan, R.A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, California 94550, United States; Vanderah, D.J., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, California 94550, United States; Coon, C.L., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, California 94550, United States; Gilardi, R.D., Laboratory for the Structure of Matter, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375-5000, United States; George, C.F., Laboratory for the Structure of Matter, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375-5000, United States; Flippen-Anderson, J., Laboratory for the Structure of Matter, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. 20375-5000, United States
Abstract: The condensation of glyoxal with benzylamine leads to 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12-hexabenzyl-2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12-tetraazatetra-cyclo[5.5.0.05.9.03, 11]dodecane (2a) in solvents such as acetonitrile or methanol with formic acid catalyst. Six phenyl-substituted derivatives of 2a have been prepared and the scope of the reaction has been examined. Intermediates l, 2,-bis(benzylamino)-l, 2-ethanediol (6) and N, N’-dibenzyl-1, 2-ethanediimine (7) have been prepared and the mechanism of their conversion to 2a is discussed. In the absence of acid catalysts, the glyoxal hemiacetal derivative 2, 3-dihydroxyl, 4-dioxane reacts with benzylamine or 4-pyridylmethylamine in acetonitrile solvent to produce 9, 10-bis(arylmethyl)-9, 10-diaza-l, 4, 5, 8-tetraoxaperhydroanthracenes 13a, b. © 1990, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Turflinger T.L., Davey M.V.
Title: Understanding single event phenomena in complex analog and digital integrated circuits
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turflinger, T.L., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States; Davey, M.V., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Single Event Phenomena (SEP) response of complex analog and digital integrated circuits (IC's) cannot be characterized using common (i.e., memory) techniques. A technique for such characterization is developed and discussed. The technique is used to analyze SEP response of an Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC). © 1990 IEEE

Authors: Desko J.C., Jr., Darwish M.N., Dolly M.C., Goodwin C.A., Dawes W.R., Jr., Titus J.L.
Title: Radiation hardening of a high voltage IC technology (BCDMOS)
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Laboratories, Reading, PA 19603, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Desko, J.C., Jr., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Reading, PA 19603, United States; Darwish, M.N., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Reading, PA 19603, United States; Dolly, M.C., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Reading, PA 19603, United States; Goodwin, C.A., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Reading, PA 19603, United States; Dawes, W.R., Jr., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Titus, J.L., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: A program was undertaken to radiation harden AT&T's existing power integrated circuit technology (BCDMOS) to total dose, gamma dot, SEU, and neutrons. Efforts have centered around hardening and optimizing our CMOS, DMOS, and NPN devices. Initial results indicate a substantial improvement in hardness over our existing commercial technology. © 1990 IEEE

Authors: Gutmark E., Schadow K.C., Bicker C.J.
Title: Near acoustic field and shock structure of rectangular supersonic jets
Affiliations: Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, 93555, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gutmark, E., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, 93555, United States; Schadow, K.C., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, 93555, United States; Bicker, C.J., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, 93555, United States
Abstract: An underexpanded supersonic rectangular jet is studied experimentally at a pressure ratio range of 1-15. The shock-cell and shear-layer structure variation with the pressure ratio is shown to be related to the near-field pressure fluctuations. Near the sonic, fully adapted velocity, the jet is fully symmetric. An abrupt change to a flapping mode occurs at a low Mach number, causing a large increase in the spreading rate, which is also related to the appearance of an upstream propagating screech component. This behavior is observed at the minor axis plane, whereas the other plane remains symmetric. As the pressure ratio is further increased, the jet growth is decreased concurrently with the reduction of the upstream propagating pressure component. At the same time, the broadband near-field pressure fluctuations are enhanced. At the highest pressure ratio measured, the jet becomes quasisymmetric, with a dominant helical screech tone and a very large spreading rate at both axis planes. © 1990 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Acoustics; Computers, Microcomputer; Mixing; Photography - Schlieren System; Mach Number; Rectangular Supersonic Jets; Shock-Cell Structure; Spark Schlieren Photography; Flow of Fluids

Authors: Gutmark E., Hanson-Parr D.M., Parr T.P., Schadow K.C.
Title: Fractal behavior of a wrinkled annular diffusion flame
Affiliations: Research Department (Code 3892), Naval Weapons Center, China Lane, CA 93555-6001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gutmark, E., Research Department (Code 3892), Naval Weapons Center, China Lane, CA 93555-6001, United States; Hanson-Parr, D.M., Research Department (Code 3892), Naval Weapons Center, China Lane, CA 93555-6001, United States; Parr, T.P., Research Department (Code 3892), Naval Weapons Center, China Lane, CA 93555-6001, United States; Schadow, K.C., Research Department (Code 3892), Naval Weapons Center, China Lane, CA 93555-6001, United States
Abstract: Fractal geometry is used to describe quantitatively the random character of a turbulent wrinkled diffusion flame. The article describes how basic ideas of mathematics of fractals can be applied to study the changes in the irregularity of the flame's surface at various axial positions. In the present work, the Planar Laser-Induced Fluorescence (PLIF) imaging technique has been used to map the hydroxyl concentration in an annular diffusion flame with propane fuel. The short pulse duration (18 ns) of the laser sheet enabled instantaneous pictures of the flame structure to be obtained with high spatial resolution of 0.5 × 0.5 × 0.5 mm. The isopleths of concentration were highly wrinkled and random in character, both in space and time. They were measured in flames that were forced at different instability frequencies, in order to stabilize the roll-up of the vortices in the flame shear layer and to simulate vortex merging. Measurements were done from the flameholder to the flame's end at many axial positions, in order to study the evolution of the flame structure. The fractal dimension was calculated for all these conditions, using two methods: the Kolmogorov-Hansdorff definition and the perimeter area relation. The fractal dimension of this flame was found to be in the range of 1.03-1.1, depending on the axial location. A verified convergence of the fractal dimension to a constant value is critical to reduce the scatter in its value in different sets of experiment. © 1990.

Authors: McKenney R.L., Jr., Struck S.R., Ellison D.S., Maegerlein S.D.
Title: An investigation of the thermal decomposition of 1, 4-butanediammonium dinitrate
Affiliations: Air Force Armament Laboratory AFATL, FL, 32542-5434, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center Explosives Sciences Branch (Code 3025), Department of Chemistry, Crane, IN, 45722-5030, United States
Authors with affiliations: McKenney, R.L., Jr., Air Force Armament Laboratory AFATL, FL, 32542-5434, United States; Struck, S.R., Air Force Armament Laboratory AFATL, FL, 32542-5434, United States; Ellison, D.S., Naval Weapons Support Center Explosives Sciences Branch (Code 3025), Department of Chemistry, Crane, IN, 45722-5030, United States; Maegerlein, S.D., Naval Weapons Support Center Explosives Sciences Branch (Code 3025), Department of Chemistry, Crane, IN, 45722-5030, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the investigation of the thermal decomposition of 1, 4-butanediammonium dinitrate (BDD). Analytical techniques used for this work were differential scanning and accelerating rate calorimetry, thermogravimetry, tandem gas chromatography/mass spectrometry and high performance liquid chromatography. It was shown that BDD decomposes thermally from the molten state via a multistep process that produces a variety of condensed phase and gaseous products. The nature of the products suggest that a proton transfer reaction from cation to anion followed by C-N bond rupture occurs early in the decomposition process. The presence of early heterocyclic reaction products demonstrates that one of the reaction mechanisms involves cycloelimination. Later reactions appear to be competitive and may proceed through transient, primary nitramine and nitrosamine species. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Lowe-Ma C.K., Nissan R.A., Wilson W.S.
Title: Tetrazolo[1,5-a] Pyridines and Furazano[4,5-b] Pyridine 1-Oxides
Affiliations: Chemistry Division, Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, California 93555, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lowe-Ma, C.K., Chemistry Division, Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, California 93555, United States; Nissan, R.A., Chemistry Division, Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, California 93555, United States; Wilson, W.S., Chemistry Division, Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, California 93555, United States
Abstract: Tetrazolo[l,5-α]pyridines may be prepared by the reaction of azide ion with 2-chloropyridines. These tetrazolo[l,5-α]pyridines are shown to be in equilibrium with the corresponding 2-azidopyridines. Furazano[4,5-6]pyridine 1-oxides may be prepared by thermolysis of the appropriate 4-nitrotetrazolo[l,2-α]pyridines, presumably via the corresponding 2-azido-3-nitropyridines. The furazano[4,5-b] pyridine 1-oxides are found to be in equilibrium with the 3-oxides. 1H and 13C NMR are used to examine this equilibrium. © 1990, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Monastero F.C., Shepherd C.A., Bjornstad S.C., Katzenstein A.M.
Title: Potential and U.S. Navy plans to develop geothermal resources at Naval Air Station, Fallon, Nevada
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Monastero, F.C., Naval Weapons Cent, United States; Shepherd, C.A., Naval Weapons Cent, United States; Bjornstad, S.C., Naval Weapons Cent, United States; Katzenstein, A.M., Naval Weapons Cent, United States
Abstract: In 1980 the U.S. Navy Geothermal Program Office initiated field studies to ascertain the geothermal potential of the Naval Air Station located at Fallon, Nevada. The studies included thermal gradient drilling, aeromagnetics, gravity, land magnetics, coring and deep observation holes. Results of those studies indicate that there is a relatively shallow (5,000 ft.) depth to the 400 degree isotherm under the southeast portion of the Mainside facilities with temperature gradients in the range of 5 to 7 degrees Fahrenheit per 100 feet. Results of Na-K-Ca geothermometry studies show that maximum temperatures that can be anticipated at NAS-Fallon are in the range of 369°F to 399°F.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources--Nevada; Geology--Nevada; Aeromagnetics; Geothermometry; Land Magnetics; Thermal Gradient Drilling; Geothermal Wells

Authors: Haag R.L., Hall S.W., Francis R.W., Hwang W.C.
Title: Joint Air Force/Navy separator qualification program
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Haag, R.L., US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA; Hall, S.W., US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA; Francis, R.W., US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA; Hwang, W.C., US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA
Abstract: The joint Air Force/Navy separator qualification program was established in order to qualify a new material, Pellon 2536, for use in flight-quality spacecraft nickel-cadmium cells manufactured by Gates Energy Products (GEP). The methodology of the test program was to evaluate comparatively the performance characteristics of cells manufactured using the 2536 material and those of cells manufactured using 2505 ML material. Early in the test program, performance anomalies, in particular, cell voltage divergence, began to appear in several battery packs undergoing low Earth orbit (LEO) cycling. The data obtained from this test program do not support the use of Pellon 2536 separator in current GEP nickel-cadmium spacecraft cells under these LEO test conditions. Separator dry-out was a major factor in the anomalous performance of the cells containing the 2536 material. Cells containing Pellon 2505 ML separator displayed similar performance characteristics to those of the 2536 separator cells, but generally later in life. Some of these failures were attributed to at least one roll of deficient separator material. However, failures also occurred in cells containing 2505 ML separator which did not contain any of the deficient material identified to date. This indicates that other performance factors may be involved. Geostationary orbit test results are presented.
Index Keywords: Satellites--Power Supply; Separators--Military Application; Air Force/Navy Separator Qualification Program; Geostationary Orbit; Low Earth Orbit (LEO) Cycling; Nickel-Cadmium Cells; Pellon 2536; Separator Dry-Out; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Schadow K.C., Gutmark E., Parr T.P., Parr D.M., Wilson K.J., Crump J.E.
Title: Large-scale coherent structures as drivers of combustion instability
Affiliations: Research Department., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA, 93555-x2013;6001., United States
Authors with affiliations: Schadow, K.C., Research Department., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA, 93555-x2013;6001., United States; Gutmark, E., Research Department., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA, 93555-x2013;6001., United States; Parr, T.P., Research Department., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA, 93555-x2013;6001., United States; Parr, D.M., Research Department., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA, 93555-x2013;6001., United States; Wilson, K.J., Research Department., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA, 93555-x2013;6001., United States; Crump, J.E., Research Department., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA, 93555-x2013;6001., United States
Abstract: The role of flow coherent structures as drivers of combustion instabilities in a dump combustor was studied. Results of nonreacting tests in air and water flows as well as combustion experiments in a diffusion flame and dump combustor are discussed to provide insight into the generation process of large-scale structures in the combustor flow and their interaction with the combustion process. It is shown that the flow structures, or vortices, are formed by interaction between the flow instabilities and the chamber acoustic resonance. When these vortices dominate the reacting flow, the combustion is confined initially to the circumference of their cores and further downstream proceeds into their core, leading to periodic heat release, which may result in the driving of high amplitude pressure oscillations. These oscillations are typical to the occurrence of combustion instabilities for certain operating conditions. The basic understanding of the interaction between flow dynamics and the combustion process opens up the possibility for rational control of combustion-induced pressure oscillations. © 1989, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: Schadow K.C., Gutmark E., Wilson K.J.
Title: Passive mixing control in supersonic coaxial jets at different convective mach numbers
Affiliations: Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China LakeCA  93555-6001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schadow, K.C., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China LakeCA  93555-6001, United States; Gutmark, E., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China LakeCA  93555-6001, United States; Wilson, K.J., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China LakeCA  93555-6001, United States
Abstract: The mixing between two supersonic coaxial jets was studied experimentally. The center jet had a fully-expanded Mach number of 3, and the outer jet of M = 1.8. The geometries of the center jet were circular and rectangular with two configurations, both with a 3:1 aspect-ratio. The convective Mach numbers were varied in the range between 0.25 < Mc < 2.25. This was accomplished by varying the density ratio between the center jet and the coaxial jet, as well as the velocity ratio. The experimental compressible spreading rate was determined using Schlieren photography and total-pressure measurements. The spreading rate of the center circular jet decreased with increasing convective Mach number until it reached a constant value of 0.2 to 0.3 of the incompressible spreading rate for Mc > 1.4. The center rectangular jets had a similar behavior, but they showed superior mixing characteristics relative to the circular jet, which prevailed in the entire convective Mach number range studied. © 1989, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.

Authors: Gutmark E., Parr T.P., Hanson-Parr M.D., Schadow K.C.
Title: On the role of large and small-scale structures in combustion control
Affiliations: Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA 935556001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gutmark, E., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA 935556001, United States; Parr, T.P., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA 935556001, United States; Hanson-Parr, M.D., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA 935556001, United States; Schadow, K.C., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake., CA 935556001, United States
Abstract: Experiments were performed to actively control combustion between coaxial air and fuel jets. The objective was to initiate the combustion as close as possible to the flameholder surface and to maintain uniform combustion in the entire mixing region. Forcing was applied to both the air and fuel streams, at different frequencies and amplitudes. The air jet was excited at its preferred mode frequency while the fuel was forced at higher harmonics in order to trigger and amplify the initial instabilities of the coaxial jet. Nonreacting tests showed that the combined forcing was promoting an earlier transition to small-scale turbulence at the nozzle's exit. Consequently, the combustion was enhanced and became uniformly distributed along the flame, contrary to the reference unforced flame where intense combustion started only at a distance from the flameholder and was limited to the region where vortical structures developed. The optimal combination of forcing parameters are presented and discussed. © 1989, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: Titus J.L., Jamiolkowski L.S., Wheatley C.F.
Title: Development of cosmic ray hardened power MOSFET's
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Center, Advanced Technology Division, Building 2087, Code 60541, Crane, IN, 47522-5060, United States; Harris Semiconductor, 125 Crestwood Road, Mountaintop, PA 18707-2189, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Weapons Support Center, Advanced Technology Division, Building 2087, Code 60541, Crane, IN, 47522-5060, United States; Jamiolkowski, L.S., Harris Semiconductor, 125 Crestwood Road, Mountaintop, PA 18707-2189, United States; Wheatley, C.F., Harris Semiconductor, 125 Crestwood Road, Mountaintop, PA 18707-2189, United States
Abstract: Developmental power DMOS (Double-diffused Metal-Oxide Semiconductor) FET's (Field Effect Transistors) were thoroughly characterized in a simulated cosmic ray environment using heavy ions at the Brookhaven National Laboratory's tandem Van de Graaff accelerator facility. The primary failure mode encountered on FET's in this environment was susceptibility to single event burnout. Burnout of the power DMOS FET was catastrophic. Another failure mode was single event gate rupture. Although gate rupture is not as severe as burnout, its long-term effects are not known. Single event gate rupture causes performance degradation due to increased gate leakage current. An increase in current can pose serious problems to applications that cannot compensate for the added performance degradation. Long-term reliability of the gate oxide may be affected resulting in premature device failure. Each failure mode will be discussed. Numerous processing lots were fabricated to experimentally verify that each failure mode could be successfully minimized. Test results have shown that an n-channel, 150-volt DMOS FET was fabricated that survived exposures to ions with LET's up to 80 MeV-cm2/mg. Finally, hardening approaches will be discussed, including the advantages and disadvantages of each approach on the FET's performance. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Cosmic Rays; Ion Beams; DMOS (Double Diffused Metal Oxide Semiconductor) Devices; Single Event Upsets; Semiconductor Devices, MOSFET
Funding Text 1: The effects of a cosmic ray environment on power DMOS FET's were researched and documented extensively. Two failure modes were identified. The main failure mode observed was single event burnout (SEB), which was catastrophic, resulting in drain-to-gate and drain-to-source resistive shorts. The other failure mqde observed was single event gate rupture (SEGR), which was detrimental to the device's performance and resulted in an increase of gate and drain leakage currents. Hypothetically, single event burnout is caused by avalanche breakdown of the parasitic NPN bipolar transistor inherent in the MOSFET To prevent single event burnout, process and design modifications were directed at reducing the parasitic NPN transistor bipolar effects and suppressing the turn-on of said bipolar. To prevent single event gate rupture, process and design modifications were directed toward reducing the electric fields along the gate oxide interface. However, only those changes that were thought to reduce the probability of a cosmic-ray-induced failure were implemented. Burnout threshold voltage and gate rupture effects were evaluated on devices which had been fabricated with specific changes and, subsequently, were exposed to heavy ions. One design variation implemented to suppress the burnout and gate This work, performed by Harris Semiconductor rupture mechanisms resulted in a major at Mountaintop, was supported by tpe Defense redesign of the typical power DMOS cell and Nuclear Agency through Naval Weapons Support will be designated as the "New Structure" Center under Contract Number N00164-86-C-0182. (NS). The layout of that design is not shown.

Authors: Turflinger T.L., Davey M.V.

Abstract: Extracting error data during transient radiation and heavy ion exposure of high-speed Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADC) presents unique radiation testing problems. The volume of data precludes simple test and analysis. Test techniques have been developed for both heavy ion and prompt gamma environments. Preliminary test data is shown to support validity of the test techniques. © 1989 IEEE

Authors: Enlow E.W., Pease R.L., Combs W.E., Platteter D.G.
Title: Total dose induced hole trapping in trench oxides
Affiliations: Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road, SE., Albuquerque, NM 87106–4245, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Enlow, E.W., Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road, SE., Albuquerque, NM 87106–4245, United States; Pease, R.L., Mission Research Corporation, 1720 Randolph Road, SE., Albuquerque, NM 87106–4245, United States; Combs, W.E., Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN, 47522, United States; Platteter, D.G., Naval Weapons Support Center, Bldg. 2087, Code 6054, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Abstract: Ionization effects in polysilicon filled trenches used for component isolation in an advanced commercial bipolar technology are examined. Contact to the trench polysilicon was used to sweep the subthreshold characteristics of a parasitic trench field effect transistor formed by the trench and two buried layers. The subthreshold charge separation technique was used to analyze the buildup of trapped holes and interface states. For typical microcircuit layouts, (the trench polysilicon is ground or floating) the irradiation data at a total dose of greater than 1 Mrad(SiO2) showed identical saturation of the threshold voltage shift and minimal interface state buildup regardless of the source and drain irradiation bias conditions. However, the radiation responses for the various irradiation bias conditions prior to saturation were significantly different. Discussions on the complex irradiation response and implications for the use of trenched bipolar microcircuits in radiation environments are provided. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Ionization; Oxides; Semiconducting Silicon; Transistors, Field Effect; Polysilicon; Total Dose Induced Hole Trapping; Transistors, Bipolar

Authors: Canning F.X.
Title: Singular Value Decomposition of Integral Equations of EM and Applications to the Cavity Resonance Problem
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Center, Rockwell International Science Center, 1049 Camino Dos Rios, China Lake, CA Thousand Oaks, CA 91360, United States
Authors with affiliations: Canning, F.X., Naval Weapons Center, Rockwell International Science Center, 1049 Camino Dos Rios, China Lake, CA Thousand Oaks, CA 91360, United States
Abstract: The use of the method of moments (MM) based on the electric field integral equation is considered for conducting bodies with closed regions. For such a calculation, the scattered field is theoretically well defined, but numerical problems have been found near resonant frequencies. To study these problems, the use of the singular value decomposition (SVD) in moment method calculations is developed, and the reason the SVD is the appropriate tool for the numerical analysis of any moment method calculation (even when the matrix equation is to be solved by an iterative technique) is shown. In particular, the SVD casts a moment method calculation into a diagonal form, which allows a careful numerical analysis. The problems near resonance are found to be due to the creation of an approximate impedance matrix Z, which has the wrong resonant frequency (i.e., it is not consistent with that of the radiation problem). One numerical method that avoids these difficulties by using the SVD is discussed, and other more efficient ways of avoiding the usual numerical difficulties are suggested. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Integral Equations; Resonators, Cavity; Cavity Resonance Problem; Method of Moments; Singular Value Decomposition; Electromagnetic Waves

Authors: Koshigoe S., Gutmark E., Schadow K.C.
Title: Initial development of noncircular jets leading to axis switching
Affiliations: Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States; Department of Physics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koshigoe, S., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States; Gutmark, E., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States; Schadow, K.C., Research Department, Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States, Department of Physics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the underlying mechanisms for the deformation of coherent structures which occurs in the initial stage of the axis switching of noncircular jets. The generalized shooting method is applied to jets with elliptic-core and equilateral-triangular-core regions of constant flow. The analysis reveals that in order to have the deformation, three requirements must be present in the behavior of the eigenmodes of noncircular jets: 1) the eigenfunctions are localized without excessive overlapping; 2) the amplification rates of the corresponding eigenmodes are comparable; and 3) sufficient phase speed difference exists between the eigenmodes. The qualitative behavior of the noncircular jets found through the numerical analysis is compared with experimental results and are in good correlation with them. © 1989 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Flow of Fluids - Jets; Mathematical Techniques - Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions; Structural Analysis; Axis Switching; Noncircular Jets; Rayleigh Equation; Structural Deformation; Triangular Core Jets; Aircraft

Abstract: This paper describes the radiation improvements obtained by fabricating bipolar integrated circuits on oxygen-implanted silicon-on-insulator substrates which were manufactured with multiple (low-dose) implants. Bipolar 74ALSOO gates fabricated on these substrates showed an improvement in total dose and dose-rate radiation response over identical circuits fabricated in bulk silicon. © 1988 IEEE.

Authors: Stilwell D.E.
Title: Electrochemistry of Conductive Polymers IV Electrochemical Studies on Polyaniline Degradation—Product Identification and Coulometric Studies
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Center, California 93555, United States; Department of Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87131, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stilwell, D.E., Naval Weapons Center, California 93555, United States, Department of Chemistry, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87131, United States
Abstract: Electrochemical studies on the degradation reactions of oxidized polyaniline (PA) have been carried out to identify major soluble degradation products. As a result of spot tests as well as spectrophotometric experiments, p-benzoquinone (BQ) was identified as a major degradation product. The overall number of electrons consumed per anilinium unit for the oxidation followed by degradation of PA was determined to be approximately two employing coulometric experiments. The yield for the BQ generation was close to 100% based on this number of electrons transferred. During the later stages of the degradation, the net hydrolysis rate follows first-order kinetics and is a function of the film thickness. In addition, the hydrolysis reaction is shown to cease upon open circuit of the cell. Finally, a reaction mechanism which accounts for the observed behaviors is proposed. © 1988, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Ionizing radiation failure thresholds were measured across a silicon wafer using 10-keV X-rays to determine the success of hardened process modifications and to examine wafer-level hardness-assurance screening techniques. Topological wafer maps of the total-dose failure response for Signetics 74F00 circuits are presented.

Authors: Anderson J., Denton R., Smith M.
Title: CONTAMINATED ANTISTATIC POLYETHYLENE.
Affiliations: US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA, US Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, J., US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA, US Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, IN, USA; Denton, R., US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA, US Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, IN, USA; Smith, M., US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA, US Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, IN, USA
Abstract: Anstistatic polyethylene materials from a major supply house are found to be contaminated with an organic acid which reacts with solder coatings. The chemical reaction produces a white, fibrous contamination on the solder surface. The contaminant was identified as a Lead salt of n-octanoic acid. When the contaminant is chemically and abrasively removed the surface appears pitted, indicating material is being depleted from the solder. The effect of the contaminated antistatic polyethylene packages and bags is to degrade the solderability of the ESD sensitive electronic components they are designed to protect.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTROSTATICS - Electric Charge; ANTISTATIC POLYETHYLENE; FIBROUS CONTAMINATION; NICHROME RESISTORS; ORGANIC ACID; SENSITIVE ELECTRONIC COMPONENTS; SOLDERABILITY; POLYETHYLENES

Authors: Linsteadt G.F., Doig III L.L.
Title: Maintaining the high-tech edge: Governmentindustry technology transfer and the federal laboratory system in California
Affiliations: Industrial and Governmental Liaison Office, Naval Weapons Center, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Linsteadt, G.F., Industrial and Governmental Liaison Office, Naval Weapons Center, California, United States; Doig III, L.L.
Abstract: One of the important resources to any state, such as California, is the technology that is available from the many federally operated and/or funded laboratories within its borders. In this age of technology a state needs to take advantage of applications of modern technology and innovative exploitation of human and natural resources. This article illuminates the importance of the Federal Government research laboratories. Many examples are presented to support the argument that the Federal Government research laboratories can be and often are substantial contributors to the storehouse of technology that finds its way to the private sector and public sector. Several types of technology transfer are discussed, i.e. primary technology, secondary applications, mission related, technical assistance and cooperative. In addition the article discusses the structure and logic of the Federal Laboratory Consortium for Technology Transfer (FLC). The legislaltion that has helped to make the FLC effective is discussed. Included in the discussion are insights of how the FLC operates and how the private sector and public sector may use the FLC in order to locate process, product and service technology. © 1987 Technology Transfer Society.

Authors: Walker P.L.
Title: Beam propagation through slab scattering media in the small angle approximation
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Center, CA, 93555, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walker, P.L., Naval Weapons Center, CA, 93555, United States
Abstract: A general solution to the radiative transfer equation applicable to beam propagation inscattering media in which scattering takes placeprincipally in extreme forward direction was obtained by H. S. Snider and W. T.Scott [Phys. Rev.76, 220 (1949)] and discussed by R. L. Fante [IEEE Trans. Antennas Propag. AP-21, 750 (1973)]. This solution is applicable to media in which theaerosol number densities are nonuniformly distributed in space. Subsequently, W. G. Tam and A. Zardecki [Appl. Opt. 21, 2405 (1982)] obtained a specific solution applicable to those cases in which the beam width and angular spread as well as the aerosol phase function can be approximatedby a Gaussian. Their solution is restricted to uniform or step function shaped media in which the detector is in the scattering medium. The present work shows that the Tam and Zardecki approach can be applied to the inhomogeneous case. Specifically, a solution is obtainedfor a slab shaped scattering medium. The results are compared with those obtained by use of a Monte Carlo simulation and to experimental data. © 1987, Optical Society of America.
References: Walker, P.L., to be submitted for publication; Fante, R.L., Propagation of Electromagnetic Waves through Turbulent Plasma using Transport Theory (1973) IEEE Trans. Antennas Propag. Authors: Titus J.L., Platteter D.G.
Title: Wafer mapping of total dose failure thresholds in a bipolar recessed field oxide technology
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Support Center, Code 60541, Building 2087, Crane, Indiana 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Titus, J.L., Naval Weapons Support Center, Code 60541, Building 2087, Crane, Indiana 47522, United States; Platteter, D.G., Naval Weapons Support Center, Code 60541, Building 2087, Crane, Indiana 47522, United States
Abstract: Ionizing radiation failure thresholds were measured across a silicon wafer using 10 KeY x-rays to determine the success of hardened process modifications and to examine wafper level hardness assurance screening techniques. Topological wafer maps of the total dose failure response for Signetics 74F00 circuits are presented. Copyright © 1987 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Paulos J.J., Bishop R.J., Turflinger T.L.
Title: Radiation-Induced response of operational amplifiers in low-level transient radiation environments
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh. NC 27695–7911, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Code 6054, Building 2087, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paulos, J.J., Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh. NC 27695–7911, United States; Bishop, R.J., Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh. NC 27695–7911, United States; Turflinger, T.L., Naval Weapons Support Center, Code 6054, Building 2087, Crane, IN 47522, United States
Abstract: Extensive computer simulations have been performed on CMOS and bipolar operational amplifiers in an attempt to obtain a better understanding of low-level transient radiation response mechanisms. The simulation methodology has been confirmed using flash X-ray data for the amplifiers studied. Variations in circuit response to loading and feedback configuration have been explored, and several generalizations can be made which may provide a useful basis for a specification methodology. Authors: Summers G.P., Dale C.J., Burke E.A., Wolicki E.A., Marshall P.W., Gehlhausen M.A.
Title: Correlation of particle-induced displacement damage in silicon
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, 20375, United States; Mission Research Corporation, San Diego, CA, 92123, United States; Wolicki Associates, Alwexandria, VA, 22307, United States; Sachs/Freeman Associates, Landover, MD, 20785, United States; Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Summers, G.P., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, 20375, United States; Dale, C.J., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, 20375, United States; Burke, E.A., Mission Research Corporation, San Diego, CA, 92123, United States; Wolicki, E.A., Wolicki Associates, Alwexandria, VA, 22307, United States; Marshall, P.W., Sachs/Freeman Associates, Landover, MD, 20785, United States; Gehlhausen, M.A., Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane, IN, 47522, United States
Abstract: Correlation is made between the effects of displacement damage caused in several types of silicon bipolar transistors by protons, deuterons, helium ions, and by 1 MeV equivalent neutrons. These measurements are compared to calculations of the nonionizing energy deposition in silicon as a function of particle type and energy. Measurements were made of displacement damage factors for 2N2222A and 2N2907A switching transistors, and for 2N3055, 2N6678, and 2N6547 power transistors, as a function of collector current using 3.7 - 175 MeV protons, 4.3 - 37 MeV deuterons, and 16.8 - 65 MeV helium ions. Long term ionization effects on the value of the displacement damage factors were taken into account. In calculating the energy dependence of the nonionizing energy deposition, Rutherford, nuclear elastic, and nuclear inelastic interactions, and Lindhard energy partition were considered. The main conclusions of the work are as follows: 1) The ratio of the displacement damage factors for a given charged particle to the 1 MeV equivalent neutron damage factor, as a function of energy, falls on a common curve which is independent of collector current. 2) Deuterons of a given energy are about twice as damaging as protons and helium ions are about eighteen times as damaging as protons. 3) The ratios of the calculated nonionizing energy deposition in silicon by protons, deuterons, and helium ions as a function of energy to the calculated nonionizing energy deposition by 1 MeV neutrons, agree exactly with the experimental damage factor ratios over the whole energy range considered, with no fitted parameters. 4) This agreement means that there is a linear dependence of the experimental displacement damage factors on nonionizing energy deposition for all particles (including neutrons) and for all energies. 5) Therefore, the damage factors for different particles are directly proportional to the number of defects originally produced, are not affected by defect cascades, and are independent of the PKA spectrum. Copyright © 1987 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Schadow K.C., Wilson K.J., Lee M.J., Gutmark E.
Title: Enhancement of mixing in reacting fuel-rich plumes issued from elliptical nozzles
Affiliations: Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States; University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schadow, K.C., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States; Wilson, K.J., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States; Lee, M.J., Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, CA, United States; Gutmark, E., University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: The mixing of jets and reacting fuel-rich plumes issued from elliptical and circular nozzles was compared in the tests reported in this paper. In nonreacting tests with hotwire probes, the jet issued from an elliptical nozzle mixed faster with a coaxial, ducted airstrcam than a jet issued from a circular nozzle. In combustion tests with thermocouples, mixing between the reacting fuel-rich plume and the coaxial air was also enhanced with elliptical nozzles. This resulted in higher local combustion temperatures and therefore higher reaction rates near the nozzle exit. In both cases, the tests were done at high Reynolds numbers and turbulent initial conditions. © 1987 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: FLAME RESEARCH; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Mixing; PLUME COMBUSTION; PLUME/AIR MIXING; ROCKET ENGINES

Authors: Haag Randy, Hall Steve
Title: SATELLITE BATTERY TESTING STATUS - NAVAL WEAPONS SUPPORT CENTER CRANE, INDIANA.
Affiliations: US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA, US Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Haag, Randy, US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA, US Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, IN, USA; Hall, Steve, US Naval Weapons Support Cent,, Crane, IN, USA, US Naval Weapons Support Cent, Crane, IN, USA
Abstract: Because of the large numbers of satellite cells currently being tested and anticipated at the Naval Weapons Support Center (NAVWPNSUPPCEN) Crane, Indiana, satellite cell testing is being integrated into the Battery Test Automation Project (BTAP). The BTAP, designed to meet the growing needs for battery testing at the NAVWPNSUPPCEN Crane, will consist of several Automated Test Stations (ATSs) which monitor batteries under test. Each ATS will interface with an Automation Network Controller (ANC) which will collect test data for reduction.

Authors: Hartley G.A.
Title: Pitch axis control system design for QF-4 Full-Scale Aircraft Target
Affiliations: Weapons Department, Weapons Development Division, Naval Weapons Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hartley, G.A., Weapons Department, Weapons Development Division, Naval Weapons Center, United States
Abstract: The pitch axis control system of the QF-4 Full-Scale Aircraft Target is a digital control system which allows a remote operator to control the remotely piloted vehicle in an interactive mode or in one of the automatic hold modes. The interactive all-attitude pitch rate controller is designed to meet the MIL-F-8785C flying qualities specification for damping ratio and normal acceleration to angle of attack sensitivity at Level 2 or better for combat aircraft. The pitch rate controller is used as an inner loop for all of the automatic hold modes to provide increased damping and more accurate holding capability. The automatic hold modes include attitude hold, altitude hold, Mach hold, and normal acceleration hold. The basic analyses are presented in this report deriving the control models and determining the gain schedules required to meet system specifications. Copyright © 1986 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Angle of attack; Angle of attack indicators; Controllers; Damping; Digital control systems; Flight control systems; Specifications; Target drones; Aircraft targets; Combat aircraft; Flying quality; Gain schedule; Interactive mode; Remote operator; Remotely piloted vehicles; System specification; Aircraft control
